otherData.headline: Don Blankenship's Mine Took This Man's Son, Brother And Nephew. Now Blankenship Wants His Vote.
otherData.short_description: To those who lost loved ones at Upper Big Branch, the former coal CEO's Senate run in West Virginia feels like harassment.

articleContent: SHREWSBURY, W.Va. â€• Don Blankenship had been out of prison for only seven months when Tommy Davis started seeing his face and hearing his voice everywhere. Blankenship launched his bid to become West Virginiaâ€™s next Republican senator late last year and started buying advertisements on local TV stations. They all began with a line that nauseated Davis: â€œIâ€™m Don Blankenship, candidate for U.S. Senate, and I approve this message.â€

Davis stopped watching the local news to avoid the ads, retreating to the reliably Blankenship-free zones of hunting shows and Netflix. But then Blankenshipâ€™s voice was there in Davisâ€™ pickup truck, via Pandora radio advertising. Davis had to limit his use of that, too, lest driving around town become its own form of torment.
â€œIt seems no matter where I go or what I do, itâ€™s Don Blankenship,â€ Davis, 50, said recently, driving along the Kanawha River in his Toyota Tacoma.

Blankenship is the former Massey Energy chief executive who presided over the Upper Big Branch mining disaster, in Montcoal, West Virginia, in 2010. Davis was a miner at Upper Big Branch with his eldest son, Cory Davis; his only brother, Timmy Davis; and a nephew, Joshua Napper. Davis was making his way out of the mine during a shift change when the explosion happened. He bolted to the exit, wind and rocks tumbling around him, and made it out alive.

Twenty-nine men did not, including his three loved ones. The bodies of his son, brother and nephew were recovered together days after the blast, once it was safe to do so. Cory was the youngest of the dead at 20 years old.

Various investigations faulted Massey officials for systematically cutting corners on safety and putting profits before their workersâ€™ lives. They found that Massey, under Blankenshipâ€™s helm, had fostered a culture of fear and intimidation inside the mine and hidden safety lapses from regulators. Blankenship served one year in prison on a misdemeanor conviction for conspiring to violate mine safety laws. He has continued to deny responsibility for the worst mining catastrophe in four decades.

The particular void left by Cory Boy, as Davis still refers to his son â€• â€œmy hunting partner, my fishing partner, my all-around go-to buddyâ€ â€• has made the Blankenship redemption tour an unbearable spectacle for Davis, just as it has for other Upper Big Branch families.
â€œI actually thought he would stay the hell out of West Virginia,â€ Davis said of Blankenship. â€œHe just wonâ€™t leave it alone.â€
â€œHeâ€™s trying to put it back in our face. I call it harassment,â€ he continued. â€œThatâ€™s what it is: Itâ€™s straight-up harassment.â€

Blankenship has spent $2 million of his own money on the campaign and has savaged his main Republican primary opponents, Congressman Evan Jenkins and West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey, in hopes of facing off in a general election against incumbent Sen. Joe Manchin (D), whom he personally blames for his prison sentence. Blankenshipâ€™s campaign did not respond to several interview requests for this story.

Although Blankenship has slipped behind Jenkins and Morrisey in recent polls, buried in attack ads the GOP establishment is funding to keep him off the ticket, his candidacy is not a joke. For all his infamy, plenty of voters still associate him with good-paying blue-collar jobs in hollows without a whole lot of them. As Davis put it, â€œThere are still people around here who worship the ground he walks on.â€
The prospect of Sen. Don Blankenship, however unlikely, has polluted even the most solemn customs for Davis.

On April 5, he and other Upper Big Branch families made the drive up to the mine to observe the eighth anniversary of the disaster. Davis carries out the same ritual each year. He picks up 29 balloons â€• 26 black and three orange, the latter signifying his family members â€• then heads to Coryâ€™s grave with his ex-wife, Cindy; their two sons, Seth and Nathan; and their grandson, Cory Tripp. There they release the balloons and talk.

Then itâ€™s on to the mine site, where each of the dead has a cross. Davis hangs a wreath for all the miners and lays out three white roses for his family members. He ties a white bandana to Coryâ€™s cross. He looks up to the spot on the mountain where he and the other miners would punch out at the end of their shifts. Then they drive down Coal River Road to the 48-foot granite memorial that was erected in 2012, showing 29 minersâ€™ silhouettes.

It was at the memorial where things got unpleasant at this yearâ€™s anniversary gathering. Among the families, politicians and news crews was Gwen Thomas, the sister of Grover Skeens, one of the miners who was killed. Thomas has taken an unusual position among Upper Big Branch family members: She has called the disaster an act of God and praised Blankenship, who in turn has featured Thomas in a television ad and on the campaign trail.

The presence of an outspoken Blankenship supporter at the memorial was too much for Davis and other mourners. She defended the former CEO; they gave her a piece of their minds. A state trooper intervened.

Davis has tried to curb his Facebook time during the Senate race. The night before the anniversary, he visited Blankenshipâ€™s campaign page, where the candidate posts videos and says heâ€™ll bring jobs back to West Virginia. Davis uploaded a photo of Coryâ€™s gravesite onto Blankenshipâ€™s page. â€œHere look at my Cory boy 20 years young,â€ Davis wrote. â€œTell him why you chose production over safety.â€
The next time Davis visited the page, his post was gone.

On a recent Friday morning, Davis steered his ATV up a gravel road to a former strip-mining site, the back of his vehicle loaded with turkey decoys, spare camo clothes and a 12-gauge shotgun. What had once been a mountaintop now felt more like prairie, with long, flat stretches of grass and brush lying between hills. Davis used to work on sites like this one as a surface miner as they were stripped. Now he comes here to run his dogs, call for turkeys, or climb a treestand and wait for a buck.

The time in the woods is bittersweet. It was his brother, Timmy, who taught him how to hunt, and Davis passed everything he knew on to Cory, who shot his first whitetail when he was 9. Now he mostly hunts alone, but he appreciates the quiet of the woods more than ever. Besides, any time spent in a treestand is time spent not drinking.
â€œIf I sit at home and dwell on things,â€ he said with a turkey call in his mouth, â€œitâ€™ll just fuck me up.â€

A few months after the disaster, Davis went back to work at a mine run by Alpha Natural Resources, the coal giant that would go on to acquire Massey. He still had a ringing in his ears from the blast and what would turn out to be post-traumatic stress disorder. He struggled with loud sounds. He had panic attacks.
â€œI just couldnâ€™t sleep,â€ he said. â€œI couldnâ€™t think. I couldnâ€™t function. I was getting lost. I was having problems.â€

He accepted a settlement for his sonâ€™s death and stopped working. Some families used their money to leave the state and start new lives. Davis stayed in West Virginia but as a slightly different person. He covered his body in tattoos, including 29 crosses along his back and the words â€œCory Boyâ€ across his shoulders. He customized a Harley as a rolling memorial to Upper Big Branch.

A couple of years ago, he sold the house where Cory grew up because the memories were too painful. He bought a small ranch house at the end of a street of trailers that backs up on the Kanawha, far enough from the highway that all he hears at night is the river.

He started an annual scholarship at Coryâ€™s high school in his name. The unofficial mission is to give kids better options than hoping for a coal resurgence. The lack of good-paying work is why people cling to someone like Blankenship, Davis said.

â€œJust look around you. There ainâ€™t a hellacious lot to do here if you didnâ€™t go to college,â€ he said. â€œThe guys who support [Blankenship] â€• they donâ€™t have other options as far as jobs go.â€

Moving on has not been easy. He ends up at Coryâ€™s grave every other night or so, drinking a beer and turning one upside down for his son. Coryâ€™s friends are at the stage where theyâ€™ve started families, and Davis finds himself wondering if Cory would have had a son, too: â€œWould he have been tall or short, fat or skinny, would he have looked more like him or more like her, and other questions weâ€™ll never know the answer to.â€

Blankenshipâ€™s visibility and lack of contrition have made it all the harder. He has maintained, contrary to official investigations, that the root cause of the blast at Upper Big Branch was a sudden influx of natural gas in the mine, rather than an excessive amount of coal dust, which is highly explosive. The distinction is crucial. Coal operators have an obligation to keep coal dust levels in check, through sufficient ventilation and rock-dusting, a process that neutralizes coal dust with pulverized limestone.

What happened at Upper Big Branch was investigated by federal regulators, state regulators, the United Mine Workers of America union, and an independent panel established by Manchin, who was West Virginiaâ€™s governor at the time. To varying degrees, they all faulted Massey for poor ventilation and inadequate rock-dusting practices in the mine.

The explosion likely started when the shearer on a mining machine ignited a methane fireball, thanks in part to poorly maintained equipment. But it would have been the high levels of coal dust that sent it ripping through more than 2 miles of the mine shaft, so that even men far from the blast couldnâ€™t escape. (The UMWA went so far as to title its report â€œIndustrial Homicide.â€)
Davis remembers the dust being so thick that day he could see it. Other miners recalled the air belowground flowing in odd directions before the explosion.
Blankenshipâ€™s natural gas theory conveniently absolves him of the chronic failures investigators found.
â€œItâ€™s just not substantiated,â€ said Celeste Monforton, a safety expert who was part of the independent panel, which also faulted federal and state regulators for not adequately policing Massey.

â€œIt was a coal dust explosion. The fingerprint mapping that was done to find a cause â€• all of that evidence indicated that,â€ she said. â€œAll of the analytical work that was done, taking all the dust samples, an extraordinary amount of evidence showed that.â€

Blankenship has also claimed that the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration forced Massey to change its ventilation plans before the explosion, suggesting MSHA may be to blame for the disaster. The independent panel found no evidence of that. However, it did find regulators failed at Upper Big Branch â€• by not cracking down hard enough on Massey.

As Blankenship has blamed natural gas and MSHA for the disaster while on the campaign trail, Robert Atkins has been there to fact-check him. Atkins lost his son Jason at Upper Big Branch. He has made a point of showing up at Blankenshipâ€™s town hall meetings to speak directly to undecided voters and rebut Blankenshipâ€™s telling of events. He estimates heâ€™s gone to five campaign events and has spoken one-on-one with 50 voters, urging them to vote for anyone but Blankenship. His wife joined him for the first event, but couldnâ€™t do any more.

â€œShe just couldnâ€™t take it,â€ Atkins said. â€œIâ€™ve got in my head, and I feel Iâ€™m right, that that man killed my son. And when he killed my son, it took the life out of me, out of his mom, and out of his brother. ... The man has no remorse.â€

According to the independent panel, the deeper cause of the disaster was what they called â€œthe Massey Way.â€ Under Masseyâ€™s corporate culture, miners were to run coal at all costs. The mine continued operating even when airflow was dangerously low. Workers lacked basic safety equipment while having to file regular production reports. Methane detectors were disabled to avoid having to shut down the mine if levels got too high. And workers were instructed to tip off colleagues belowground when federal safety inspectors showed up.

Massey enforced this system through intimidation, investigators found. Workers testified after the explosion that they did what they were told because they feared for their jobs. Managers belittled miners who couldnâ€™t get with the program. The company had a slogan: â€œS1 P2,â€ for safety first and production second. According to Davis, the joke among miners was that it was really â€œP1 S2.â€

As his ATV lurched up and down the ravines, Davis tried to explain the grip Blankenship had on his mines. He had worked at other Massey properties before Upper Big Branch. He remembers eating lunch out of his pocket as he worked, reluctant to slow production with a proper break. He didnâ€™t speak up about hazards, either, fearful of losing the job that he desperately needed.

He recalled the pressure workers felt whenever Blankenship showed up in his car or helicopter. Someone would shout to him as he cut coal with the highwall miner machine: â€œTommy, whatever it is youâ€™re cutting, keep it rolling. Do not stop. Do. Not. Stop.â€
â€œThat money was feeding their kids and paying for their trucks. They were proud of that and didnâ€™t want to lose that,â€ Davis said. â€œDon Blankenship scared those people to death.â€

Three Upper Big Branch managers went to prison before Blankenship, all found to have deceived regulators or investigators in covering up safety problems. Blankenship was charged with three counts: securities fraud, making false statements to officials, and conspiring to violate mine safety regulations. A jury found him guilty only of the latter charge.

Davis attended every day of the two-month trial that he could, making a point to sit near Blankenshipâ€™s supporters. He wore the same outfit each day so Blankenship could better recognize him: a plaid shirt with a green jacket and an Under Armour hat. The one-year sentence handed down â€• the maximum the judge could impose under the misdemeanor conviction â€• infuriated Davis, considering Blankenship had been facing up to 30 years under the original charges. (The conspiracy charge was not directly linked to the disaster itself.)

Outside the courthouse, a television reporter asked Davis why he was so frustrated. His raw and eloquent response, delivered with a quaking voice, would be viewed over a million times online: â€œIf you was where I was that day, and you seen my son after laying in there for five days, and seen what he looked like â€• if you worked on them men like we did when they come outside, if you smelled them, and you looked at them, then youâ€™d know where I come from.â€

The 12-month sentence didnâ€™t make Blankenship any more penitent. He declared himself a political prisoner. He published a 67-page booklet from his low-security prison in California, proclaiming his innocence and propagating conspiracy theories about a government cover-up. He promoted a 2014 â€œdocumentaryâ€ heâ€™d funded, called â€œUpper Big Branch â€• Never Again,â€ faulting the feds for the disaster. He blamed Manchin personally for his prosecution, taking his feud to Twitter.

As West Virginiaâ€™s governor, Manchin was at Upper Big Branch in the days following the explosion. He and Davis have since become friends. Davis said he often gets a call from a number he keeps in his cell as â€œSenator Joe,â€ and itâ€™s Manchin asking how heâ€™s doing. They talk about motorcycles, Blankenship and whatever else Davis has on his mind. (Manchinâ€™s uncle died in the Farmington Mine Disaster, along with 77 others, in 1968.)

Davis said Manchinâ€™s campaign has never asked anything of him, though he would happily oblige if it did, particularly if Blankenship wins the Republican nomination on May 8. â€œHeâ€™s the only politician whoâ€™s been there the whole time,â€ Davis said of Manchin. â€œHe wonâ€™t say it, but I will.â€

On a Thursday in mid-April, Davis learned that Blankenship would be attending a meet-the-candidates forum that night in Chelyan, just across the river from Davisâ€™ home. He was surprised the Senate hopeful would have the nerve to show up to a public event so close to Upper Big Branch, an area where Blankenship campaign signs appear to be sparse. Davis had told himself that he wouldnâ€™t attend town hall-style events, knowing he might lose control in an encounter with Blankenship. He decided to bend his rule.

He removed the gun from his truck and told his buddy Gary Price to meet him down at the community center, where Blankenship would be. When Davis got there, a handful of police officers who already knew him came outside to greet him. They told Davis he could say whatever he wanted to Blankenship, so long as he kept some distance and didnâ€™t threaten him.

Davis took a sign from his truck and laid it across his windshield. It said: â€œCory Davis 5/22/89 - 4/5/10. Don Blankenship murdered him over coal and money.â€ Price parked his truck in front of the buildingâ€™s main exit, dragging a custom trailer that has a dedication to Cory on one side and the names of every miner killed at Upper Big Branch on the other. Davis waited outside to confront the candidate as he left the event.

He saw Blankenship walk to the glass doors and stop, the memorial display laid out in front of him. Then he watched Blankenship turn and head toward another exit, accompanied by what appeared to be an aide. They hopped in a car and left, before any words could be exchanged with Davis.
Another Republican candidate, Jack Newbrough, came out the doors to take a break. â€œIâ€™m sorry for your loss, Tommy,â€ he said, shaking Davisâ€™ hand. â€œI sure would love to have your support.â€

Davis let the invitation hang in the air. He thanked his friend Price for coming out, then headed to his truck and off to the bar to have a beer. Although there was no confrontation, he considered his trip to the forum a success. He felt heâ€™d shamed Blankenship for coming into his end of the valley. He noted that Blankenship never looked him in the eye. He believes the man feels guilt, despite everything heâ€™s said to the contrary.

â€œThat boy of mine, he canâ€™t speak out no more, so I speak out for him,â€ Davis said. â€œThatâ€™s why I do it â€• to make sure Blankenship doesnâ€™t forget it. Just like Iâ€™m sitting here thinking about him, now heâ€™s driving home thinking about Cory and those men.â€

otherData.headline: Chilean Clergy Abuse Victims Took Their Stories Of Survival To Pope Francis
otherData.short_description: â€œToday I have more hope in the future of our church," said Juan Carlos Cruz. "Even though the task is enormous.â€

articleContent: Three Chilean survivors of clergy sex abuse said they are encouraged after private meetings with Pope Francis at the Vatican.

The conversations, which took place over the weekend at the popeâ€™s Casa Santa Marta residence, were arranged by the Vatican after Francis received harsh criticism for his handling of the sex abuse crisis in Chile.

On Twitter, JosÃ© AndrÃ©s Murillo said he tried to emphasize to the pope that the abuse he had suffered as a teenager at the hands of a pedophile priest was specifically an â€œabuse of power.â€ He wrote that he had spoken to Francis for two hours. Another victim, James Hamilton, tweeted that his conversation with Francis was â€œenormously constructiveâ€ and that he left it â€œvery happy and satisfied.â€
Juan Carlos Cruz, the third victim, wrote on Twitter that he had spoken privately with Francis for more than 2Â½ hours on Sunday.

â€œHe listened to me with great respect, affection and closeness, like a father. We talked about many subjects,â€ Cruz wrote. â€œToday I have more hope in the future of our church... even though the task is enormous.â€

Before the meetings, Vatican spokesman Greg Burke announced that the Holy See will not be releasing official press statements about the conversations, since Francisâ€™ primary intention was to â€œlisten to the victims, ask them for forgiveness and respect the confidentiality of these meetings.â€

Francis had previously received sharp rebuke from clergy sex abuse victims and their advocates after he was caught on tape in January accusing the men of slander against Chileâ€™s Bishop Juan Barros. Murillo, Hamilton and Cruz claim Barros witnessed abuse carried out by the Rev. Fernando Karadima but did nothing to stop it. The three men testified against Karadima during a Vatican trial that eventually led to the priestâ€™s conviction in 2011. Barros continues to deny knowing about the abuse.
Francis appointed Barros to lead the diocese of Osorno in 2015 despite protestations from Chilean politicians and local Catholic clergy.

Earlier this month, Francis admitted that he had made â€œserious errorsâ€ in handling Chileâ€™s sex abuse scandal due to a â€œlack of truthful and balanced information.â€ In a rare move, he also summoned all 32 of Chileâ€™s bishops to Rome during the third week of May to discuss the allegations against Barros.

Anne Barrett Doyle, co-director of BishopAccountability, an organization that tracks clergy sex abuse worldwide, said that she was moved by the â€œgraciousnessâ€ of the three men after their meetings with Francis.

â€œGiven the years of silence and disrespect theyâ€™ve endured from church officials, including Pope Francis, they could have refused the popeâ€™s invitation,â€ she told HuffPost in an email. â€œBut always, Juan Carlos Cruz, Jimmy Hamilton and JosÃ© AndrÃ©s Murillo focus on the bigger picture â€• in this case, the plight of the many Chilean victims who have no voice, and the ongoing safety crisis in Chilean parishes and Catholic schools.â€

Barrett Doyle cautioned that speaking with survivors is a start, but it doesnâ€™t constitute change. She hopes that, along with removing Barros and other Chilean clergy who were aware of Karadimaâ€™s crimes, Francis will also create an efficient system for investigating and disciplining bishops who have enabled child abuse.

â€œMeeting with survivors is a time-tested, winning public relations tactic for popes and bishops,â€ Barrett Doyle said. â€œTime will tell whether these meetings were mere damage control or a precursor of desperately needed systemic change in the global Catholic church.â€

otherData.headline: Wealthy Texas Couple Accused Of Enslaving Young Woman For 16 Years
otherData.short_description: One of the suspects is the son of Guinea's first president, CNN reports.

articleContent: A Texas couple has been accused of holding a Guinean girl against her will for more than a decade, all the while subjecting her to abuse and forcing her to perform household chores.

Mohamed Toure and his wife, Denise Cros-Toure, both 57, allegedly forced the girl to sleep on the floor in their Southlake home and subjected her to beatings with belts and electrical cords, federal investigators said.

According to the Justice Department, the girl, who is not named in court documents, does not even know her birthdate. She told authorities the Toure family brought her to the United States from Guinea in 2000, when she was about 5 years old. She said the family never celebrated her birthday or enrolled her in school.

â€œThroughout the years ... the defendants forced the victim to labor in their home for long hours without pay,â€ the Justice Department said in an April 26 press release. â€œThe defendants required her to cook, clean, do the laundry, perform yard work, and paint, as well as care for their five children.â€

The criminal complaint filed by prosecutors further alleges the girl was regularly referred to as â€œa little nothing,â€ a slave, and on at least one occasion, a whore. She also allegedly told investigators Cros-Toure once assaulted her by grabbing one of her earrings and yanking it with such force that it tore her earlobe. The investigative documents indicate the girl has a visible scar on one of her ears.

Toure and his wife are natives of Guinea, and he is the son of Guineaâ€™s first president, Ahmed Sekou Toure, according to CNN. The Dallas Morning News reported that Cros-Toureâ€™s father was the nationâ€™s secretary of state at one point.
The couple lives in a $600,000 home and receives income from â€œsignificantâ€ overseas deposits, the Morning News said.

A 2002 police report obtained by The Washington Post indicates a Southlake police officer once found the girl sleeping on a bench at Bicentennial Park. She was â€œwearing dirty unkempt clothing and was very visibly scared and nervous,â€ the officer wrote. The cop, who suspected the girl was a runaway, returned her to the Toure residence.

It was not until 2016, after neighbors helped the girl escape, that authorities opened an investigation, according to court documents. That investigation came to a head on Wednesday, when Mohamed Toure and his wife were arrested and charged with forced, unpaid labor of a domestic servant.

A lawyer for the couple, Scott H. Palmer, said in a statement sent to The Dallas Morning News that the criminal complaint against his clients â€œis riddled with salacious allegations, fabrications and lies.â€
Palmer claims the girl was treated like a member of the Toure family and was allowed to communicate with relatives in Guinea, the outlet reported.

â€œWe look forward to amassing a mountain of evidence to refute the Governmentâ€™s portrayal of our clients,â€ Palmer said, â€œand look forward to revealing the motivation of this woman to lie, betray, and attempt to destroy the family that took her in at the request of her father for a better life in the United States.â€
If convicted, Toure and his wife face up to 20 years in prison.

otherData.short_description: Police said the panty caper was pulled off in less than four months.

articleContent: Authorities in Florida have arrested three people in connection with a brazen panty pilfering scheme that allegedly stole thousands of dollarsâ€™ worth of womenâ€™s unmentionables.

According to the Tallahassee Police Department, Quinessia Jackson, 29, and her fiancÃ©e, Coby Richardson, 47, are former employees of a logistics company that packages and ships Victoriaâ€™s Secret products.

Beginning in November 2017, customers whoâ€™d purchased panties online from Victoriaâ€™s Secret began complaining that their shipments were overdue. An internal investigation was launched. In March, it was allegedly discovered that Jaresa Frye, a 25-year-old friend of Jackson and Richardson, was selling new Victoriaâ€™s Secret underwear online.

Photos posted by Frye show that the merchandise being offered for sale was in the same barcoded bags used by the logistics company to track items prior to shipment, authorities said. The trail of plundered panties further pointed to Jackson and Richardson, police said, when it was discovered theyâ€™d been assigned to prepare the majority of the missing items for shipment.

Questioned about the lost undies, Richardson allegedly confessed to stealing and selling more than 400 packages of panties. Jackson, Richardson and Frye have since been charged with felony theft. Richardson also faces a charge of grand theft of items worth over $20,000, police said.
All three have since been released from jail after posting bonds totaling $35,000. It was unclear on Monday if any of the missing merchandise had been recovered.

otherData.headline: How Views On Guns Have Changed Since The Parkland Shooting
otherData.short_description: Interest in new gun restrictions went up at first. That hasn't necessarily lasted.

articleContent: The school shooting that took place in Parkland, Florida, earlier this year launched a new generation of gun control activists, inspired walkouts and marches, and sparked the most substantial â€• and long-lasting â€• shift in public opinion on guns in recent years. The appetite for gun control appears to have tapered off in the following weeks, but some surveys indicate that some changes in public opinion could endure.

In the more than two months since that shooting, HuffPost and YouGov have conducted five surveys tracking Americansâ€™ views on guns. The results show a burst of support for gun reform in the two weeks after the shooting, followed by a gradual reversion to the mean. Once-heightened concerns about gun violence have tapered back to previous levels, as has a desire for stricter gun laws and a belief that gun restrictions can be passed without violating Second Amendment rights.
A few changes in thought, however, seem to have stuck.

The percentage of Americans who believe itâ€™s politically possible to pass gun laws has dropped several points since its high in late February, but itâ€™s still higher than it was in the aftermath of last yearâ€™s massacres in Las Vegas and Sutherland Springs, Texas.

In the most recent survey, one-fifth of Americans also chose gun policies as one of the two issues they found most important. That remains a noticeable, if modest, uptick from the 13 percent who chose it as a priority following the shooting in Sutherland Springs. Other polling since the Parkland shooting also suggested gun control was carrying greater-than-usual prominence on the campaign trail, although itâ€™s unclear how much of that energy will remain until November.

That public opinion shifted at all in the wake of the shooting was striking. Itâ€™s even more striking that it lasted as long as it did. Last yearâ€™s shootings, by contrast, appeared to have little effect on Americansâ€™ views about guns.

One illustration of the uncommon nature of this yearâ€™s debate comes from Google Trends, which tracks the level interest in various search terms. According to that data, searches for â€œmass shootingâ€ usually dwarf searches for â€œgun controlâ€ in the aftermath of an incident, and both disappear soon after. After the Parkland shooting, though, interest in gun control significantly outpaced attention to the shooting itself.
Even now, specific gun reform proposals remain broadly popular.

In the most recent survey, conducted in mid-April, three-quarters of Americans favored strengthening background checks, while just 13 percent opposed the proposal. A 63 percent majority favored raising the age for gun purchases to 21, with only about one-quarter in opposition. And a 42 percent plurality of those polled said President Donald Trump was not doing enough to pass new gun laws, while about one-quarter said heâ€™s doing the right amount. Just 9 percent that heâ€™s doing too much. (At the end of February, 37 percent said Trump wasnâ€™t doing enough.)
Data from other pollsters, meanwhile, suggests that the national focus on guns is waning. But some find that the decline has stopped short of entirely erasing the changes post-Parkland.

Some of the most granular information comes from the progressive pollster Civiqs, which has been tracking data on gun control for several years. According to its data, votersâ€™ backing for such restrictions spiked from the low 50s prior to the Parkland shooting to a high of 60 percent â€• a bigger reaction than in the wake of mass shootings in Charleston, South Carolina; San Bernardino, California; Orlando, Florida; Las Vegas and Sutherland Springs. Some of that change wore off in the weeks after, stabilizing around the 55 percent mark.

Civiqsâ€™ data only goes back through 2015. But support for enacting new gun laws in April was higher than it was after the shooting at a Newtown, Connecticut, elementary school in 2012, according to a Washington Post/ABC News survey, thanks largely to a movement among Democratic-leaning groups. A 53 percent majority of Americans told pollsters they believed student activism on guns were part of a lasting movement, while 43 percent said the rallies were â€œmore of a one-time thing.â€

Another poll from Gallup found that the share of Americans mentioning guns or gun control as the nationâ€™s most important problem dropped from 13 percent in March to 6 percent in April â€• a downtick that nevertheless leaves it as one of the highest-ranked national issues. In a recent NPR/PBS NewsHour Marist poll, a slim 53 percent majority of Democratic voters said guns will be a major factor for them in November, down 21 points since February.

otherData.headline: 'Aggretsuko' Is A Workplace Comedy Where Rage Is Front And Center
otherData.short_description: Netflix's new animated series adds a heavy metal soundtrack to the injustices of office life.

articleContent: To be a cog in the corporate machine is to subject yourself to injustices large and small in the name of eking out a living: tiresome office politics, a jammed printer, a stolen lunch, or worse, sexual harassment. Just look at the seminal â€œ9 to 5,â€ â€œOffice Space,â€ â€œThe Officeâ€ and â€œCorporate,â€ all pop cultural depictions that draw on the inescapable ennui of zombielike number-crunchers and buttoned-up executive assistants who subsist on burnt coffee and keyboard cleaner, waiting for the day their crappy co-workers and abusive bosses get their due.

Netflix and Sanrioâ€™s new anime series â€œAggretsuko,â€ which debuted on the streaming service on Friday, takes the mundane workplace frustration many of us have come to know and cranks the dial to 11. The series follows Retsuko, an endearing red panda who wants nothing more than to get through her work days without incident. And when real life doesnâ€™t measure up to her hopes, she turns to the only thing that temporarily soothes her discontent: death metal.

Thereâ€™s a lot for Retsuko to get angry about. She works in accounting for some vague corporate entity, one of several lackeys made to tidy the desk of her rage-inducing boss, a literal chauvinist pig. She heads to the office in an overstuffed commuter train, only to have to face a rumor-spreading hippopotamus and a Komodo dragon who loves to dump extra work on her. She faces small, relatable dilemmas outside her job, too: feeling conflicted over how much to give for a wedding present, or simply wanting to shop without constant check-ins from a store clerk.

She gets by thanks to her work buddies â€” a chill fennec fox with unmatched social-media stalking skills and a hyena in slacks (who, based on Twitterâ€™s consensus, seems to be the most crush-worthy character). Sheâ€™s in awe of two more experienced colleagues, women who strut down the hallways with an air of #girlboss assuredness, but who actually share many of our titular heroâ€™s insecurities.

Retusko channels all of this insecurity and rage into a death-metal hobby that lets her express exactly how she feels. She tries to hide it first from her more intimidating female co-workers and then from a love interest, but realizes her truest self lies within these moments. Itâ€™s in these small vignettes where Retsuko is able to be fully unvarnished: â€œYouâ€™re a shitty boss!â€ she scream-sings during a work happy hour. â€œDeath metal is my soul!!!â€ she confesses in another episode.

The sharp contrast between Retsukoâ€™s adorable outward appearance and her unbridled rage-singing is played for laughs in each of the seriesâ€™ 10 episodes, yet doesnâ€™t become tiresome. Perhaps because itâ€™s rare to see a female character, animated or not, succumb fully to her anger, especially in a way thatâ€™s seen as a net positive. Retsukoâ€™s metal habit provides a private, nondestructive space to contend with the pitfalls of an early-career slog.
Requiring a standing appointment at a karaoke bar might be self-care taken to its most extreme, but Retsuko isnâ€™t a role model. Sheâ€™s just trying to make it through her 20s.

The lyrics of Retsukoâ€™s throat-murdering screams are the cherry atop her rage sundae, adapting to fit her crisis du jour. In one episode, she determines that all she needs is a wealthy partner to escape her current drudgery. Cue the metal guitars, and the passionate cry of future financial security: â€œMATRIMONIAL FREEDOM!â€ Itâ€™s good.

American audiences might not immediately associate the show with Sanrio, the Japanese company best known for Hello Kitty. Retsuko, along with Sanrioâ€™s listless egg character Gudetama, stand out from the companyâ€™s other happily uncomplicated creations by virtue of their issues. Even Retsukoâ€™s resting â€œcuteâ€ face lacks a smile.

The full-length series, inspired by shorts that aired on Japanâ€™s Tokyo Broadcasting System network, hits on an interesting spot. It feels intended for an audience older than do kid-adult crossovers like â€œAdventure Timeâ€ or â€œSteven Universe.â€ Yet its lightness â€” despite all its rage â€” doesnâ€™t feel quite in line with the darker adult-cartoon stalwart (and fellow Netflix original) â€œBoJack Horseman.â€ Still, itâ€™s pointed enough to feel true to life, even if heavy metal isnâ€™t your genre.

The series is generally self-aware, of the moment and endearingly weird: Retsukoâ€™s fennec fox friend, for example, details a pattern in their co-workerâ€™s Instagram feed, nailing down her routine of food, selfie and occasional â€œthigh shotâ€ pictures. But the office caricatures arenâ€™t always charitable. That same â€™gram-friendly co-worker, a starry-eyed doe who talks in a baby voice, also allows the gross boss to flirt with her to her benefit. Sheâ€™s clearly set up as a contrast to Retsuko and company â€” surely theyâ€™d never stoop so low â€” but her overly ditzy depiction feels a little one-note at first.

Each episode is a short 15 minutes, putting â€œAggretsukoâ€ in the ranks of Netflixâ€™s other feel-good original fare that requires minimal time commitment (looking at you, â€œNailed Itâ€). The effect of catching a handful in one sitting is like having read several culturally savvy comic strips: bright colors, enough for a laugh, but not a lot of narrative depth. Fortunately, â€œAggretsukoâ€ isnâ€™t trying for prestige television; it succeeds as a cathartic mirror to contemporary office life â€” and the activities that sustain us once weâ€™ve punched out.

articleContent: â€œDoesnâ€™t Look Like Anything To Leigh ... And Billâ€ is HuffPostâ€™s weekly recap in which we break down the craziest thing you might have missed on â€œWestworld.â€ This week: Season 2, Episode 2, â€œReunion.â€

If the connections between â€œWestworldâ€ and a certain, mysterious stock image have flown under your radar, we have some new information that might finally pique your interest.

Remember, back in Season 1 of the HBO series, when Doloresâ€™ (Evan Rachel Wood) father Peter Abernathy (Louis Herthum) short-circuited after discovering a picture of a woman posing in New York Cityâ€™s Times Square? In the showâ€™s fictional universe, the photo is a shot of Juliet, sister to parkgoer Logan (Ben Barnes) and the eventual wife of William (Jimmi Simpson and Ed Harris), aka the Man in Black. A mere glimpse of the real world beyond Peterâ€™s robotic realm seemingly caused him to malfunction.

Mr. Abernathyâ€™s frazzled moment was a pivotal â€œWestworldâ€ plot point, so of course the internet went nuts when fans realized the show had apparently used a Getty stock image of a random woman, rather than hire an actress to play the role of Juliet.
The photographer credited for the photo is Erik von Weber, a name that sounds curiously like Arnold Weber (Jeffrey Wright), one of the characters on the show who helped create Westworld.

Von Weberâ€™s stock images have been used by a variety of websites, including HuffPost, so his involvement in the show didnâ€™t immediately raise red flags. But when fans looked closer at von Weberâ€™s Getty photos, they noticed some other notable pictures: images of horses, cowboys and, most interestingly, samurai, which are all subjects that have a connection to Westworld.
Hmmm. Could von Weber have some secret ties to HBO?
Well, something fascinating just happened: In Season 2, Episode 2, titled â€œReunion,â€ the woman from the Times Square stock photo made an appearance on the show.

HuffPost reached out to the actress, Claire Unabia, to ask her about the experience of evolving from stock photo subject to â€œWestworldâ€ actress, and she revealed an interesting detail: According to Unabia, the picture she posed for wasnâ€™t originally meant to be a stock photo.

â€œIâ€™ll be honest with you, I donâ€™t know if they got that photo that way, because that picture, as far as I know, wasnâ€™t for a stock photo,â€ she said. â€œI donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s actually the way that they got it. Iâ€™m not sure. Iâ€™ll just put it out there that maybe it wasnâ€™t actually a stock photo.â€
Though she doesnâ€™t remember all the specifics of the shoot in question, Unabia recalled it was for a job involving some sort of â€œtechnology company.â€
â€œIt was for a particular job. What I recall was for technology, [an] internal technology picture, so thatâ€™s what I recall taking it for.â€
Uh, â€œtechnologyâ€? Claire, are you talking about Delos, the company running Westworld?

The actress didnâ€™t think the shoot, which she previously told HuffPost happened about four years before Season 1, was some big HBO conspiracy to take photos of potential â€œWestworldâ€ stars, but she believes the showrunners â€œmight have had other reasons when they chose the picture.â€
She is also suspicious about â€œErik von Weber.â€
â€œI donâ€™t recall that name at all,â€ said Unabia, adding, â€œMaybe the name is not the actual name.â€

When reached for comment on von Weberâ€™s possible connection to the show, HBO reps said they didnâ€™t know if there was any information to share on the topic. We also contacted representatives at Getty Images, who said von Weber has refused all media requests.

But if there is a connection between the photographer and the show, this opens up a wormhole of possibilities. Are the samurai photos on his account associated with the Delos park Shogun World? Do some of von Weberâ€™s other photos hint at future show reveals, too?

Most notably, von Weberâ€™s photos include images of knights and people dressed up like barbarians. Maybe these are peeks into a medieval park world, which was in the original 1973 movie and is rumored to be appearing on the show.
In addition to the conspiracy theory, Unabia talked to us about what it was like when HBO tracked her down and put her in the episode.
So when did you really find out your picture was in the show?
It was when [HuffPostâ€™s Carly Ledbetter] reached out asking to talk to me about that and confirm it was me in the picture, and thatâ€™s when I found out.
What was your reaction?

I was very surprised. But itâ€™s a kind of a thing where you feel like when youâ€™re putting yourself out there in a way that somehow it will get picked up by the world, so in some way I wasnâ€™t surprised.
When did HBO contact you?

It was after Season 1 finished.

They had actually a slightly hard time getting in touch with me as well, and then it was a bit of back and forth with them. They asked me to do a scene and send it to them, and I didnâ€™t hear anything for a while. Then they had some troubles with their shooting and script. They went through a lot of things, so their timeline was put off from what they thought it wouldâ€™ve been previously. Then, they finally called me in to shoot as if I had known I was coming the whole time. Like, â€œOK, can you come two days from now or tomorrow?â€
What? So were you able to change your schedule?
I did. I was working on some other job, but it was just going to be the last two days of it or something, so I just canceled the last two days and went out.
Whatâ€™s it like arriving in â€œWestworldâ€?

It was a bit magical. You definitely feel like youâ€™re stepping into another world when you arrive at the ranch. It looks a bit just like how it looks on the show, so you feel like youâ€™ve stepped into that world, and I saw some of the set design. Itâ€™s crazy how some of it doesnâ€™t feel like these psychotic crazy scary places, but then when I realize what it was, then I had that feeling like, â€œOh my gosh. This is that place, and it looks like that place, and it looks like nothing right now, but itâ€™s very scary.â€
Was anybody like, â€œOh, youâ€™re the person from the photoâ€?

Yeah, somebody â€” another director â€” he came up to me, and he thought he knew me and was talking to me. â€œOh, how are you?â€ and everything. And then it was minutes later that he said, â€œOh, my gosh! Youâ€™re from the picture!â€ And he just realized it.
So what was your character, Juliet, thinking when she saw Dolores?
Oh, a world of terrible and suspicious things.
[Laugh] Thatâ€™s what it looked like.

As a married person, you know, itâ€™s when you have that look and understanding and kind of seeing your whole marriage or life in a way on the edge. Itâ€™s very upsetting. Especially in my house? This woman. She comes into my house?
So do you have any theories about the show?

My husband has a theory that Iâ€™m going to come back as a robot and kill the Dolores character and have a face off with her. But no, I donâ€™t know anything. Iâ€™m not holding fast to any one theory or idea.
So is it weird that Logan is carrying around a picture of his sister in the park?

Yes, I do try to find reasons for that myself. I donâ€™t know. Maybe because there was such excellent history with him and her and the park and his friend that itâ€™s about something more than carrying a picture of your sister.
Whatâ€™s it like going from a photo to being on the show?

Thatâ€™s honestly the way that my life always is. Every year itâ€™s some other new, crazy adventure, and I have no plans for it, and things just happened. One year Iâ€™m producing a show for a Fringe Festival in Scotland, and then the next year Iâ€™m doing something completely different, some acting thing, having kids. otherData.headline: Some Democrats Want Hillary Clinton To Return The DNC's Money
otherData.short_description: The national party agreed to pay $1.65 million for her campaign email list and other resources.

articleContent: Several Democratic officials are asking Hillary Clinton to return the money that the Democratic National Committee paid her political group for her campaign email list and other resources.

In February 2017, the DNC agreed to pay Clintonâ€™s group Onward Together $1.65 million for her campaign email list, analytics, donor data and related items, The Intercept reported on Wednesday. The cache of material was worth more than $5 million; Clintonâ€™s campaign made an in-kind donation of resources worth $3.5 million, and the DNC paid for the rest.

Now a number of Democratic Party officials, including some state party chairs and DNC members, want Clinton to retroactively donate the campaign materials to the DNC and return the money that the party organ gave Onward Together.

â€œShe should return the money for the â€˜love of the Democratic Partyâ€™ to the DNC for its use,â€ said Alabama Democratic Party chairwoman Nancy Worley, who supported Clinton during the 2016 primary.
Wisconsin Democratic Party chairwoman Martha Laning and Missouri Democratic National Committeeman Curtis Wylde likewise called on her to retroactively donate it and return the payment.

And Nebraska Democratic Party chairwoman Jane Kleeb, who supported Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) in the 2016 primary, argued that Clinton could also contribute the equivalent money to state Democratic parties.
Other DNC officials, including at-large member Brian Wahby and Kansas Democratic National Committeeman Chris Reeves, welcomed an in-kind donation but stopped short of asking for it.
â€œIt would be a Christian thing to do,â€ Wahby said.
Sandersâ€™ office did not return a request for comment on whether the senator agrees.
Nick Merrill, a Clinton spokesman, defended the price tag on Thursday on the grounds that the DNC has already reaped far more than it paid for the email list in fundraising so far.

â€œPaying a rental fee for use of an email list is common practice, and in this case the DNC has raised over $30 million with it, an 1,800 [percent] return on their investment,â€ Merrill wrote in an email to Fox News. (The DNC purchased the email list to own, rather than renting its information.)
Merrill did not respond to a HuffPost request for comment on calls to retroactively make the resources an in-kind contribution and return the money already received.
Xochitl Hinojosa, a DNC spokeswoman, agreed that the DNC had gotten â€œa return on our investment and more since obtaining all of the lists and data.â€

Donna Brazile forged the agreement between the Clinton campaign and the DNC in February 2017, while she was serving as interim DNC chairwoman. Brazile, who has been critical of how the Clinton campaign treated the DNC, said she believed the deal would help her successor as DNC chair â€œinherit a party in good shape.â€
â€œI felt that it was a fair bargain at the time,â€ she said.

The current DNC chairman, Tom Perez, has amended the payment schedule, but the core of the accord â€• how much the DNC would pay and what it would get in return â€• remains in place, according to Hinojosa.

The DNC paid Onward Together $300,000 in January and $135,000 in every subsequent month, according to Federal Election Commission filings and information provided by the DNC. Thus far, it has transferred $705,000 to Clintonâ€™s group; as of the end of this month, that sum will have increased to $840,000.
The revelation of the sale of Clinton campaign resources to the DNC has struck a nerve with some Democratic officials because it exemplifies practices that they have criticized for years.

These Democrats lament the transactional relationship of Democratic standard-bearers with the DNC and state parties, which often have a harder time fundraising. Former President Barack Obama withheld his campaign email list entirely from the DNC during his first term, using it instead to build his political group, Organizing for America (later renamed Organizing for Action). After Obamaâ€™s re-election in 2012, he initially allowed the DNC to use the list free of charge before formally donating it to the party body in 2015.

Officials from state parties who joined the Clinton campaignâ€™s joint fundraising agreement during the 2016 election also complained that the campaign left state parties little funding to maintain their operations.

Onward Together, which as a 501(c)(4) political nonprofit is not required to disclose its financial data, says it has distributed grants to 11 progressive groups, including Indivisible, Swing Left, Run for Something and Color of Change.

However, there are many forms of political organizing that state parties, unlike those groups, are uniquely equipped to do. For example, state parties have historically played important roles in recruiting candidates for state and local office; advising and funding those candidates; and registering and turning out voters in down-ballot races.

Another source of tension is what Sanders allies see as a double standard being applied to the Vermont senatorâ€™s famously successful campaign email list. Although Sanders was not the Democratic presidential nominee, after the campaign, many Democrats called on Sanders to turn over his list to the DNC. (Sanders has declined to do so.)

â€œThey werenâ€™t saying Bernie, â€˜Rent your list.â€™ They wanted the list,â€ said Jim Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute and a Sanders appointee to the DNCâ€™s Unity and Reform Commission. â€œThey said, â€˜All candidates do this â€• they turn it over to the party.â€™ Well, now I find out that they donâ€™t.â€

Zogby, who refused to comment on the conduct of the Clinton campaign, was one of several reformers who pressed the Unity Commission to recommend the creation of a financial oversight committee at the DNC with full access to the partyâ€™s budget data.

He hopes that the latest revelation will increase support among the DNCâ€™s membership to approve the oversight committee and other financial transparency measures. The entire DNC membership is due to vote on the proposals in August.

otherData.headline: An Oral History Of *NSYNC's Breakup, According To Bandmates Not Named Justin Timberlake

articleContent: In 2002, *NSYNC, the boy band of our collective pre-teen dreams, decided to go on hiatus at the height of their career. Lance Bass, JC Chasez, Joey Fatone, Chris Kirkpatrick and Justin Timberlake were stretched a little too thin and in need of some R&R, fans were led to believe.
But as the months rolled on and Timberlake released his first solo album, â€œJustified,â€ the situation proved to be a little more murky.

â€œThereâ€™s no reason my solo career and *NSYNC canâ€™t coexist in the same universe. *NSYNC is in no danger. The break weâ€™re on was a conscious move. We all wanted to do it, and we were ready to do it. Performing at stadiums every night for 50,000 fans takes a little out of you ... The time was right; we were all in the same zone,â€ Timberlake told The New York Post in November 2002, before cryptically adding of his new record â€œJustifiedâ€: â€œThis album is what I wanted to do.â€
What Timberlake wanted to do, yes, and perhaps Chasez, who also headed into the studio to work on a solo project.

â€œFor us, it happened organically,â€ Chasez told me over the phone last month, a few weeks before he was set to reunite with his former bandmates for a Hollywood Walk of Fame ceremony in Los Angeles. â€œAfter you do something for a certain amount of time, you get into a rhythm of it and then new things spark your curiosity; you need new brain food. At that time, we just felt like we had exhausted every kind of idea for what we were doing and we just felt like â€˜OK, letâ€™s do something different.â€™ So, thatâ€™s what we did.â€
All these â€œweâ€™sâ€ suggest that the break was a unanimous decision, a Kumbaya conclusion that served to benefit everyone. And maybe it was. But an actual breakup? Not so much.

â€œWe thought we were getting back together,â€ Fatone told me. â€œIt was, â€™OK, after [Justin] does his thing, blah, blah, blah, weâ€™ll get back together and move forward and do what we got to do. And then it was like, nope. The record company wanted to push Justin, I guess, is what it was. He got bigger and bigger, which is honestly great for him and Iâ€™m totally happy for him in that sense, but it was more or less weird that there wasnâ€™t an explanation to say weâ€™re not going to do it, period. I was a little bit on hold for a moment and it was like, â€˜OK, we got to shit or get off the pot.â€™â€

In fact, the band never officially announced the end of *NSYNC. Yet, in his 2007 book Out of Sync â€• released five years after their initial rest period â€• Bass wrote, â€œWeâ€™re definitely broken up. Itâ€™s not a hiatus. Justin made it clear that he wouldnâ€™t be interested in discussing another album any time soon.â€

When I asked Bass about the hiatus-turned-breakup, he said he always saw *NSYNC â€œevolving and maturing,â€ despite its origins as a boy band. â€œWe all decided, â€˜OK, six months. We need it. We need the vacation time, we need the downtime,â€™â€ he said. â€œBut when we came back, it just â€¦ everything changed.â€

â€œIt took us a while to naturally say, â€˜You know what? I think ... we might be done,â€™â€ Bass recalled, laughing. â€œAnd thatâ€™s how it was. It wasnâ€™t anything crazy â€“ no big, crazy fight to break us up. Weâ€™re all still close and we talk daily, but I guess it just had run its time, which was sad because I was really excited for the next album.â€
Fatone and Kirkpatrick felt the same way.
â€œI was upset at first about the â€˜why.â€™ Then you understand the logistics of everything,â€ Fatone said.

â€œI donâ€™t know if I was ready for it to end,â€ Kirkpatrick added. â€œIn my 20s and into my early 30s, I was in a band touring the world every day. You wake up and thereâ€™s a schedule on your floor saying you have a photo shoot this time, a meet-and-greet this time, a radio interview this time, a TV appearance this time and a show this time. Then, suddenly, you wake up and thereâ€™s nothing. Youâ€™re like, â€˜Oh man, where do I go now?â€™â€

To fans and music critics alike, it was a strange choice for *NSYNC to throw in the towel after only a few very successful years and three chart-topping albums. In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter last year, Timberlake further explained his leaving. â€œIt started as a fun snowball fight that was becoming an avalanche,â€ he said. â€œAnd, also, I was growing out of it. I felt like I cared more about the music than some of the other people in the group.â€

Whether he did or didnâ€™t is up for debate. Chasez produced and wrote multiple *NSYNC songs, and admitted the studio is still his safe haven. And Bass said he spent a good portion of his time off in Nashville writing lyrics for what he thought would be the bandâ€™s next album.

â€œI had several songs that I wrote that I was going to present, so that was definitely sad that I didnâ€™t get to experience that part of making the next album,â€ Bass said. â€œI thought our sound just kept evolving â€• from â€˜*NSYNCâ€™ to â€˜No Strings Attachedâ€™ to â€˜Celebrity,â€™ you could see the growth there. It wouldâ€™ve been very interesting to see what our sound would be like today.â€

After years apart, the five members of *NSYNC will be back together on Hollywood Boulevard to receive a star on the Walk of Fame. They wonâ€™t be performing, though. Instead, the group will be joined by family members and former collaborators, including speakers Ellen DeGeneres and Carson Daly, recruited to commemorate their legacy in the presence of the Chamber of Commerce and fans. Thereâ€™s even an â€œimmersive experienceâ€ (read: a memorabilia mecca) for former followers called The Dirty Pop-Up. Itâ€™s a nostalgic affair, laced with an air of anticlimax: *NSYNC is reuniting without really reuniting.

Ahead of the ceremony, I reached out to the former members to see if I could compile an investigation of *NSYNCâ€™s demise. Bass, Chasez, Fatone and Kirkpatrick obliged, mostly eager to reminisce about the good ole days of wide-legged cargo pants, frosted-tip hair and smooth a cappella. But Timberlake, whoâ€™s already had a few shots at explaining his side of the story, was too busy to hop on the phone. (Heâ€™s currently on the U.S. leg of his Man of the Woods tour.) Perhaps it was for the best, because the other guys got trÃ¨s deep about the beginnings of the group, fame in the early aughts, their unfortunate dissolution and their unlikely-but-high hopes for a legitimate reunion.
Behold: A history of *NSYNCâ€™s breakup (and everything that led to it), according to bandmates not named Justin Timberlake.
Itâ€™s Gonna Be Me: The Rise Of Chris Kirkpatrickâ€™s Boy Band

As most histories will tell you, *NSYNC was formed by the now-late and disgraced record producer Lou Pearlman in Orlando, Florida, in the mid-1990s, after he found huge success with their future rivals, The Backstreet Boys. Chris Kirkpatrick was the one who met with Pearlman to discuss starting another boy band, thanks to a connection to Backstreet Boy Howie Dorough.

â€œI went to school [Valencia College in Orlando] with Howie â€• we had chorus together,â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œAnd there was another kid, Charlie Edwards, who went and became a Backstreet Boy, and I guess he had a falling out with a producer and quit. Heâ€™s the one who came to me saying that this guy Lou Pearlman was looking for another band.â€

After Pearlman and Kirkpatrick met, Kirkpatrick began helping him audition potential band members, bringing â€œquartets I was in from school.â€ They landed on a few potential singers who eventually dropped out before Mickey Mouse Club alum and Tennessean Justin Timberlake walked into the picture, bringing along fellow Mouseketeer and Maryland native JC Chasez. During a bonding night out at Disney Worldâ€™s Pleasure Island, the newly formed trio happened to run into a mutual friend who seemed like a natural addition: Brooklyn-born Orlando transplant Joey Fatone. And just like that, there were four.

â€œI was like, â€˜Hey, this is my buddy Joey! We both worked at Universal!â€™ And JC was like, â€˜Yeah, we know him. He used to come to the Mickey Mouse Club,â€™â€ Kirkpatrick explained. â€œSo we all knew each other and we were like, â€˜Hey man, weâ€™re putting together a group!â€™â€

At the time, Fatone was in another group, Big Guys, with Luis Fonsi, but he left to join Kirkpatrickâ€™s budding ensemble, deciding his then-bandmate Jason Galasso would round out the quintet. Thatâ€™s when the concept for the name â€œIn Sync,â€ aka *NSYNC, was formed, using the last letters of the guysâ€™ first names: JustiN, ChriS, JoeY, JasoN, and JC. Of course, Galasso didnâ€™t last long. He was soon replaced by Mississippi teen Lance Bass, who allegedly earned the nickname Lansten so the remaining â€œNâ€ in the groupâ€™s name would still make sense.

â€œBob Westbrook was Justinâ€™s and my vocal coach, so when they got the group together, Justin called him to see if he knew of any bass singers that would work and he immediately thought of me,â€ Bass said. â€œI didnâ€™t think my mom would ever let me do it!â€

At 14, Timberlake was the youngest member of the group, followed by Bass, 16; Fatone, 18; Chasez, 19; and Kirkpatrick, 23. Timberlakeâ€™s and Bassâ€™ moms stayed with the band as they traveled and rehearsed, since the pair was too young to go without chaperones.

â€œWeâ€™d have my mom and Justinâ€™s mom washing the clothes in hotel sinks every night because weâ€™d wear the same outfit for like six months,â€ Bass said with a laugh. â€œWe didnâ€™t really have a choice of what we wore at the beginning because it was just whatever we could afford.â€

By 1996, *NSYNC signed with BMG Ariola Munich and were carted off to Europe to work with Swedish music producer and songwriter Denniz PoP and producer Max Martin in PoPâ€™s Cheiron Studios. There, they perfected their â€œboy-bandâ€ image â€• an image they werenâ€™t quite sure would work with their musical background.

â€œThe only time that we felt like we were kind of pushed with new stuff and new styles was when we were in Europe, because everything was so new to us. We thought we were kind of getting cultured,â€ Chasez laughed. â€œWe were experimenting and trying to be as excited and open as possible.â€

â€œWe basically had label and management people looking down on us saying, â€˜Hey, now you have to do this,â€™ especially the late Lou Pearlman. He was always like [imitating his husky voice], â€˜Now I want to see you guys like this,â€™â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œI think we couldâ€™ve been a lot better right out of the gate if he wasnâ€™t there trying to push us into this mold. The word boy band wasnâ€™t even out then, and it was almost like Lou knew what that was.â€

In the beginning, a cappella music was *NSYNCâ€™s passion. Kirkpatrick recalled how, during those days abroad, the guys would find a hallway with great acoustics and harmonize â€• conjuring an image we always hoped existed, of five beatific friends who just canâ€™t stop singing.

â€œSo to be in this band where it was like, â€˜OK, we want you to dress as clowns. OK, now we want you to be in the swimming pool with your shirts off.â€™ There were so many times where we thought why are we doing this? This is stupid,â€ Kirkpatrick said.

Although each bandmate emphasized that they werenâ€™t aggressively slotted into personas, they did tick a certain box, respectively, when it came to fitting the five-person boy band mold Pearlman originally envisioned. The boxes werenâ€™t as â€œcut and dry as the Spice Girls,â€ Kirkpatrick noted, but they contained certain fan niches.

â€œWe were never like, â€˜You have to be the funny one, you have to be the cool one, you got to be the sexy one,â€™â€ Fatone said. â€œLike Chris is always the prankster and the jokester. Justin has a great voice and everyone wants to marry him. And the moms wanted to take me home and cook me dinner. Thatâ€™s the one I always got.â€
â€œWe always thought that the most important thing was to be good at what we were doing, and then the rest weâ€™d let the chips fall where they may,â€ Chasez said.

That was the mantra when determining who would get the lead solos, too. Kirkpatrick explained that, in the beginning, the guys would take turns singing verses when practicing a cappella, and when it came time to record in studio, it was clear two voices stood out.

â€œJustin and JC had already been doing this, they were professionals, they knew what they were doing. But they also proved themselves to be the best lead vocals for the songs. After exploding in Germany with their hit â€œI Want You Back,â€ they released their self-titled album under BMG, Ariola Records and Trans Continental in May 1997. It peaked at No. 1 in its second week on the charts. *NSYNC became an overnight success abroad, touring across Europe and garnering the attention of RCA Records, which signed them to an American deal. But American audiences didnâ€™t automatically swarm. â€œI Want You Backâ€ wasnâ€™t receiving the attention it had garnered overseas, and the album debuted at only No. 82 on the Billboard 200. So Disney, a bastion of media aimed at tweens and beyond, swooped in and saved the day by offering the band a chance to headline a special, â€œ*NSYNC: In Concert,â€ which first aired in July 1998.

â€œWe were a little discouraged, thinking, â€˜Well, I guess weâ€™ll never be able to create that craziness we had in Europe. Weâ€™ll just have a normal career here.â€™ But that Disney special started to air five times a day for months and we went from zero to 100 overnight,â€ Bass said.

The â€˜No Stringsâ€™ Years: How â€˜Clockwork Orangeâ€™ Inspired *NSYNC

Justin, JC, Joey, Chris and Lance quickly became household names, their faces peering down from posters in teenage bedrooms. â€œTearinâ€™ Up My Heartâ€ â€• or their equally successful holiday album â€œHome For Christmasâ€ â€• rang through adolescent boom boxes everywhere. They toured the U.S., appeared on â€œTotal Request Live,â€ and showed up at events alongside the reigning princess of pop, Britney Spears, Timberlakeâ€™s longtime girlfriend. (Thatâ€™s a whole other story.)

â€œIt was almost like going to college in a way, growing up with these different artists who were pretty much the same age and all starting at the same time: Destinyâ€™s Child, Mandy Moore, Britney, Christina [Aguilera], Backstreet â€“ it was like a pop college,â€ Bass said. â€œWe all worked together, toured together and became kind of family.â€

Friends, perhaps, but foes nonetheless. Anyone who consumed entertainment news 20 years ago knows of the relentless fan rivalry between *NSYNC and The Backstreet Boys, which the bandmates claim was entirely perpetuated by the press.

â€œEverybody, mostly the fans, were trying to pit us against each other, but for a while there we had the same management. So everywhere we turned it was like we were doing our thing, they were doing their thing, but it was always â€˜Backstreet, Backstreet, Backstreetâ€™ to us and â€˜*NSYNC, *NSYNC, *NSYNCâ€™ to them,â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œAfter a while, that kind of rubs off on you and you feed into it a little bit. I think people just wanted to pick something up and know thereâ€™s some kind of huge animosity between us. All the gossip.â€

Actually, *NSYNC was focused less on the BSB drama and more on a legal battle with Pearlman, Trans Continental and BMG Entertainment over business practices. A few months after Pearlman and BMG filed a $150 million lawsuit against the band for prematurely breaking a contract, both parties settled out of court. *NSYNC eventually released their third album, â€œNo Strings Attached,â€ under Jive in the spring of 2000. The concept for the album, which dominated the Billboard 200 for eight consecutive weeks, was slightly inspired by the management snafu.
We thought â€œnobody is controlling us anymore. This is us, this is who we are, weâ€™re not going to just appease the management and label,â€ Kirkpatrick said.

That album gave fans earworms like â€œBye, Bye, Bye,â€ â€œItâ€™s Gonna Be Meâ€ and â€œThis I Promise You.â€ It also provided some of the most iconic *NSYNC fashion moments: acid-washed denim jackets, leather cargo pants, spiky colored hair.

â€³â€˜No Strings Attachedâ€™ was like the Pinocchio â€˜I Got No Stringsâ€™ song. We came up with this whole weird idea of patchwork orange â€• a â€˜Clockwork Orangeâ€™-ish sense,â€ Fatone said. â€œThis guy Steven, who was on our wardrobe team, came to us with these drawings and we loved them. Thatâ€™s was how the style of it went down.â€

For the â€œItâ€™s Gonna Be Meâ€ video, the group â€• as they did with â€œBye, Bye, Byeâ€ â€• gravitated toward an on-the-nose marionette concept, portraying themselves as dolls at a toy store. Fatone said itâ€™s one of his favorite *NSYNC music videos.
â€œItâ€™s a staple, you know? Like â€˜Bye, Bye, Bye.â€™ All our videos kind of stick out because theyâ€™re all moments in time.â€

The fandom was intense in the â€œNo Stringsâ€ era. Young followers werenâ€™t hiding behind iPhone screens or computers tweeting about why *NSYNC was the greatest boy band of all time. They were physically present at meet-and-greets, red carpet events and concert dates.

â€œYouâ€™re like, â€˜What the hell is going on?â€™ Some were die-hard fans and know my birthday or ask about my brother. They talked to you like they actually knew you, even though youâ€™ve never met these people before in your life,â€ Fatone said. â€œTheyâ€™ve followed everything youâ€™ve done and love everything you do and everything about you. Itâ€™s a weird, surreal feeling. Even to this day, Iâ€™ve never gotten used to it.â€
But the chaos was different than what the likes of Justin Bieber face today â€• constant praise and scrutiny in public and on the web from admirers and critics alike.

â€œWe were so lucky that we got to have a way more innocent time in this industry than a lot of people do today. We could be stupid teenagers, we could be seen with a beer in our hand at a club and not think someone was going to take a picture of that and send it to someone,â€ Bass said.

Bass, perhaps, had the toughest task in terms of dealing with wild female fans. During the days of *NSYNC, he had not yet come out as gay, and was facing the â€œtortureâ€ of hiding his identity behind a diluted pop culture persona.

â€œBeing onstage and singing those songs that you donâ€™t really relate to since youâ€™re talking about girls, it all, to me, wasnâ€™t real,â€ Bass recalled. â€œOnstage, I just felt like I was playing a character the whole time, but offstage, unfortunately, I didnâ€™t get to have my real life, because I felt like I just had to hide this secret.â€

After enduring what heâ€™s described as excruciating guilt during his formative years, the singer came out in a People magazine story in 2006, shocking friends and fans. He said he kept his sexuality under wraps as not to diminish the success of his bandmates.

â€œThe â€™90s were a different time,â€ he said. â€œIf you came out, if anyone knew you were gay, it was a disaster and people really flipped out. I felt like if anyone found out that I was gay, the record label would immediately drop us and the fans would hate us â€• these were all the crazy things that went through my head as a teenager. So, I just trained myself into being a certain person and became that person.â€
Bass said â€œit wouldâ€™ve changed everythingâ€ if he had been open about his sexuality during his days with *NSYNC, knowing his bandmates wouldâ€™ve been completely supportive.

â€œAs long as Iâ€™ve known the guys, Iâ€™ve known that thereâ€™s not one bigoted bone in their bodies, so I knew they would be fine with it, but I also knew that they wouldnâ€™t be able to keep their mouths shut,â€ he said, laughing. â€œThatâ€™s why I just told no one. I just thought if I even told just one single person it would get out, which it would have. So that secret stayed with me and me only.â€
They Were On A Break: The Rise Of Justin And The Fall Of Everyone Else

A few months after the release of their fourth album â€œCelebrity,â€ which featured the catchy, Grammy-nominated songs â€œGoneâ€ and â€œGirlfriend,â€ things started to take a turn for *NSYNC. The album sold nearly 1.9 million copies in its first week, but after touring stadiums for months on end, first with the PopOdyssey Tour in 2001 and then the Celebrity Tour in 2002, the boy band was out of fresh ideas. They decided to announce their hiatus.

â€œYouâ€™re thinking, â€˜OK, weâ€™ve done this, weâ€™ve done this, weâ€™ve done this. I donâ€™t know what else we can do. I think I have an idea, but itâ€™s not for this, so Iâ€™m going to change gears,â€™â€ Chasez said. â€œAt that point, everybody had been messing with different things. Chris was messing with clothing line ideas, Lance was working on being an astronaut,â€ he laughed. â€œJoey was interested in making movies, Justin was interested in having a solo career, and I was interested in being in the studio. All of us were more interested in what was on our minds.â€

In the interim, Timberlake went solo with â€œJustifiedâ€ in November 2002, as did Chasez with his single â€œBlowinâ€™ Me Up (With Her Love)â€ the next month and his album â€œSchizophrenicâ€ in 2004. Bass set a goal of going to space (yes, really). Fatone dabbled in acting with â€œMy Big Fat Greek Wedding,â€ and Kirkpatrick launched his own clothing line, FuMan Skeeto (the clothes were as bad as the name). But, again, despite personal ventures, most of the members assumed that the break wasnâ€™t permanent â€• that they would reunite, record another album and tour anew.
That never happened.

The slide out of celebrity was difficult for some. â€œI made the mistake of being too complacent and realizing that, man, I got this celebrity-ism and all these things going for me, so Iâ€™m going to spend the next few years of my life just partying my ass off,â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œI was young enough where I thought that was the right thing to do. And looking back, I had so many opportunities and there was so much I could have done.â€

Kirkpatrick, Bass and Fatone said they didnâ€™t feel pressure to launch their own solo careers, but they were frustrated to see Chasez, whose debut didnâ€™t perform anywhere near Timberlakeâ€™s effort, flounder.

â€œNo matter what happened with Justin, he was going to end up being Justin anyway, whether or not he started in *NSYNC. But it surprises me that JC isnâ€™t just as big, because JC is as talented,â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œTheyâ€™re both through that Mickey Mouse Club upbringing with Christina and Britney and all them, and they got their chops all together and theyâ€™re amazing talents. I really wish JC was out there doing a little more. He still has so much to offer.â€

Even Timberlake praised Chasez, telling MTV in 2006, â€In my opinion, he had the best voice out of all of us. Out of all the boy bands, call â€™em what you will, he was the one that could out-sing all of us.â€

â€œItâ€™s flattering coming from someone such as Justin, such a great musician himself. Heâ€™s one of my favorite artists,â€ Chasez said when I reminded him of the compliment. â€œThe feeling is mutual. I think heâ€™s done some of the coolest stuff thatâ€™s come out in the last 20 years. At the same time, itâ€™s like, well, yeah, of course your friends are going to say nice things!â€

Overall, the four members of *NSYNC who arenâ€™t Justin Timberlake had nothing but nice things to say about him, calling him their super-talented â€œlittle brother.â€ Their admiration could ring as surprising, considering the ultimate cause of the split and the conceivably unfair toll his decision took on their individual trajectories in the industry. But now, as grown men, they seem to understand he had to be selfish to become the global superstar he is today.

â€œI say the name Justin Timberlake and itâ€™s almost like saying the name Madonna â€• a name where everybodyâ€™s like, â€˜Yeah, of course,â€™â€ Kirkpatrick said. â€œIâ€™m sitting there at the Super Bowl watching him do the halftime show like, â€˜Man, this is a big deal.â€™ Heâ€™s really done amazing, and Iâ€™m not a jealous person, so itâ€™s awesome to watch because I feel like thatâ€™s part of me out there.â€
Speaking of the Super Bowl, how did the guys feel about being left off Timberlakeâ€™s lineup?

â€œEverybody wanted it, everybody was waiting for it, but itâ€™s his show and his thing, so whatever he wants to do,â€ Fatone said. â€œThe guy was doing his job. You do you. If youâ€™re in a position, go for it! People ask if Iâ€™m upset and Iâ€™m like, â€˜Nah, I canâ€™t be. No way.â€™â€
â€œWe already did the MTV VMAs, so what are we going to do â€• the same thing again?â€ Chasez insisted, with Kirkpatrick adding, â€œEvery showâ€™s different, every circumstance is different.â€
I Want You Back: â€˜If The Stars Align, Then We Get Back Togetherâ€™
When it comes to *NSYNC, reunion is still the word.

Although the guys regularly keep up with each other over group text â€• â€œSometimes Iâ€™ll be drunk and be like, â€˜Oh my god, I love you guys, youâ€™re so great. Merry Chrismas,â€™â€ Fatone said â€• they are one of the only boy bands who have not yet reunited for a tour or new album. Their only joint performance since â€œthe breakâ€ was that MTV Video Music Awards bit for Timberlakeâ€™s Vanguard award in 2013. Now, the guys will all be together at the Walk of Fame ceremony on Monday. (Yes, Justin, too.)

â€œItâ€™s a chance for us, even though weâ€™re not singing or dancing, to still look at it as a bit of a performance, because whenever weâ€™re together in public, people seem to want to comment on it, so it will be fun,â€ Chasez said, with Fatone adding, â€œYou always wish you had something like that or some sort of legacy.
