otherData.headline: Marvel Lied To Us About 'Avengers: Infinity War'
otherData.short_description: The "Infinity War" creators promised a "final chapter" and "permanent" deaths. That's not what happened.

articleContent: Warning! If you do not want to know who dies in â€œAvengers: Infinity War,â€ do not keep reading. You have been warned.
What. Just. Happened?

For fans of the Marvel universe, death has never really meant death. Weâ€™ve seen Loki â€œdieâ€ and come back plenty of times. Bucky Barnes and Nick Fury have been assumed dead at various points, only to spring back into existence in the Marvel Cinematic Universe as well.
But this time, it was supposed to be different.

Leading up to the release of â€œAvengers: Infinity War,â€ the directors of the film spoke about the movie as a â€œfinal chapter.â€ Marvel boss Kevin Feige talked about the deaths in the movie being â€œrealâ€ this time. In an interview on April 22, one day before the premiere, I asked writers Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely to define what death means in their recent project.

â€œDeath is death,â€ McFeely said. â€œI mean, weâ€™re sensitive to that, and certainly the Marvel universe played with taking characters away and then giving them back to you in some other form. If we say goodbye to some characters, we will say it permanently.â€

He continued: â€œThe idea is that this movieâ€™s going to be different and has a potential to be really good is because the stakes are real and choices are real and we know that weâ€™ve cried wolf a little bit on that, so I suppose some audience members might look at that skeptically, but trust us.â€
Did you get all that? â€œPermanent,â€ he said. â€œTrust us,â€ he said.

So I audibly gasped in the theater when certain characters bit the dust. Loki in the filmâ€™s first minutes. (Are you kidding me?) Gamora just halfway through the movie. (Holy what?) That is, until the very end, when Spider-Man, most of the Guardians of the Galaxy and Black Panther â€• yes, even Tâ€™Challa â€• crumbled to ash at the snap of Thanosâ€™ fingers, thus rendering everything Marvel said to be pretty much baloney.
As my colleague Matt Jacobs pointed out, these characters are coming back.

New movies are already in the works for â€œSpider-Man,â€ â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ and â€œBlack Panther.â€ Is the third â€œGuardiansâ€ going to be about Rocket living life as a raccoon on Earth? Is â€œSpider-Man 2â€³ going to just focus on Ned putting that Lego Death Star he broke back together?

It all sounds riveting, but I doubt it. These characters will be resurrected one way or another. The creators played up their deaths, insinuating that they would mean something when they, well, wonâ€™t. Or canâ€™t. The newly deceased are contractually obligated to come back.
I reached out to a rep for Markus and McFeely to clarify their previous quote, but didnâ€™t hear back as of Monday afternoon.
I could see the studio putting out a press release explaining the sequels have been put on hold ... or something. But itâ€™s not going to change anything.
â€œInfinity Warâ€ was billed as the movie that the previous 18 MCU entires had been building toward. On that count it did not disappoint, but letâ€™s face it: Marvel lied to us.

Maybe we shouldâ€™ve seen this coming. After all, the â€œInfinity Gauntletâ€ comic, upon which the movie is largely based, is about Thanos killing a bunch of people before the characters eventually just ... reverse everything. But with all the talk of â€œpermanent deathâ€ and â€œreal stakes,â€ it was easy to get caught up in the potential tragedy.

Now weâ€™re left wondering: Were the writers truthful about anything in the run-up to the premiere? Well, maybe. Even before I knew the outcome of â€œInfinity War,â€ I asked them, â€œWherever Captain America ends up, what was the reasoning for it?â€
Markus told me it was a matter of â€œfulfilling the destinyâ€ of that Brooklyn kid we met back in the 1940s.

â€œI mean, just continuing to put that guy, Steve Rogers, the asthmatic whatever-other-disease-he-had-at-that-point into the most unbelievable situation ... and taking that to the farthest point,â€ he said.

This is what â€œInfinity Warâ€ achieves: setting up Captain America (and the other Avengers left standing at the filmâ€™s end, aka the actors with soon-to-be-expiring contracts), for one final conflict against Thanos to reverse everything and save the universe at the end of the next movie.
What that involves is anyoneâ€™s guess. HuffPostâ€™s Andy McDonald suggested Cap could end up wielding the Infinity Gauntlet in the follow-up movie. Iâ€™d be down with that.
Itâ€™s just, after being promised real stakes, Iâ€™d rather not be treated to more fake deaths and last-minute saves, ultimately left wondering once again, â€œWhat just happened?â€

otherData.headline: Thousands Protest Across Spain After 5 Men Are Cleared Of Gang Rape
otherData.short_description: The group is known as the "wolf pack," named after a WhatsApp chat where they bragged about the assault.

articleContent: Thousands of protesters flooded the streets in cities across Spain after a court failed to convict a group of men for the gang rape of an 18-year-old girl during the Running of the Bulls festival in 2016.

Instead of convicting the five men of rape on Thursday, a three-judge panel in Pamplona in northern Spain found the men guilty of the lesser crime of â€œcontinuous sexual abuse,â€ according to CNN. Unlike a rape charge, sexual abuse charges indicate that violence or intimidation was not involved in the assault.
The judgesâ€™ verdict prompted demonstrators to protest outside of the Pamplona courthouse in droves, calling the failure to convict the men of rape unjust.
Amnesty Internationalâ€™s Spanish chapter said the judgesâ€™ ruling makes women responsible for their rapists.

The attackers have come to be known in Spain as â€œla manada,â€ or the â€œwolf pack,â€ named after the title of a WhatsApp chat group that included four of the five men. Before the festival, members of the chat group discussed using sedatives on women to rape them, according to The Telegraph.

After the attack, members of the group boasted that the men had â€œf***** a girlâ€ and had footage to prove it. CNN reported that one of the men said in a text that the festival had been an â€œamazing trip.â€

The attackers, JosÃ© Ãngel Prenda, Alfonso Cabezuelo, Antonio Manuel Guerrero, JesÃºs Escudero and Ãngel Boza, were sentenced to nine years in prison, five yearsâ€™ probation and were ordered to pay â‚¬10,000 euros (about $12,150) to the victim, The Guardian reported.
Both the state prosecutors and the defendantsâ€™ attorney said they would appeal the judgesâ€™ ruling.
Inigo Mendez de Vigo, a spokesman for the Spanish government, said on Friday that officials would review laws against sexual crimes and update them if necessary, according to CNN.
â€œThe government has been, is and always will be with the victims,â€ he said.

The assault occurred during the famous Festival of San FermÃ­n that includes the running of the bulls. In her testimony last year, the victim said the five men, whom she didnâ€™t know, led her through a doorway, gang-raped her, then stole her phone and fled, Public Radio International reported.
Some of the men had filmed part of the assault on their cellphones, resulting in seven videos that had a total of 96 seconds of footage viewed during the trial.
The woman was later found crying on a bench, according to The Guardian. She filed a report with police and the five men were arrested the next day.
The assault dominated local media for two years, sparking in the country a Spanish version of the Me Too movement against violence on women.
After the verdict was handed down, demonstrators protested outside of the Pamplona courthouse, as well as in the cities of Alicante, Barcelona and Madrid.

Over the years, Pamplonaâ€™s bull festival has been plagued with sexual assaults on women, with reports ranging from groping incidents to more violent assaults including rape. In 2015, similar protests were held after a 19-year-old British woman was reportedly assaulted in a bathroom by a group of men during the festival. She was eventually rescued by her friends.

Days before the â€œwolf packâ€™sâ€ 2016 assault, Pamplonaâ€™s city council added to the festivalâ€™s official rulebook a warning against â€œsexual assaults against women,â€ according to The Telegraph.
â€œSexist attacks against women of any age and in all circumstances will be investigated and punished,â€ Pamplona Mayor Joseba Asiron said at the time, the British newspaper reported.
â€œSan FermÃ­n must be a festival which women can enjoy freely, safely and with complete equality.â€

otherData.headline: Hawaii Moves To Ban Gay Conversion Therapy For Minors

articleContent: Hawaii is set to become the 12th state to ban â€œ conversion therapyâ€ for minors.

The stateâ€™s House and Senate passed a bill on Friday that would prevent licensed medical professionals and counselors from conducting sexuality and/or gender identity conversion therapy to people under the age of 18.
Conversion therapy is rooted in the belief, often found in religious communities, that sexuality and gender identity is a choice, and something that can be changed through therapy.

The legislation, SB 270, discusses â€œsexual orientation change effortsâ€ as a practice that has no scientific backing and can cause â€œdepression, suicidality, loss of sexual feeling, anxiety, shame, negative self-image, and other negative feelings and behaviors,â€ according to the American Psychological Association.

â€œThe purpose of this Act is to protect the physical and psychological well-being of minors, including lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender youth, against exposure to serious harms caused by sexual orientation change efforts,â€ the bill reads.
Hawaii Governor David Ige (D) is expected to sign the bill into law.
Michael Golojuch, chair of the LGBT Caucus of the Democratic Party of Hawaii, reacted to the billâ€™s passage to Hawaii News Now.
â€œThis has been a priority of the caucus for years,â€ Golojuch said. â€[The measure] ensures that LGQTB youth will not be tortured by mental health professionals.â€

JoDee Winterhof, senior vice president for policy and political affairs at the Human Rights Campaign, likened conversion therapy to child abuse when Hawaiiâ€™s House of Representatives passed the initial bill in the beginning of April.

â€œSo-called â€˜conversion therapyâ€™ is nothing short of child abuse with life-threatening consequences for countless LGBTQ youth,â€ Winterhof said in a statement. â€œIt is time Hawaii join the growing number of states who are enacting laws to protect LGBTQ youth from this dangerous and discredited practice.â€

If Ige signs the bill into law, Hawaii would be the 12th state to ban conversion therapy for minors. New Jersey, California, Illinois and New Mexico are among the 11 states that have implemented legislation banning conversion therapy.

The legislation unfortunately does not apply to non-medical professionals such as religious or spiritual advisors. California is currently trying to classify conversion therapy as a fraudulent business practice in order to close this loophole.

articleContent: LONDON, April 30 (Reuters) - Britainâ€™s interior minister resigned on Sunday after Prime Minister Theresa Mayâ€™s government faced an outpouring of indignation over its treatment of some long-term Caribbean residents who were wrongly labeled illegal immigrants.

The loss of one of Mayâ€™s closest allies is a blow as she navigates the final year of negotiations ahead of Britainâ€™s exit from the European Union in March 2019. It also deprives the cabinet of one of its most outspoken pro-European members.

In a resignation letter to May, Amber Rudd said she had inadvertently misled a parliamentary committee last Wednesday by denying the government had targets for the deportation of illegal migrants. May accepted her resignation.

For two weeks, British ministers have been struggling to explain why some descendants of the so-called â€œWindrush generation,â€ invited to Britain to plug labor shortfalls between 1948 and 1971, had been denied basic rights.

The Windrush scandal overshadowed the Commonwealth summit in London and has raised questions about Mayâ€™s six-year stint as interior minister before she became prime minister in the wake of the 2016 Brexit referendum.
â€œThe Windrush scandal has rightly shone a light on an important issue for our country,â€ Rudd said in a resignation letter to May.
Rudd, who was appointed Home Secretary in 2016, said voters wanted those who had the right to reside in Britain to be treated fairly and humanely but also that illegal immigrants be removed.
MAY TO BLAME?
The opposition Labour Party, which had repeatedly called on Rudd to resign, said May was responsible and should explain her own role in the governmentâ€™s immigration policies.

â€œThe architect of this crisis, Theresa May, must now step forward to give an immediate, full and honest account of how this inexcusable situation happened on her watch,â€ said Diane Abbott, Labourâ€™s spokeswoman on interior affairs.
Abbott called on May to give a statement to the House of Commons explaining whether she knew that Rudd was misleading parliament about the deportation targets.

Facing questions over the Windrush scandal, Rudd, 54, told lawmakers on Wednesday that Britain did not have targets for the removal of immigrants, but was forced to clarify her words after leaked documents showed some targets did exist.
The Guardian newspaper on Sunday reported a letter from Rudd to May last year in which she stated an â€œambitious but deliverableâ€ aim for an increase in the enforced deportation of immigrants.
After repeated challenges to her testimony on the deportation of immigrants, Rudd telephoned May on Sunday and offered her resignation.
â€œI feel it is necessary to do so because I inadvertently misled the Home Affairs Select Committee over targets for removal of illegal immigrants,â€ Rudd told May.
With her Conservative Party split over Brexit, May will have to be careful to preserve the uneasy balance in the cabinet after the loss of such a senior pro-EU minister.

Possible contenders who could replace Rudd include Environment Secretary Michael Gove, Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Communities Secretary Sajid Javid, Northern Irish Secretary Karen Bradley and former Northern Irish Secretary James Brokenshire.
WINDRUSH CRISIS

The government has apologized for the fiasco, promised citizenship and compensation to those affected, including to people who have lost their jobs, been threatened with deportation and denied benefits because of the errors.

But the controversy over policies which May is closely associated with has raised awkward questions about how the pursuit of lower immigration after Brexit sits alongside the desire to be an outward-looking global economy.

The immigrants are named after the Empire Windrush, one of the first ships to bring Caribbean migrants to Britain in 1948, when Commonwealth citizens were invited to fill labor shortages and help rebuild the economy after World War Two.
Almost half a million people left their homes in the West Indies to live in Britain between 1948 and 1970, according to Britainâ€™s National Archives.
A week before local elections, May apologized to the black community on Thursday in a letter to The Voice, Britainâ€™s national Afro-Caribbean newspaper.
â€œWe have let you down and I am deeply sorry,â€ she said. â€œBut apologies alone are not good enough. We must urgently right this historic wrong.â€

The crisis has focused attention on May, who as interior minister set out to create a â€œreally hostile environmentâ€ for illegal immigrants, imposing tough new requirements in 2012 for people to prove their legal status.

Ruddâ€™s resignation comes four months after another close ally and her then most senior minister, Damian Green, was forced out of his job for lying about whether he knew pornography had been found on computers in his parliamentary office.
Anna Soubry, a Conservative lawmaker, predicted Rudd may one day return to a senior job in government.
â€œShe is a woman of great courage and immense ability,â€ Soubry said. â€œIf there is any justice she will soon return to the highest of office.â€

otherData.headline: William Friedkin's Faith In Exorcisms Is Unwavering. As For Diversity In Hollywood? It 'Snags' Him.
otherData.short_description: The Oscar-winning director of "The French Connection" and "The Exorcist" discusses his new documentary, the Trumpian zeitgeist and the "evil" in the world.

articleContent: In 1973, William Friedkin released â€œThe Exorcist,â€ one of the highest-grossing and most applauded horror movies in history. In 2018, William Friedkin released â€œThe Devil and Father Amorth,â€ a documentary about exorcisms. The movie landscape has drastically changed in the intervening years, but William Friedkin hasnâ€™t.

He is still a dazzling raconteur. His most recent fiction features, â€œBugâ€ (2006) and â€œKiller Joeâ€ (2011), boast the same moody panache seen in the movies that launched his career, including â€œThe Boys in the Bandâ€ (1970), â€œThe French Connectionâ€ (1971), â€œThe Exorcist,â€ â€œSorcererâ€ (1977) and â€œTo Live and Die in L.A.â€ (1985). And, at 82, he has aged into your overly nostalgic and slightly regressive great-uncle. He rails against the changes in American popular culture â€• sometimes with good reason â€• and carps about the whole â€œdiversityâ€ thing thatâ€™s hit Hollywood in recent years.

For an hour on a recent Thursday afternoon, I sat with Friedkin in his room at Manhattanâ€™s swanky Carlyle Hotel, where the Oscar-winning director wore slippers, green pajama pants and a T-shirt with a dog on it. In â€œThe Devil and Father Amorthâ€ (now in theaters and available on select streaming platforms), Friedkin travels to Italy to profile one of the worldâ€™s leading exorcists as he treats a woman apparently possessed by demonic forces. The movie presents footage of this womanâ€™s exorcism as fact, which led to a conversation about the reliability of documentary filmmaking, the role evil plays in the world, Friedkinâ€™s views on the state of movies today, and the more socially conscious culture we now live in.
Youâ€™re hardly prolific these days.

I have a very active travel and social life. And Iâ€™m writing a script now that I hope to finish in a couple of months that I worked on for a long time that I hope to film next. But I canâ€™t talk about the subject, because if it gets into print it will give other people ideas, which I hope not to do.
You arenâ€™t bit by as much of a moviemaking bug as you once were, perhaps?

Well, when I started out, it was a different kind of zeitgeist. And the stuff thatâ€™s being done today is not of strong interest to me: superhero movies, which is what the studios have put most of their resources behind. It is the new zeitgeist. I wouldnâ€™t even begin to know how to begin to make one of those films.

There are also some very good films that are independent that come out occasionally, but itâ€™s very tough for them. It wasnâ€™t when I started. You had people like John Cassavetes and other great filmmakers who would mortgage their house to make a film. They made interesting, unusual and very personal films. I donâ€™t know if they would publish â€œThe Great Gatsbyâ€ today, or William Faulkner. I just donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s a different zeitgeist. The paintings arenâ€™t the same, the music is not the same, certainly not the popular music of my day.
When did you first notice that zeitgeist change?

It changes constantly. It changed with â€œStar Warsâ€ in the â€™70s. The zeitgeist changed when the silent movies were replaced by sound. [Charlie] Chaplin and [D.W.] Griffith were largely the inspiration for American films. Then I think the next big change was probably â€œCitizen Kane,â€ where a story like that, really utilizing sound on film, changed everything. The complexity and yet the simplicity. And then the next change was in 1960 with the French film â€œBreathlessâ€ by Jean-Luc Godard. Theyâ€™re still shooting films somewhat like that: hand-held cameras, jump cuts. Now itâ€™s changed in American cinema to superhero films, for the most part. Thatâ€™s what theyâ€™re interested in: the next blockbuster. Everyone is trying to replicate â€œStar Wars,â€ its success. I donâ€™t know that these same people would have been comfortable in the early days making films, because they were not about superheroes. They were more complex, deeper and darker films.

The difference with â€œStar Wars,â€ though, is that it was fundamentally an original story when it first opened. It took inspiration from Flash Gordon and whatnot, but nobody had seen anything like â€œStar Warsâ€ before.
We used to see it every Saturday afternoon as kids going to eight little pictures at a time for a quarter. There were Buck Rogers and that whole school of dumb science fiction.
OK, but it wasnâ€™t â€œAvengers 12â€ or â€œTransformers 16.â€

No, but they were making sequels and serials to that stuff all the time. They just didnâ€™t have the tools. And George Lucas didnâ€™t have the tools that they have now, but he did very well with that he had.
Thatâ€™s why the car chase in â€œThe French Connectionâ€ is so famous. It looks handmade.
Well, there was no other way to do it. There were no computer-generated images then. We had to do everything that you saw.
Do you think filmmakers are drunk on the power of visual effects?

I donâ€™t know that I would go that far. I would use it if I had to. Itâ€™s a tool. It can take you to places where you could never before even think about putting a camera. It can take you inside the Taj Mahal or the Louvre or the Vatican, and convincingly. There have been a lot of really good chase scenes that have used it. The â€œBourneâ€ films used computer imagery, and theyâ€™re good chase scenes.
What do you like right now? Whom do you respect as a filmmaker?
I just did a podcast with Guillermo del Toro.
Heâ€™s someone who uses effects in a purposeful and profound way.

I agree. Heâ€™s a very serious filmmaker. He studied with Dick Smith, who did the makeup for â€œThe Exorcist,â€ â€œThe Godfatherâ€ and a lot of other great films. He is a really interesting filmmaker. I like Damien Chazelle, the two films Iâ€™ve seen of his. I like Wes Andersonâ€™s films. I enjoy them a lot. And Tarantino, who has really created a niche for himself.

You and del Toro talked on that podcast about how much you both love old MGM musicals. Iâ€™m sort of extrapolating here, but you implied a few years ago that the birth of rock â€™nâ€™ roll and the changes popular music went through as a result contributed to the downfall of the classical musical.

I think thatâ€™s close enough because rock music was a revolution. Elvis was a revolution. And he made some movies, but theyâ€™re not really musicals. Theyâ€™re shots of Elvis performing. The popular music that gave birth to the MGM musicals were written by people like Cole Porter, George Gershwin, Sammy Cahn, Rodgers and Hammerstein. They were influenced by the popular music of the day, which was largely love songs. The popular music gradually evolved into rap and hip-hop, which is not about that, generally. And theyâ€™re not necessarily singable or danceable, certainly not by people like Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly and Cyd Charisse.
But hip-hop has yielded its own genre of dance, and itâ€™s powerful too.

I havenâ€™t seen any films about hip-hop that are as exciting as â€œThe Band Wagonâ€ or â€œSinginâ€™ in the Rainâ€ or â€œSeven Brides for Seven Brothers.â€ Those and many other films drew on the popular music of the day.
So you liked â€œLa La Landâ€?
I thought it was well-done. [Chazelle] did a very decent homage to the old musical. Heâ€™s such a wonderful filmmaker. And I loved the other film of his I saw, â€œWhiplash.â€ Itâ€™s terrific.
Have you tried to get more movies off the ground in recent years?
Not really. I havenâ€™t found anything since â€œKiller Joeâ€ that has really compelled me.
Are people sending you scripts?

Yes, but itâ€™s not about scripts. Itâ€™s about what you really want to give your life to. You know, I had no script for â€œThe French Connection,â€ but I loved the story. I thought the story was great. We made it up as we went along, but the guy who was the last writer on it won the Academy Award for best screenplay.
Howâ€™d you make sense of that?

When they fall in love with a film at the Academy, they generally fall in love with all of its parts. But Iâ€™m telling you we improvised that film every day on the set. Not one word of the chase was ever written. Itâ€™s not in any script. I went to those locations and I was inspired by them to do something that I had not seen.
Who did you consider your contemporaries?
Francis Coppola and Peter Bogdanovich.
Bogdanovich is someone whoâ€™s made a few movies lately that no one has paid attention to.

Well, thatâ€™s for a variety of reasons. The distribution platforms arenâ€™t the same anymore. Most films are not made for a theater. Theyâ€™re made for Netflix and for video on demand. The films that are made for theaters are the superhero films for large audiences, and some of the horror films recently, which I think are very good. â€œGet Outâ€ and â€œA Quiet Place.â€ I like them a lot.
Horror seems to be the one genre that can can remain original and still succeed both commercially and artistically.
Youâ€™re right.
Even comedies have suffered.

I donâ€™t know whatâ€™s funny to people anymore. Guys acting stupid. I canâ€™t think of any that have moved me recently. And a lot of that is due to series television, where people got used to laugh tracks and everything that somebody says while sitting on the couch and eating a chicken egg gets uproarious laughter. I donâ€™t know what people make of this stuff at home, staring at these people who are supposedly representative of American marriages in all of their various forms today. But theyâ€™re cracking jokes at each other. Is that how people go through life? Is that how you do?
No, certainly not.
You have friends. Are you married?
No, but I have a partner.
Do you guys sit around telling jokes to each other?
I wish. But I think many sitcoms are more nuanced than youâ€™re giving them credit for. And anyway, thereâ€™s a lot to be said for the value of escapism, which is what sitcoms offer.
I couldnâ€™t escape that way. Thatâ€™s not an escape for me.
Whatâ€™s an escape for you?

Reading a good book, fiction or nonfiction. Reading about something I wasnâ€™t aware of before. Or listening to music. Miles Davis. Elvis. John Coltrane. Gil Evans. Itâ€™s hard for me to find somebody in todayâ€™s world, but there are many recording artists that I still listen to, especially in re-release. Sinatra. Thereâ€™s nobody better with a lyric than Frank Sinatra. I like David Bowie a lot.
Did you feel that way about television in the â€™70s, like â€œAll in the Familyâ€?
Well, not in the â€™60s when you had really good humorists on TV. Jack Benny, Red Skelton, Burns and Allen.
What changed?
The zeitgeist changed. First of all, there are no performers like that anymore. Theyâ€™re mostly people that read somebody elseâ€™s jokes and theyâ€™re not naturally funny to me.
Moving on to â€œThe Devil and Father Amorth,â€ itâ€™s pretty shocking to see footage of a supposed exorcism. What got left on the cutting-room floor?

Almost nothing. I had planned to go back and do what we call b-roll with Cristina [the possessed woman in the movie], but she had freaked out by then. Father Amorth was in the hospital with pneumonia, and he never came out. I went back to do her 10th exorcism, and he couldnâ€™t do it. Now she is out there seeking other help but has not been successful as of yet.

[Amorth] was in a class by himself. He was totally original. He was the founder of the International Association of Exorcists. His work was supported and respected by the last three popes. He had been the Vatican exorcist for 31 years. So I fully expected to do her 10th or more, but he passed.
There have been so many â€œExorcistâ€ knockoffs over the years.
Iâ€™ve never seen them. Iâ€™ve never seen the sequels.
Did you ever consider making one?

No, no. [â€œExorcistâ€ screenwriter William Peter] Blatty did â€œExorcist III,â€ which was not called that. It was from his novel called Legion, and then the film company got him to call it â€œExorcist IIIâ€ for obvious reasons. They threw an exorcism in, which he didnâ€™t have.

With all those knockoffs, the image of an exorcism has become mythologized and hyperbolized, partly because â€œThe Exorcistâ€ is so evocative. Understandably, demonic possession has a lot of skeptics. People could easily look at the footage in this movie and still cast doubts on the veracity of what actually happened. How do you feel about that?

I filmed what I saw and experienced. Thatâ€™s all. I didnâ€™t make a film to convert skeptics. Iâ€™m not a skeptic. As a journalist, you should not be a skeptic. You shouldnâ€™t be writing things and thinking people are out there to fool everyone. Weâ€™ve got to be open to what you may or may not get from what youâ€™ve done, but you canâ€™t approach life as a skeptic. First of all, youâ€™re not old enough to be skeptical.
Iâ€™m not saying I personally am skeptical.
No, but there are skeptics who just donâ€™t care enough to examine the unexamined life, so they have an attitude about it. You want to know something? Nobody knows anything.
Sure, we can agree on that.

The greatest philosophers and scholars in the world do not know if thereâ€™s a heaven or a hell or an afterlife or anything about Jesus. We donâ€™t know about the eternal verities, but Iâ€™m curious about all of them. I know Iâ€™ll never know, but that doesnâ€™t stop me from being curious about things that happen that change the world. You have to be curious, for example, about why Trump became president.
I am curious about that, yes.

You have to be. He won 30 states. Now, Mrs. Clinton can blame Comey. She can blame this, that and the other, Russian collusion. But 30 states voted for Donald Trump, who was not a politician. And that tells you something about this country at this time. It could change, it could evolve. There was a time that people had faith in politicians and continued to vote for them. They voted against politicians when they voted for Trump. Theyâ€™d had it. You know the politicians have all just lied to us as long as we can remember.
Yes, but now we have somebody in office who has openly lied since being elected.

Well, I donâ€™t know that. The people who voted for him donâ€™t know that. They wanted something else, and I think, by the way, that he was pretty straightforward with people. He said that he loved to have sex with who he considered beautiful women. We all knew that. He wasnâ€™t denying it. He wasnâ€™t saying that he was Jimmy Carter, a religious man married to the same woman forever.
Heâ€™s no Jimmy Carter, thatâ€™s for sure.
He was a reality-TV host, and they voted for him over a woman whoâ€™d been around politics most of her adult life. So Iâ€™m curious.
Right, and maybe â€œskepticâ€ is the wrong word to get wrapped up in. Storytelling-wise, what we see in this documentary is fairly straightforward in its presentation, but â€•
Totally straightforward. Itâ€™s hardly edited. I shot these people talking, doing an exorcism, these doctors talking about it, and this is what they said.
But I think anybody who watches documentaries with a critical mind should always question whatâ€™s being presented onscreen.
Why?

Because whether a movie is edited heavily or not, a documentary filmmaker captures and assembles the footage however he or she chooses. She chooses who is featured and how the story unfolds and what information is included.
Thatâ€™s true.

So, what is fundamentally objective becomes subjective because itâ€™s filtered through the lens of one filmmaker. Itâ€™s similar with journalism and newsgathering. So thatâ€™s why people might be skeptical of footage that claims to show a real exorcism. We donâ€™t know what happened before and after the events we see in the film.
Yeah, thereâ€™s no subjectivity in what I did with this documentary. This may not be as I feel at all. This is what I heard and saw. Thatâ€™s it, and here it is.

When I filmed the exorcism, I had no idea what I was going to do with it. And then it occurred to me to take it to neurosurgeons and psychiatrists and let them debunk it if thatâ€™s what they were going to do. And they didnâ€™t. But it was up to them. I put not one word in their mouth. I asked them questions. I asked the neurosurgeon from Israel whoâ€™s done thousands of surgeries, â€œDo you have any religious beliefs?â€ He said something to the effect of, â€œBeyond what I can see and feel in the reasonable world, I do accept the existence of an entity called God.â€ Which doesnâ€™t say heâ€™s a religious man at all. Heâ€™s certainly not a Catholic. He tried to explain, from his perspective, what was going on with that woman. It was a religious-based disease in which everyone in the room, including the woman and her priest and her family and other priests who were there, were participating in something that they accepted to be her demonic possession and exorcism.

If you have no religion, or if youâ€™re a Jewish guy or a Muslim or of another faith entirely, you probably would not see an exorcist. Itâ€™s religious-based. The only treatment she or any of the other thousands of people who went to [Amorth] received was exorcism, but they had to see a medical doctor and psychiatrist in Italy first and be told that those skills were not going to help them. Then, if he had the time, he would do an exorcism.
What do you make of Father Amorthâ€™s more outlandish beliefs? Heâ€™s said that Stalin and Hitler were possessed by the devil, and that the devil had a hand in creating â€œHarry Potter.â€
Well, I donâ€™t have any problems about â€œHarry Potter.â€ He did, I guess, because it dealt with witchcraft. He wasnâ€™t the only guy who was troubled by â€œHarry Potter.â€
Sure, itâ€™s not a unique opinion. But you made him the subject of a documentary.

So, what do I feel about what? Hereâ€™s what I feel. First of all, I feel there is evil in the world, without a doubt. Some of it has been alleviated by groups that have come out and spoken up for themselves and fought back, but itâ€™s not even about group evil. Thereâ€™s evil in every human being, just as thereâ€™s a bit of good in many human beings. But how do you explain a guy that goes up into the Mandalay Bay in Vegas and shoots up a rock concert? Or these guys that shoot up the schools? Or the nanny who cold-bloodedly killed two little girls? Is that sickness or is it evil? I donâ€™t know. It may be both. Where does that come from?

In the case of the woman in my documentary, the evil is directed at her, not from her. But I have seen evil in people that I know. You see it in the smallest way almost every day if you drive in Los Angeles. You see road rage. Thatâ€™s when people turn evil. Have you never felt so badly about somebody that you might have wanted to kill them? We all have. You wouldnâ€™t do it because you have restraints. Some people donâ€™t have restraints.
Father Amorth believed the devil was a metaphor, not an actual person or thing. Certainly I canâ€™t argue with that.

A few years ago, you said, â€œWhen youâ€™re making a film, you donâ€™t start to think of the social consequences, or whether there will be any.â€ But todayâ€™s filmmakers, as well as todayâ€™s audiences, do think more critically about the social implications of entertainment. Weâ€™re much more politically conscious, even though the â€™70s are known for being such a politically charged decade in and out of Hollywood. Do you think that evolution toward socially conscious film criticism is a good thing?

I donâ€™t think so. No. I donâ€™t know that I could say this is good, but it does happen. No, I think a film should be enjoyed on its own terms for the ingredients in it. You like the story or you donâ€™t. You like these actors or you donâ€™t. This interests you in the way itâ€™s done or it doesnâ€™t. To apply some other set of principles to it is so subjective. I donâ€™t look at â€œThe Boys in the Bandâ€ as a film simply about the gay lifestyle. Itâ€™s a wonderful love story to me, with great humor.

And itâ€™s still controversial, even as it reopens on Broadway. Part of why everything is so political right now is because the culture hasnâ€™t served folks pushed to the margins. That speaks to the success of â€œBlack Panther,â€ for example.

Yeah, I donâ€™t go to see a work of entertainment to be politicized. I donâ€™t know what the political nature of the Bruce Springsteen show is. Itâ€™s his life. I saw it. It was great. I know that his politics are liberal; thatâ€™s been obvious for years, before this show. But I enjoyed the show as entertainment, period â€” not entertainment from a liberal performer whoâ€™s trying to proselytize me about voting his way or something. Things are more politicized, youâ€™re right. Everything is political. The whole idea of diversity kind of snags me. I think people should be hired on merit. Iâ€™ve always believed that, and yet they werenâ€™t.
But what happens when the system isnâ€™t in place to hire people of merit who donâ€™t fit the dominant demographic?

It was always in place. I just have to tell you that when I hired people, I hired women, men, I didnâ€™t know if they were gay or not gay. I could not have cared less. I was interested in their talent, period. And thatâ€™s all that you can be.

I donâ€™t like Michelangelo because heâ€™s a gay artist. I like him because heâ€™s a great artist. I donâ€™t like Picasso because he was a straight artist. I value a work of art, be it music or painting or cinema, because of the work. I donâ€™t give a good goddamn about Leonardoâ€™s sexuality or Michelangeloâ€™s or Miles Davisâ€™. I just like the work, and Iâ€™m not going to hire somebody just because theyâ€™re black. If theyâ€™re black and good, thatâ€™s wonderful. If theyâ€™re black and theyâ€™re not as good as this other dude over hereâ€¦
Sure, but what happens when the people at the top â€” executives, for example â€” arenâ€™t historically hiring people of color or greenlighting movies about queer people? It becomes a systemic issue.

I donâ€™t know anybody who is that way now, who would say, â€œIâ€™m not going to make this story because the guy is gay or the guy is black or itâ€™s a lesbian.â€ I donâ€™t know anybody in charge of a studio who would do that today.

You have to understand something. The guys who founded the movie industry all started at the bottom somewhere. They started in entry-level jobs. They were stage hands and gaffers and grips. They moved up to become directors. John Ford did that, and Howard Hawks. Some of the greats started on the crew, and they learned every facet of their work. That tradition carried on. There werenâ€™t a lot of women then who sought out jobs as carpenters on a film. There just werenâ€™t. Not because they thought they wouldnâ€™t get them, but it just wasnâ€™t the kind of job a woman sought. Now they do. The thing is, then there were a great many closeted homosexuals who started the film industry. But mostly they were straight guys who were working on the soundstages, or working an entry-level job somewhere and worked their way up. That tradition continued. Instead of carpenters, they became agents. And agents worked their way up to be heads of a studio.

Now, I personally think the best action filmmaker in America today is Kathryn Bigelow, a woman. I think sheâ€™s a great director of actors and action. There were years when people wouldnâ€™t hire her to do an action picture because they thought a woman couldnâ€™t do that, until she did it. So it takes someone coming out of left field to do it. Why have there not been more women who were great artists? Great painters? There was one woman impressionist, I think, Marie Laurencin. Maybe there was somebody else, but Iâ€™m not aware offhand of any of the other impressionists being women, or the pre-Raphaelites or the 17th-century Dutch. The great movements of art: Where were the womenâ€™s paintings? They were not told you could not paint.

But the canon is dominated by men. And art is full of gatekeepers. If you arenâ€™t invited to the table to be exhibited in a gallery, for example, youâ€™re never given the chance to be considered great.

You donâ€™t get to be invited. You do great work, it gets hung. Marie Laurencin was invited. If you do great work, itâ€™s going to be seen. Vincent van Gogh never sold a painting in his lifetime, died at about 44 by committing suicide. You look at a van Gogh today and say, â€œThis is great! What didnâ€™t they see then?â€ And his brother, Theo, was the dealer for the impressionists. He couldnâ€™t sell a Vincent. Why? Now youâ€™ve got to be a billionaire to own a Vincent. What happened? In the short period of less that 100 years, van Gogh went from being unsaleable to one of the great appreciated masters. If Vincent sold one of his paintings then for what they sell now, he would have been a rich man and done more. But he produced well over 3,000 works: oils, water colors, drawings, prints. What did they have against him? He was great and he couldnâ€™t sell, so itâ€™s hard for me to make the argument that there are women like that who were great and couldnâ€™t sell, because I donâ€™t know any.
But history always leaves people out.

Yeah, but nobody ever said that a gay painter will not be working. Michelangelo and Leonardo got the greatest commissions and delivered. I donâ€™t know if anyone gave a shit what they were. Do you care? I donâ€™t.
No, but itâ€™s hard to talk about todayâ€™s landscape by referencing Michelangelo. For a long time, the infrastructure wasnâ€™t there for women directors and protagonists of color.
There were women directors.
Few and far between until just a few years ago.
Ida Lupino, Dorothy Arzner.
Sure, but they are not mentioned in the same breath as â€”
They werenâ€™t as good. The werenâ€™t as good as William Wyler, Orson Welles, Richard Brooks.
Maybe, but the point is more that women werenâ€™t invited to the table and then exalted at the same rate that Howard Hawks and John Ford were.
You donâ€™t get invited to the table.
Well, someone has to sign over a paycheck. Someone has to hire you. During the classic studio system, especially.
You donâ€™t get invited to the table. You make your own place at the table.

Many people think that Iâ€™m gay, but nobody knew or cared if I was or wasnâ€™t. I swear to you. It never was a factor. I neither traded on that fact or not. And I frankly donâ€™t care what people think of me, as long as they donâ€™t think something horrible that isnâ€™t true. But thatâ€™s not horrible to me. Who gives a flying fuck into a rolling donut? I really donâ€™t. I never thought in working with someone â€” and that includes â€œThe Boys in the Bandâ€ â€” â€œAre these guys gay? Is he gay? Is that guy gay?â€ The guy who played the most flaming character in the show was not gay. Cliff Gorman was doing an imitation of a gay man at that time. Some of the others who were, letâ€™s say more butch, were gay. They were actors. And thatâ€™s all that seemed to matter.

But the reason we can even sit here and have a 20-minute discussion about this movie is that culture was so starved for stories about gay characters in general, just as people are for the sort of characters of color we saw in â€œBlack Panther.â€
Youâ€™re right. And they were not given opportunities. Thereâ€™s no doubt about that.
This interview has been edited for clarity and condensed for length.

otherData.headline: Joy Reid's Defenders Praise Her Apology â€” But Ignore Her Apparent Cover-Up
otherData.short_description: The MSNBC host's most ardent fans are willing to turn a blind eye to her hacking claims, and that's unsettling.

articleContent: Joy Reid has apologized for writing anti-LGBTQ posts on her old blog, but she still has not answered important questions about her honesty and journalistic integrity.

A weeklong saga surrounding her claims that The Reid Report, her now-defunct blog, was subject to a cyberattack culminated with the MSNBC host apologizing â€• once again â€• for previously espousing homophobic positions.

The host of â€œAM Joyâ€ said on air Saturday that her opinions have evolved since writing â€œoffensiveâ€ statements several years ago. She echoed an apology she delivered in December after screenshots surfaced of blog posts she wrote between 2007 and 2009 that accused a former Florida governor of being a closeted gay man.
Many of her most vocal supporters online have enthusiastically accepted her apologies, concluding â€• and rightly so â€• that people should be allowed to re-examine their beliefs over time.
What stands out, though, is the ease with which her supporters have accepted her hacking claims, ignoring monumental gaps in plausibility.

After screenshots appearing to capture dozens of her past homophobic blog posts were tweeted the previous week, Reid told Mediaite last Monday that she didnâ€™t author the posts. According to her initial statement, â€œan unknown, external party accessed and manipulated material ... to include offensive and hateful references.â€ Reid said that the newly revealed content â€œseems to be part of an effort to taint my character with false information.â€

â€œI can state unequivocally that it does not represent the original entries,â€ she said. â€œI hope that whoever corrupted the site recognizes the pain they have caused, not just to me, but to my family and communities that I care deeply about: LGBTQ, immigrants, people of color and other marginalized groups.â€

But the hacking claims fell apart under scrutiny from several media outlets. Documents and statements provided to HuffPost by Reidâ€™s hired cybersecurity consultant, Jonathan Nichols, failed to prove Reidâ€™s blog had been hacked or that the disputed posts were in fact fraudulent.

Whatâ€™s more, these homophobic statements Reid has been accused of writing arenâ€™t a major departure from what sheâ€™s already owned up to, nor are they far from the liberal blogging norms of the mid-2000s, as Richard Kim noted in The Nation.

Nichols also told HuffPost that the alleged posts captured in the recent batch of screenshots never existed on Reidâ€™s blog. But HuffPost and other outlets found this simply wasnâ€™t true. You can view the alleged posts in full here.
Many of Reidâ€™s followers either cast doubt on reports calling into question the veracity of her hacking claims or pledged unwavering support even if the claims proved untrue.

Reid returned to her show this Saturday, after nearly a week of noticeable silence on her social media pages. She addressed the alleged hacking, saying her hired cybersecurity experts could not prove it happened, but that she doesnâ€™t think she wrote the posts.

â€œWhen a friend found them in December and sent them to me, I was stunned,â€ Reid said. â€œFrankly, I couldnâ€™t imagine where theyâ€™d come from or whose voice that was. In the months since, Iâ€™ve spent a lot of time trying to make sense of these posts.â€

â€œI hired cybersecurity experts to see if somebody had manipulated my words or my former blog, and the reality is they have not been able to prove it,â€ she continued. â€œBut hereâ€™s what I know: I genuinely do not believe I wrote those hateful things because they are completely alien to me. But I can definitely understand based on things I have tweeted and have written in the past why some people donâ€™t believe me.â€
Her comments appeared in stark contrast to her initial statement.

Reid apologized for her past anti-trans comments about conservative host Ann Coulter, who Reid called a â€œdudeâ€ and a â€œdrag queenâ€ on Twitter in 2011. She explained that she grew up in a household that had â€œconservative viewsâ€ on the LGBTQ community.
The next 30 minutes or so of Saturdayâ€™s show were dedicated to discussion with a panel of LGBTQ activists on the ways â€œhurtful speechâ€ imperils marginalized communities.

Reid did not say whether her hired cybersecurity experts were continuing to investigate the alleged hacking, nor did she provide new details about the FBIâ€™s alleged investigation into the matter, as confirmed by her attorney Wednesday. She did not address the posts at all during her show Sunday, nor did any of her guests bring them up.
Support from Reidâ€™s defenders, including several MSNBC reporters, flooded Twitter over the weekend.

It is striking â€• and disturbing â€• that Reidâ€™s colleagues and her employer arenâ€™t demanding answers about her seemingly contradictory statements on the alleged hacking. In her initial statement, Reid said a cybersecurity expert had â€œidentified ... unauthorized activityâ€ on her blog that resulted in numerous â€œfabricatedâ€ posts. But on Saturday, Reid said her hired experts couldnâ€™t prove it.
MSNBC has not publicly released a statement supporting Reid. On Sunday, a MSNBC spokesman told NPRâ€™s David Folkenflik that network executives â€œremain supportive of Reid.â€

A representative for MSNBC declined to provide HuffPost with evidence suggesting Reidâ€™s blog had been subject to â€œunauthorized activity,â€ as Reid claimed in her initial statement. Nichols did not respond to a request for additional comment.
MSNBC also hasnâ€™t responded to a request for comment about whether the network is conducting an internal investigation into Reidâ€™s story.
If the network canâ€™t be trusted to seek truth in its own organization, how can it expect its viewers to trust it to seek truth from the highest levels of the government?

Memory is malleable, and itâ€™s possible that Reid, when first confronted with the latest batch of screenshots, genuinely believed that she did not write them. But as a journalist and public intellectual, she had an obligation to thoroughly examine whether she wrote the items that she now views as hateful. Instead, she waved away this responsibility by declaring that she does not â€œbelieveâ€ she wrote them.

At a time when the press is routinely attacked by the Trump administration, integrity should be of the utmost importance to every media organization. Reid is obviously well-liked by liberals, and as a female political analyst of color she offers a voice thatâ€™s often underrepresented on cable news.

Surely people neednâ€™t condemn Reidâ€™s character to eternal damnation over this incident, but the public can â€• and should â€• demand transparency and truth from journalists. As some of Reidâ€™s most high-profile defenders have noted in the past, our democracy depends on it.
This article has been updated to note that an MSNBC spokesmanâ€™s comment to NPR was not an official statement from the network.

otherData.headline: Police Guard White Nationalist Conference From Protesters At Tennessee State Park
otherData.short_description: The American Renaissance conference took over a taxpayer-owned hotel. Protesters wanted the racists inside to know they're not welcome in Tennessee.

articleContent: BURNS, Tenn. â€” Police formed a tight perimeter around a Tennessee state-owned hotel Saturday, guarding a white nationalist conference inside the building from anti-racist protesters gathered outside.

American Renaissance, a racist Virginia-based organization listed by the Southern Poverty Law Center as a hate group, reserved the 125 rooms inside Montgomery Bell State Park Inn for the weekend conference. Attendees not staying at the hotel arrived there early Saturday morning. Nearly all of them were men. They wore suit and ties â€” mandatory dress for the event â€” and didnâ€™t respond to reportersâ€™ questions as police escorted them inside.
Anti-racist protesters arrived a short time later. State park rangers subjected each protester to a metal detector test before allowing them to enter a fenced-off area across from the hotel.
One protester, Beth Foster, grew upset when park rangers wouldnâ€™t allow her to bring a purse inside, as bags were prohibited in the protest zone.

â€œThis is absolutely absurd,â€ she told the officers. â€œNazisâ€ from out of state, she told them, were allowed to rent out an entire Tennessee taxpayer-owned hotel, and yet she wasnâ€™t allowed to bring a tiny purse inside a section of her own state park. Eventually Foster â€” co-director of the Mercy Junction Justice and Peace Center in Chattanooga, Tennessee â€” left her purse and walked through the security checkpoint.

â€œItâ€™s anti-racist activists that the state sees as the enemies,â€ she told reporters. â€œNot the Nazis or the white supremacists who are in our buildings, using our public restrooms, and eating in our public restaurant, plotting genocide.â€

The Inn at Montgomery Bell State Park â€” nestled in a 3,850-acre state park 30 miles west of Nashville â€” has hosted American Renaissanceâ€™s annual conference since 2012. Privately owned venues had repeatedly canceled or denied reservations to American Renaissance before that, after pressure from anti-racist activists. Legally, itâ€™s more difficult for publicly owned venues like the parkâ€™s inn to deny reservations to racist groups.

But this yearâ€™s American Renaissance conference was marked by a much larger police presence than in years past. Over 100 officers from local and state law enforcement were in the park Saturday. A handful were stationed on the roof of the inn, looking down at protesters. A helicopter circled overhead. Police rode around on horseback. Police dogs sniffed at cars. At one point, police opened and searched a vehicle that appeared to belong to an anti-racist protester.

Since the deadly â€œUnite The Rightâ€ white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, last August â€” which erupted into violence and ended with a neo-Nazi driving his car into a crowd of anti-racist protesters, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer and injuring 19 others â€” cities across the country have aggressively policed white supremacist events.

At the American Renaissance conference Saturday, the 60 or so anti-racist protesters â€” from groups including Nashville AntiFa, Anti-Racist Action Nashville, the Tennessee Anti-Racist Network, Womenâ€™s March Tennessee and Shelbyville Loves â€” were kept about 100 yards away from the hotel behind a police barricade. Over 50 police officers stood guard outside the inn.

â€œThose are the most influential white supremacists in the world meeting at this rural location in Tennessee!â€ Lacy MacAuley, an anti-fascist activist from Washington, D.C., yelled at the cops. â€œYou all are protecting absolute evil right now and youâ€™re looking at us as if weâ€™re the problem!â€

Marisa Richmond, a history professor at Middle Tennessee State University, said she has come to multiple protests against American Renaissance. In previous years, protesters were allowed to go into the building, to use the bathroom, buy some food, and occasionally confront the white supremacists face to face.
â€œIâ€™m a Tennessee taxpayer and I grew up here and Iâ€™m not even allowed to enter the building now,â€ she said. â€œWe pay for that.â€

Police also prohibited protesters from wearing masks at this yearâ€™s protest. When one young protester briefly wore a bandana around the lower half of his face, police charged at him, grabbed him by the arms and walked him out of the protest pen. Other protesters followed, swarming the police and chanting â€œLet him go!â€ and â€œShame!â€

Police did not arrest the masked protester but forced him out of the protest area. In an act of solidarity, a group of his fellow protesters then donned masks of their own and stared down police for an hour. This time the police did nothing.

The Southern Poverty Law Center, a legal advocacy group that tracks extremism, describes American Renaissance as a â€œself-styled think tank that promotes pseudo-scientific studies and research that purport to show the inferiority of blacks to whites â€” although in hifalutin language that avoids open racial slurs and attempts to portray itself as serious scholarship.â€

Its founder, Jared Taylor, has said: â€œBlacks and whites are different. When blacks are left entirely to their own devices, Western civilization â€” any kind of civilization â€” disappears.â€ Heâ€™s discussed sterilizing mothers who are on welfare, and has advocated for the creation of a whites-only country, or ethnostate, within the U.S.

Previous American Renaissance conferences have attracted some of Americaâ€™s most notorious white supremacists, including David Duke and Richard Spencer, who called for â€œpeaceful ethnic cleansingâ€ in the U.S. at a prior yearâ€™s event.

American Renaissance denied this HuffPost reporter press credentials to report from inside this yearâ€™s conference. (â€œThere will be plenty of media at our conference,â€ Taylor wrote in an email. â€œYou, on the other hand, have a record of covering any form of racial dissidence, not as a journalist, but as a closed-minded bigot.â€)

The conference was billed on the American Renaissance website as an opportunity for speakers and attendees to â€œplot a course for the years aheadâ€ after some â€œstartling setbacksâ€ over the last year, likely referring to infighting that has fractured the white nationalist movement since last yearâ€™s rally in Charlottesville.

Paul Adams, a 65-year-old U.S. Navy veteran, drove over 50 miles from Smyrna, Tennessee, for Saturdayâ€™s protest. â€œIf my neighbor had a rattlesnake in his backyard, Iâ€™d sure come over and tell him,â€ he explained.
He held a sign showing a giant Uncle Sam preparing to crush a group of Nazis. â€œYou again?â€ it said. â€œStop the â€˜alt-right.â€™ We beat â€™em before. Weâ€™ll beat â€™em now.â€

Daryle Lamont Jenkins, a longtime anti-racist activist and executive director of the One Peopleâ€™s Project, which monitors far-right groups, said â€œthe suit and tiesâ€ that typically attend American Renaissance conferences are especially concerning because â€œtheyâ€™re the ones that have real careers, theyâ€™re the ones that get into academia, theyâ€™re the ones that get into politics.â€
â€œYou gotta maintain vigilance against groups like this,â€ he said. â€œYou gotta say, â€˜Weâ€™re watching.â€™â€

The American Renaissance attendees appeared content to hunker down in the hotel all day Saturday, offering protesters few chances to heckle them. When one older man in a suit and tie was escorted by police into the event, protesters yelled â€œNazi scum!â€
The protesters also did their best to try and be heard inside the hotel, breaking out in chants of â€œHeather Heyer! Say her name!â€ and blaring Billie Holiday songs through a megaphone.

Some protesters lit candles for those murdered by white supremacists. Others denounced the Tennessee state House of Representatives for declining last month to pass a resolution condemning neo-Nazis and white supremacists.

Rumors spread that police were preparing for a mass arrest, but by 3:30 p.m., it became clear that was just a rumor. Protesters walked out of the protest pen, many retiring to a park pavilion for drinks and food, taking in the beautiful spring day.
The white nationalists, whose conference lasts through Sunday, stayed fortified in the hotel. A large contingent of police remained outside, standing guard.

America does not do a good job of tracking incidents of hate and bias. We need your help to create a database of such incidents across the country, so we all know whatâ€™s going on. Tell us your story.
