articleContent: â€œDoesnâ€™t Look Like Anything To Leigh ... And Billâ€ is HuffPostâ€™s weekly recap where we look at the craziest thing you may have missed on â€œWestworld.â€ This week: Season 2, Episode 1, â€œJourney Into Night.â€
When â€œWestworldâ€ brought itself back online Sunday night, we immediately stopped and shouted, â€œWhoa, baby!â€
Namely because of the title sequence for Season 2, which is reminiscent of Season 1â€²s layout with a few new additions â€• including a baby.
To get the inside scoop, we talked to the creative director behind the titles, Patrick Clair. But first, letâ€™s discuss a popular and relevant â€œWestworldâ€ theory:
The next step in the hostsâ€™ evolution is, well, robot babies.
A â€œWestworldâ€ fan theory thatâ€™s been around since the first season supposes that androids could eventually make babies â€• children weâ€™ll affectionately refer to as robotots.

â€œRobot babies?!â€ was Luke Hemsworthâ€™s reaction when we spoke to him about the opening credits this month. The actor, who plays security officer Ashley Stubbs on â€œWestworld,â€ said he saw the Season 2 premiere for the first time in Los Angeles on Monday and insisted he didnâ€™t remember the â€œlittle robot babies.â€

Well, Stubbs, weâ€™re here to fill you in.

Robot reproduction makes a whole lot of sense, and it could be the next logical step in the androidsâ€™ quest to become the superior race. There was even speculation in Season 1 that procreation was the final step of the ever-confusing maze. After all, thereâ€™s a little dot under the figure in the maze drawing (conveniently located on a scalp below). Could it possibly represent new life?
The reproduction angle didnâ€™t happen in Season 1, and the maze turned out to be about the robots finding true consciousness, but there are subtle hints that itâ€™s still a lingering possibility.

For example, one of the Season 2 trailers used Nirvanaâ€™s â€œHeart-Shaped Boxâ€ as a backing track â€• you know, the song from their album â€œIn Utero.â€ If that doesnâ€™t scream robotots, what does?

Furthermore: those title sequences we were talking about. In the latest season premiere, we get a glimpse of a mother and child in the opening credits. The vignette replaced Season 1â€²s scene of two robot lovers.

The sequenceâ€™s designer, Clair, didnâ€™t outright confirm robotots are on the way, but he did say the titles might hint at whatâ€™s to come. While reflecting on the mother and child scene, Clair told us, â€œWhat really affected me most watching Season 1 was the bond between parent and child, and mother and baby, and I think led us to be like, what could we do that has the emotional resonance of the lovers but goes in a new direction of where the story has been, where the story is going?â€

â€œI think there will be some real rewards for people as the season plays out,â€ he added. â€œTheyâ€™ll start to really be able to realize what that means and its place within the titles.â€

So ... robotots confirmed?

At least Hemsworth is into the idea.

Though he missed the baby in the opening sequence, he told HuffPost, â€œWould I be surprised if something like that happens? Itâ€™s an interesting direction, for sure,â€ he laughed, continuing, â€œItâ€™s very scary but I think itâ€™s on par with the innovation of the show. Whether we see anything like that anytime soon, I donâ€™t know. Once robots can have babies, I think the outlook for the human race is probably pretty bleak.â€

All weâ€™re saying is: why not? There are so many advantages. You can put your baby in sleep mode whenever you want, and they probably have a Wifi connection. Who wouldnâ€™t want a hot spot in their robotot?
While weâ€™re waiting for more on that possible reveal, Clair was also kind enough to walk us through the other additions to the updated opening credits.
The buffalo hints at the theme.

On the falling buffalo, Clair said, â€œThis was how buffalo or bison could be hunted back in time where they could kind of be cajoled into diving off cliffs, and you have this tragic moment of them falling to their deaths. [Itâ€™s] tragic for the beast, but obviously theyâ€™re generating food and feeding the circle of life, and I think for us, that became an interesting theme because so much of the â€˜Westworldâ€™ titles are about the circle of life.â€
The brains are like a visual search engine.

â€³[In the first season], we use the iris of the hosts ... to reflect the landscapes, so when we were looking for something that could do the same thing as the iris you kind of realize thereâ€™s this quite beautiful object â€• we call it the pearl. Itâ€™s the brain of the host, so we sort of went about imagining how that could look in extreme close up.â€

He told us the idea was â€œvisualizing neural networks like the ones search engines use, like the ones that image recognition uses, and then imagine how that could work in a more complicated three-dimensional space.â€
The hat is sinking. The hosts are rising.

Season 1 titles end with a host sinking back into liquid. Clair wanted to insinuate a sense of progression in Season 2â€²s opening, so he based the image of the host on photographs looking up from water into the sky.

â€œWe got this imagery of this mysterious black hat drifting into the abyss while the host is actually emerging from this dark liquid. Having that host be a female host ... there are so many empowered characters from Season 1. [There] are amazing badass female robots, so this felt like a slightly more empowered way to kick off the episodes of Season 2.â€
The mother and child are the perfect setup.
The image of the baby was a personal experience for Clair, who has a 5-year-old son of his own.

â€œRealizing that youâ€™re bringing this very sacred thing into the world, bringing a mind into the world, thatâ€™s everything that â€˜Westworldâ€™ is about. Itâ€™s about the sacred mysterious responsibilities of giving rise to conscious minds. Itâ€™s something that all of us have experience of from a childâ€™s perspective, and so many of us have experience from a parentâ€™s perspective, and I think any imagery there can kind of evoke that from the start of this story is a good kind of setup for where itâ€™s gonna go.â€
If you find yourself unsettled by the figures, thatâ€™s on purpose.

â€œI think if you saw the lovers or the mother and child in full light, you would be horrified. It would give you nightmares. Those beings, the way we designed them, is based on where the light falls on them. Where the light falls on them, theyâ€™re fairly complete.â€

To create the figures of the lovers and the mother and child, the design team started with anatomical models and then peeled back layers until they are â€œdeeply grotesque.â€ Those parts of the characters remain in the shadows.

â€œBeing very careful with the light, hopefully, you donâ€™t see that, but you get a sense of that there. Maybe one day weâ€™ll show everyone what it looks like if you actually turn the lights on in that room.â€

articleContent: Give me a T-H-A-N-O-S! What does that spell?
Meh, never mind. It doesnâ€™t really matter now anyway.

Crazy theories about â€œAvengers: Infinity Warâ€ keep cropping up, since so little is actually known about the movie. Some people think all the dead characters are coming back, while others speculate that all the past villains could make an appearance.
But in the lead-up to the new movie, one theory has risen above the rest: The name of the main villain, Thanos, has been secretly revealing the locations of the infinity stones.
There are six infinity stones. There are six letters in Thanosâ€™ name. Thanos is after the infinity stones. It just makes sense.
It even seems to line up, as Nerdist laid out:

T is for Tesseract, the Space Stone
A is for Aether, the Reality Stone
N is for Necklace, the Time Stone
O is for Orb, the Power Stone
S is for Lokiâ€™s Scepter, the Mind Stone

Fans have been using this theory to try to figure out the location of the final missing infinity stone, the soul stone. The popular guesses are that the H may stand for Idris Elbaâ€™s character, Heimdall, or that N stands for Nebula rather than Necklace. Nebula is one of Thanosâ€™ daughters, a character who plays a big role in the â€œInfinity Gauntletâ€ comic that served as an inspiration for the movie.
HuffPostâ€™s Leigh Blickley asked Karen Gillan, who plays Nebula, for her thoughts over the weekend, and she was intriguingly vague.

â€œI canâ€™t say whether thatâ€™s going to happen,â€ Gillan said of the theory. â€œNebula has a significant role and has a lot of stuff to do because her father is Thanos, who is the villain of the movies. She has some serious daddy issues with him, so she has a lot to confront.â€
That made it sound to us like the theory might be right. But then I talked to â€œAvengers: Infinity Warâ€ writers Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely on Sunday.
While reflecting on the wildest theories he has heard, McFeely settled on one that was â€œobviously crazy.â€ You guessed it: spelling out T-H-A-N-O-S to reveal the locations of the stones.
And just like that, the theory was O-V-E-R.
â€œThat seems fairly random,â€ McFeely said.
â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s how you go about writing a good script,â€ Markus added.

â€œIt really isnâ€™t,â€ McFeely agreed, laughing and imagining what that writing process would look like. â€â€˜You know, itâ€™d be great to put the soul stone here but itâ€™s not an O,â€™ or whatever the hell it is.â€
â€œWe need an O planet,â€ Markus joked.
Look, Nebula could still have something to do with the soul stone. After all, Gillan confirmed she has a â€œsignificantâ€ role. But it wonâ€™t have anything to do with spelling out her dadâ€™s name.
The writers also set us straight on some other rumors and theories.
There wonâ€™t be a Sherlock Holmes joke.

It doesnâ€™t take a detective to figure out there was the opportunity for a great Sherlock Holmes joke in â€œInfinity Warâ€: Robert Downey Jr. and Benedict Cumberbatch appear together in scenes, and both actors have played popular versions of the character in recent years.
Unfortunately, weâ€™re not going to see that in â€œInfinity War.â€

â€œI donâ€™t want to ruin peopleâ€™s fun, but the idea is that thatâ€™s a meta joke, right?â€ McFeely said. â€œThatâ€™s a joke that those two guys are actors and have careers outside of these movies. For our purposes, theyâ€™re not actors, and they donâ€™t have careers outside of these movies.â€
â€œNow both Watsons [Martin Freeman and Jude Law] are in the MCU too, so itâ€™s still some sort of situation,â€ Markus added, referring to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Could Ant-Man secretly be in other Marvel movies? Maybe.
Another theory thatâ€™s been floating around is that Ant-Man has possibly secretly been in all the Marvel movies from the start, just miniaturized.
â€œEven if I could confirm or deny it, how could I confirm or deny it?â€ McFeely joked.
Both Markus and McFeely speculated that even if Hank Pym (Michael Douglas) was originally out there as Ant-Man, he still isnâ€™t old enough to be in â€œCaptain America: The First Avenger.â€
So itâ€™s possible Ant-Man has made appearances, but maybe he hasnâ€™t been in all the movies.
Loki probably didnâ€™t intentionally lose in the first â€œAvengers.â€
One theory says Loki (Tom Hiddleston) may have intentionally failed in his plan to take over Earth in the first â€œAvengersâ€ movie.
The idea is that Loki always wanted to take over Asgard. Failing on Earth was his way to be taken back there by his brother. He eventually takes over at the end of â€œThor: The Dark World.â€
The writers were skeptical about that theory, too.
â€œIt sounds like a long and inefficient plan,â€ Markus said. â€œHe couldâ€™ve just gone to Asgard.â€
Sure, maybe. But Loki is all about theatrics, and we wouldnâ€™t have had scenes like this if he went straight to Asgard:
He may not get a crown, but Loki at least deserves an Oscar.
Leigh Blickley contributed reporting.

otherData.headline: Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens Outside Voter Registration Center In Kabul
otherData.authors: Qadir Sediqi and Sayed Hassib, Reuters
otherData.short_description: The blast came after repeated warnings that militants could try to disrupt the country's election process.

articleContent: By Qadir Sediqi and Sayed Hassib

KABUL (Reuters) - A suicide bomber blew himself up outside a voter registration center in the Afghan capital Kabul on Sunday, killing at least 57 people and injuring more than 100, in the most serious attack yet on preparations for elections scheduled for October.

Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack on a project of key importance to the credibility of President Ashraf Ghaniâ€™s government, which has been under international pressure to ensure long-delayed parliamentary polls take place this year.

Interior Ministry spokesman Najib Danesh said a bomber on foot approached the center where officials were issuing identity cards as part of the registration process for around 10 million voters across Afghanistan. Registration began this month.
President Ghani issued a statement condemning the attack and said it â€œcannot divert us from our aims or weaken this national democratic processâ€.
A spokesman for the ministry of public health said at least 57 people, including eight children, were confirmed dead and 119 wounded, but the total could still rise.
The explosion destroyed cars and shattered windows in nearby buildings, leaving rubble strewn across the blood-stained street.

It was the deadliest blast in Kabul since about 100 people were killed in January by a bomb concealed in an ambulance and it came after repeated warnings that militants could try to disrupt the election process.
Tadamichi Yamamoto, the senior United Nations official in Afghanistan, issued a statement condemning the attack.

â€œCompounding the callous disregard for the lives of civilians, the killing appears to be part of a wholly unacceptable effort by extremists to deter Afghan citizens from carrying out their constitutional right to take part in elections,â€ he said.

After weeks of relative calm, the blast took place in Dasht-e Barchi, an area of western Kabul inhabited by many members of the mainly Shiâ€™ite Hazara minority, which has been repeatedly hit by attacks claimed by Islamic State.
â€œThere were women, children. Everyone had come to get their identity cards,â€ said Bashir Ahmad who had been near the blast, which occurred despite heightened security after the January attack.

According to U.N. figures, more than 750 people have been killed or maimed in suicide attacks and bombings by militant groups during the three months to March ahead of an expected start of the Talibanâ€™s usual spring offensive.
BITTER REACTION

Afghanistanâ€™s international partners have insisted that the elections should be held this year before a presidential vote due in 2019, although there has been widespread scepticism that they will go ahead.

More than 7,000 voter registration centers have been set up across Afghanistan to handle about 10 million registrations in a process that has been repeatedly disrupted by technical and organizational problems.

Officials had pledged tight security to ensure the process, which will be vital to ensuring a ballot broad-based enough to be accepted as legitimate, proceeded safely. But those caught by Sundayâ€™s attack voiced frustration at what many Kabul residents see as government shortcomings in securing the capital.

â€œThey should be keeping the country safe, if they canâ€™t, someone else should be in their place,â€ said Sajeda, who was wounded in the blast along with three other members of her family as they lined up for their cards.
The voter registration process, designed to reduce the electoral fraud that has marred past ballots, began this month but there have already been several security incidents.

On Sunday, a roadside bomb near a registration center in the northern city of Pul-i Khumri killed six members of a family and wounded three, although there was no indication that the incident was directly linked to the Kabul attack.

Last week, two police officers in the eastern city of Jalalabad were killed outside a voter registration center, while a voter center in the central province of Ghor was burned down last week and electoral officials briefly abducted.
The vote could be postponed to next year if registration of voters, many of whom do not have national identity cards, is not completed before winter sets.
Parliament is still sitting three years after its term officially expired and further delays would seriously weaken already fragile confidence in the political system.

There was an additional scare on Sunday when a NATO military convoy in Kabul accidentally hit and injured a child and triggered a protest that police dispersed by firing into the air. A NATO spokesman said the child had been taken to hospital and was in a stable condition.
(Additional reporting by Abdul Aziz Ibrahimi, Sardar Razmal in KUNDUZ, Ahmad Tolba in CAIRO; writing by James Mackenzie; Editing by Robert Birsel/Edmund Blair/David Evans)

otherData.headline: Netflix Sought To Purchase A Chain Of Movie Theaters
otherData.short_description: The next step for the streaming giant, or a step backward?

articleContent: Streaming service Netflix has been looking to buy its own series of movie theaters, according to The Los Angeles Times.

The newspaper, citing sources familiar with the matter, reported that the company attempted to reach a deal with L.A.-based Landmark theaters, but negotiations went south because Netflix believed the asking price was too high.
Why the streaming giant would need to buy theaters may have something to do with its strained relationship with the Cannes Film Festival.

Netflix, still looking to be seen as a legitimate filmmaking entity, pulled out of Cannes this year after the festival decided movies without theater distribution in France would not be allowed to compete for prizes. This continues a storied war between the streaming service and the French festival.
The Netflix original film â€œOkjaâ€ was featured at the Cannes Film Festival in 2017, but when the film was shown, the Netflix logo drew boos from the festival crowd.

Netflix original films have been gaining critical acclaim in recent years. â€œMudboundâ€ received four 2018 Oscar nominations and â€œIcarus,â€ a film about the doping scandal surrounding Russian Olympic athletes, won this yearâ€™s Oscar for best documentary. Netflix productions have also won four Golden Globes and 37 Emmy Awards.

As filmmaking evolves in the streaming age of Netflix and Amazon, itâ€™s difficult to know what role brick-and-mortar theaters will play in the future of the movie-making business. Maybe Netflix knows something we donâ€™t?

otherData.headline: Dating App Transdr Aims To Be A Tinder Alternative For Trans People
otherData.short_description: The app's descriptions of trans people still need revisions, some of our readers have pointed out.

articleContent: A new app aims to make dating in the digital age a little easier for the transgender community â€• but its developers may need to reconsider some of its presentation before that can be successfully achieved.

Billed as â€œTinder for trans people,â€ Transdr aims to help connect reliable partners and friends. At the same time, the appâ€™s developers hope it will fill a long-existing void as a legitimate dating app focused exclusively on transgender users and trans-attracted people.

The app, which launched last month and is currently available for free, operates in a similar fashion to predecessors Tinder and Grindr. Users can swipe right or left on a profile depending on their level of interest, and if both users swipe rightâ€” indicating mutual interest â€” they can communicate with each other. Thereâ€™s also a search feature that allows users to narrow their preferences.
Transdrâ€™s co-founder Sean Kennedy described the app as â€œa new place for trans people who are looking for serious relationships.â€

As noble as Transdrâ€™s aims may be, however, some of the appâ€™s marketing relies on language many interpret as transphobic. After this story was first published, HuffPost readers flagged that the app included several derogatory terms such as â€œtrannyâ€ and â€œshemaleâ€ on its Apple Store landing page and its website.
A representative for Transdr told HuffPost in an email that such words were used â€œto improve the search ranking.â€
â€œThose terms â€¦ were used for SEO purposes because a lot of people search [for] them every day,â€ the representative said. â€œWe didnâ€™t mean to offend people who care about this.â€
The company is looking at updating its Apple Store description to remove the offending terms, they added, but the process may take some time since Apple needs to approve any changes.

Interestingly, Transdr arrives at a time when previously existing apps have already expanded their services to include trans users. In 2016, Tinder announced an update that made it possible for users to specify gender identities like â€œtransgender,â€ â€œtrans man,â€ â€œtrans woman,â€ and â€œgender queer.â€
Previously aimed at gay men, Grindr followed suit last November, offering users customizable gender identity and pronoun fields.

In spite of those efforts, questions about those appsâ€™ inclusivity for all users remain. Last month, a transgender woman in Oregon reportedly filed a lawsuit against Tinder, arguing that her profile was removed from the app for â€œviolating its terms of serviceâ€ after she indicated that she was a â€œpreop trans woman.â€
Meanwhile, Craigslist shuttered its personals section in late March, removing yet another social networking resource for trans people.

â€œLife has been so hard for trans people because they have to overcome the social stigma of being transgender. When it comes to dating, itâ€™s even harder for them,â€ Kennedy, who is based in Canada, said in an email statement. â€œThey need a comfortable place to meet and date with other trans people without judgment.â€
This story has been updated to note Transdrâ€™s use of problematic language and to include the companyâ€™s remarks on the issue.

otherData.headline: In 'Brown Rice,' Natti Vogel Examines A Gay Man's Struggle With Self-Image
otherData.short_description: In the indie-pop singer's video, Matthew Wilkas escapes inner turmoil through drugs and casual sex.

articleContent: Indie pop singer-songwriter Natti Vogel hopes his new video, â€œBrown Rice,â€ will encourage viewers to â€œempathize with some real, modern-day pitfallsâ€ of queer life.

Vogelâ€™s video, viewed above, is at once steamy and melancholic. It follows a gay character (played by Matthew Wilkas) who, on the surface, has it all: chiseled good looks, an active lifestyle and a lively social media presence.

Far from the gaze of Instagram, however, Wilkasâ€™ character struggles to fill an emotional void. He finds a temporary escape from his depression through a night of drugs and casual sex with a stranger (adult film star Tegan Zayne). At the videoâ€™s conclusion, he locks eyes with Vogel in an empty Manhattan nightclub, and the two men share a moment of solidarity.

Released March 29, â€œBrown Riceâ€ arrives at a prolific time for Vogel who, until now, had been known primarily on New Yorkâ€™s indie music circuit, with performances at the Brooklyn Museum and National Sawdust. The video is the third to be released from his six-track debut EP, â€œServing Body,â€ and had racked up more than 40,000 views as of Sunday afternoon. (By comparison, the clip for the catchy second single, â€œI Donâ€™t Want To Find The One,â€ had received just over 1,100.)

Much of the buzz on â€œBrown Riceâ€ has focused on Wilkasâ€™ presence. The actor, whose credits include 2012â€™s â€œGaybyâ€ and HBOâ€™s â€œLooking,â€ has become a media fixture in recent weeks due in part to his relationship with Olympic freeskier Gus Kenworthy. Footage of the two men sharing a kiss during the Winter Games made global headlines and received praise from LGBTQ rights advocates.

Though grateful that Wilkasâ€™ rising star has boosted interest in â€œBrown Rice,â€ Vogel is hopeful that discerning viewers will see the video as an â€œunfiltered and uncompressedâ€ portrait of the queer â€œemotional experienceâ€ rather than simply a serving of beefcake.

â€œI want the general audience to feel the desperation of needing to be approved of and to question the lengths they are willing to go to gain that approval at the expense of whatever it is that might make them amazing to begin with,â€ the singer told HuffPost. He added that he wrote the song about â€œa super-athletic, super-arrogant ex I never felt good enough for.â€
â€œI want audiences to actively yearn for whatever parts of themselves that theyâ€™ve been suppressing,â€ he said.
To help execute his vision, Vogel tapped director Eamon Foley, a veteran Broadway performer and choreographer who recently co-founded a production company called Grind Arts.

Calling Vogelâ€™s song â€œhaunting and gorgeous,â€ Foley aimed to paint a picture of â€œa man chasing a thrill or some sort of climax, but falling short of satisfaction.â€ Still, he stressed that â€œBrown Riceâ€ isnâ€™t meant to â€œjudge a certain subset of gay men or cast a shameful light on certain actions.â€

â€œI wanted everyone to be able to find themselves in this character, and question if what consumes them is leading them towards happiness,â€ he said. â€œEven the man who looks like he has it all with his 100K followers and free underwear feels inadequate ... [Many] gay men are organizing their lives around an unachievable ideal that wonâ€™t take care of them in their old age.â€
Ultimately, Vogel said he hopes to portray other aspects of queer life in his work, noting, â€œItâ€™s important that we not tone our truth down for anyone.â€

â€œI felt the story for years emotionally, as I think most of us gay men have, and we just had to express it artistically,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™ve been pressured, threatened, forced, advised to do that our whole lives and it hasnâ€™t worked â€• itâ€™s left us with a ton of anxiety and loneliness.â€
Listen to â€œServing Bodyâ€ below.

otherData.headline: Mitt Romney Fails To Secure Utah Senate GOP Nomination, Will Face Primary
otherData.short_description: Romney fell short of getting the nod at the state's Republican Convention.

articleContent: Mitt Romney failed to secure the Utah Senate Republican nomination outright at a party gathering over the weekend and must run in a June 26 primary.

The 2012 GOP presidential nominee, who has been endorsed by President Donald Trump to replace retiring Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch, fell short of the 60 percent needed to clinch the nomination at the Utah Republican Convention and will face state Rep. Mike Kennedy in the primary.

Kennedy edged Romney in the vote among convention delegates, 51 percent to 49 percent, according to The Salt Lake Tribune. But the convention result is often a poor indicator of the preferences among the stateâ€™s Republican rank and file. In 2012, for example, Hatch similarly failed to clinch the nomination outright but went on to win his primary by 30 percentage points.
Romney sought to put a positive spin on the convention vote and the need for a primary.

â€œThis is terrific for the people of Utah, and I really want to thank the delegates who stayed so late to give me the kind of boost that I got here,â€ he said after the vote. â€œWeâ€™re going to have a good primary.â€
The former governor of Massachusetts long has had a home in Utah and is popular in the state. He remains expected to cruise to victory â€• both in the primary and the general election.

Although Romney accepted Trumpâ€™s endorsement, he had attacked him as a â€œphonyâ€ and â€œfraudâ€ during the 2016 presidential campaign. Romney was especially critical of Trumpâ€™s negative rhetoric about immigrants.
On Saturday, Romney said heâ€™s not ready to commit to endorsing Trump for re-election in 2020, calling that a decision he would make â€œdown the road.â€
â€œAs a person of political experience, if I endorse someone, Iâ€™ll want to know whatâ€™s in it for Utah and what help would he provide for us on key priorities in Utah,â€ Romney told CNN.
â€œSo Iâ€™m not a cheap date,â€ he added.

otherData.headline: For The First Time, Here Are Jerry Garcia's Earliest Known Recorded Performances
otherData.short_description: Way before the Grateful Dead, Garcia played a friend's birthday party. This is what it sounded like.

articleContent: Picture this: an 18-year-old Jerry Garcia strumming at a birthday party â€• before the Grateful Dead, before fame, before the â€œDeadheadsâ€ came to be.
Thatâ€™s what can be heard on â€œTrouble in Mindâ€ and â€œAll My Trialsâ€ â€• two previously unreleased recordings believed to be Garciaâ€™s earliest known recorded performances.

The tracks, premiering on HuffPost, feature Garcia and fellow singer/musician Robert Hunter playing at a 16th birthday party for their friend Brigid Meier in Menlo Park, California, on May 26, 1961. Meierâ€™s father worked at the Stanford Research Institute and had access to their Wollensak reel-to-reel tape recorder. So, he captured a young, pre-psychedelic Garcia exploring folk music for one of the first times in front of an audience.

â€œThe most remarkable thing about this is itâ€™s a very intimate group. Thereâ€™s probably about 10 or 15 people in the room,â€ author and historian Dennis McNally told HuffPost. â€œYou got an 18-year-old kid... He semi-talked his way out of the Army... He had played a little electric guitar at a pickup band in high school, and then had learned fingerpicking from a friend of his while in the Army.â€
â€œNot counting the high school stuff, youâ€™re like four months into his serious practice of a guitar,â€ he went on. â€œMostly he strums. But he does some fingerpicking.â€
Garcia, of course, would make a career out of music â€• playing in various groups and eventually forming the Grateful Dead in the San Francisco Bay Area amid the counterculture of the 1960s.

â€œAs you listen to this and as you listen to people listen to him, you realize that at 18, he had this presence. People were just glued to him,â€ McNally said. â€œEven at 18, people are just attracted to him as a presence.â€
The performance at Meierâ€™s party will appear on the upcoming box set â€œBefore the Deadâ€ â€• but weâ€™re premiering two of the tracks here first.
â€œAll My Trialsâ€ is a traditional song often associated with both the civil rights movement and Joan Baez, who included it on her debut album.
â€œTrouble in Mindâ€ is a popular eight-bar blues song written by the jazz pianist Richard M. Jones.
â€œBefore the Deadâ€ will be released as a four-CD set and a limited-edition five-LP collection on May 11.

otherData.headline: Last Known Person Born In The 19th Century Dies At Age 117
otherData.short_description: Nabi Tajima, born roughly 14 years before World War I began, was believed to be the world's oldest person.

articleContent: The worldâ€™s oldest known person, a Japanese woman, has died at the age of 117.

Nabi Tajima died in a hospital Saturday on her native Kikai Island, one of Japanâ€™s southernmost islands, located roughly 900 miles southeast of Tokyo, local media outlet Kyodo News reported. She had been hospitalized since January, according to the publication.
â€œShe passed away as if falling asleep,â€ Tajimaâ€™s 65-year-old grandson Hiroyuki told Kyodo News. â€œAs she had been a hard worker, I want to tell her â€˜rest well.â€™â€

Tajima reportedly had nine children â€• seven sons and two daughters â€• and at least 160 descendants. She claimed her secret to longevity was eating â€œdelicious foodâ€ and sleeping well, reported The Washington Post.

Born on Aug. 4, 1900, Tajima was the last known person born in the 19th century, which includes the years between Jan. 1, 1801 and Dec. 31, 1900. The same year she was born marked the second iteration of the modern Olympic Games. She was born roughly 14 years before the start of World War I and had just turned 45 when the U.S. dropped two atomic bombs on Japan during World War II.

Tajima was one of just 37 living supercentenarians â€• people who are at least 110 years old. Nearly half of the worldâ€™s remaining supercentenarians were born in and live in Japan, according to the Gerontology Research Group.

She inherited the title of oldest living person after Violet Brown of Jamaica died in September at the age of 117. Chiyo Miyako, another Japanese woman, has become the worldâ€™s oldest person, the research group reported.

otherData.headline: Sen. Bob Corker Not That Excited About The Leading Republican To Replace Him

articleContent: Retiring Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) could muster up only lukewarm praise for his partyâ€™s leading contender to replace him in Novemberâ€™s election, and again offered kind words for the main Democratic candidate.

otherData.headline: The GOP Has One Big Idea For Health Care Reform: Crappier Insurance
otherData.short_description: Republicans are busy bringing back junk plans, pre-existing condition exclusions and higher costs for the sick.

articleContent: The American health care system is an expensive, sprawling mess. The Republican Partyâ€™s brightest idea for how to fix it? Make health insurance worse.

Hereâ€™s what the GOP has in mind: Weakened protections for people with pre-existing conditions. Skimpier benefits that leave out coverage for important medical needs. Less protection from financial harm due to illness. And a number of actions designed to make the Affordable Care Actâ€™s exchanges less stable for the millions of Americans who use them.

GOP officials at the federal and state levels have proposed and undertaken a variety of new policies they say will make health insurance more affordable. During the seven-plus years between President Barack Obamaâ€™s signing of the health care reform law in 2010 and the collapse of the repeal attempt last year, President Donald Trump and congressional Republicans also promised over and over that they would repeal and replace the federal law with something better.
They didnâ€™t. It turns out thatâ€™s not because they didnâ€™t have any ideas. Itâ€™s because their best idea is â€¦ crappier health insurance.

If the only goal is to reduce monthly premiums, the GOP measures might sort of work for some people. Selling insurance products that are cheaper because they exclude the sick and leave policyholders with huge coverage gaps isnâ€™t a very impressive trick. Itâ€™s kind of like promising to make cars cheaper by selling them without transmissions and then declaring youâ€™ve solved the problem of auto affordability.

Itâ€™s true that some people could potentially access less-expensive insurance under the Trump administrationâ€™s deregulatory agenda. But those gains come with risks for the consumers. If you qualify for a health plan that screens based on pre-existing conditions or buy a policy with huge gaps in coverage, you might be left in the lurch when you really need care.

The risks are even greater for those who wonâ€™t have access to less-regulated insurance policies. People with illnesses or pre-existing conditions will face higher costs because theyâ€™ll be shut out of the cheaper options.

Moreover, segmenting the health insurance market between the healthy and the sick undermines the entire notion of insurance. Changing the rules to let insurers sell one set of policies to healthy people and another to those with pre-existing conditions and ongoing health care needs inevitably leads to the latter policies becoming costlier. And thatâ€™s not just a problem for those who are currently sick because everyone gets sick eventually, be it today or decades from now.
Here are nine ways Republicans in Washington and across the country are working together to make health insurance even worse.
1. Inaugural Executive Order

On his first day in office, Trump issued an executive order instructing the federal agencies responsible for the Affordable Care Act to find ways around it. This didnâ€™t have much impact in and of itself, but it set the stage for much of whatâ€™s come after.
2. Inessential Health Benefits

The Affordable Care Act requires health insurance plans to include 10 categories of benefits, including hospitalization, prescription drugs, maternity care and emergency-room services. Each state chooses an existing policy in its market as a â€œbenchmarkâ€ for these benefits.

This month, the Trump administration proposed a regulation that would let states select plans from other states as benchmarks or pick and choose elements of plans in another state â€• say, prescription coverage â€• and make those part of their own benchmark.

This is wonky stuff, but the notion behind it is to let states with a deregulatory bent allow the sale of plans with skimpier benefits and less financial protection than whatâ€™s on their local market now.
3. Not-So-Short Short-Term Plans

Health insurance plans intended to cover gaps in coverage â€• for example, when you start a new job but your health benefits donâ€™t kick in right away â€• have been around for a long time. Most of the Affordable Care Actâ€™s rules about benefits donâ€™t apply to them, and they donâ€™t have to cover pre-existing conditions. Typically, these policies had to be short-term, lasting only a few months. So the Trump administration came up with an idea: Let the bare-bones plans cover 364 days, essentially making them an alternative to yearlong policies.

The result will be a parallel insurance market for healthy people to buy bad coverage. And, again, the more healthy people not using the insurance exchanges, the worse it will be for everyone who still must, for they will see their premiums rise.
4. Associate Decree

Association health plans allow employers in the same field to band together to get a better deal on benefits for their workers. Think small companies that belong to the same trade group. Thatâ€™s all pretty reasonable, and this type of plan has existed for a while.

After the Affordable Care Act became law, the Obama administration determined that association health plans had to follow the same rules on benefits and pre-existing conditions as other types of insurance. Trump proposed a regulation this year to reverse that and let these plans ignore some of the lawâ€™s consumer protection standards.

Under Trumpâ€™s proposal, these plans could leave out a lot of key benefits, making their premiums lower. Thatâ€™s appealing to those who need coverage the least and unappealing to people who have to have medical care.

Still, cheaper insurance gets a lot more expensive if you try to use it and find out it doesnâ€™t cover what you need. Oh, and thereâ€™s a long track record of association health plans not paying claims and even defrauding their customers.
5. Idah-Oh-No
In January, Idaho Gov. C.L. â€œButchâ€ Otter (R) devised an interesting approach to the Affordable Care Act: Pretend it doesnâ€™t exist.

Otter issued an executive order inviting insurance companies to design health plans that, among other things, could charge people different rates based on their medical histories. This was so obviously a violation of the Affordable Care Act that even the Trump administration had to tell Idaho they couldnâ€™t do it. But in its rejection, the administration reminded state officials that its own efforts to undermine Obamacare made the Idaho plan redundant.
6. Iowanna Follow The Affordable Care Act

Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds (R) signed a law this month allowing insurance companies to sell policies through the Iowa Farm Bureau that also totally disregard the Affordable Care Act. How is Iowa ignoring the federal statute? It simply declared that this insurance is not insurance. No, really.

These farm bureau policies will be permitted to reject people with pre-existing conditions or at least charge them higher premiums. They wonâ€™t have to follow federal law governing what benefits must be covered. And insurers will once again be allowed to set hard-dollar limits on how much theyâ€™ll cover in a year or over a patientâ€™s lifetime. All of that is illegal under the Affordable Care Act.
7. Extra #Liberty

Congress passed a huge tax bill last year that, among other things, repealed the individual mandate, a central component of the Affordable Care Act that required most U.S. residents to obtain health coverage or face tax penalties. Starting in 2019, those penalties wonâ€™t exist anymore.

The mandate has always been unpopular â€• even 2008 presidential candidate Obama opposed it before taking office and changing his position â€• and it wonâ€™t be mourned by anyone but health insurance companies and some health care policy nerds.

But even though the mandate didnâ€™t work as well as the lawâ€™s authors expected, it served a purpose by nudging healthier people into buying insurance. That meant more money coming into the system to cover the costs of the less healthy. Thereâ€™s now one less reason for people to get covered. Combine that with the availability of those other types of plans that cater to the healthy, and it spells a sicker, more expensive mix of people on the exchanges. That will lead to higher costs for them.
8. The Check Isnâ€™t In The Mail
Trump threatened for months last year to cut off payments that the federal government owed insurance companies serving low-income Obamacare customers and, in October, he finally did it.

The Affordable Care Act requires insurers to provide discounts on out-of-pocket costs, like deductibles and copayments, to exchange customers with incomes below 250 percent of the federal poverty level, which amounts to about $30,000 for a single person. The government is supposed to pay the insurers back. Trump wonâ€™t.

This looked like it would throw the exchange markets into turmoil as insurers worried about financial losses would look to recoup them through enormous premium increases or even stop selling this kind of insurance at all.

Fortunately, that didnâ€™t happen because insurance companies and state regulators figured out a clever way to increase premiums only on subsidized products in most states. Because the value of the government subsidies rises with the price of the insurance, those consumers were mostly shielded from the higher premiums. But people who didnâ€™t qualify for financial assistance had to bear the full brunt. Plus, those higher subsidies cost the federal government a lot of money.
Still, it worked out better than many expected. So naturally, the administration is considering a ban on the solution that insurers and states came up with to protect subsidized consumers.
9. Listen All Yâ€™all, Itâ€™s A Sabotage
The open enrollment period for exchange customers last November and December was the first over which the Trump team had total control. They took advantage.

They cut the sign-up period in half. They cut the budget for enrollment assistance by 40 percent. They cut the advertising and outreach budget by 90 percent. They forbade federal employees from participating in local enrollment efforts. The Department of Health and Human Services even used money intended to promote enrollment on a public relations campaign advocating Affordable Care Act repeal.

Itâ€™s remarkable that this mix of less effort and higher costs didnâ€™t cause enrollment to plummet. Sign-ups did fall this year to 11.8 million, about 400,000 less than for 2017. But itâ€™s telling that the decline occurred almost entirely in the 39 states where the federal government runs the exchanges. Enrollment was flat in state-run exchanges in 11 states and the District of Columbia because they werenâ€™t affected by Trumpâ€™s budget cuts and because most held longer enrollment periods.

otherData.headline: NASA Releases Astounding Video Of The Lagoon Nebula To Celebrate Hubble's Birthday
otherData.short_description: The nebula is a "raucous star nursery full of birth and destruction," NASA says.

articleContent: Ever wanted to zoom near that central bulge in the Milky Way in the Sagittarius constellation where stars are born? NASA has almost made it possible thanks to the Earth-orbiting Hubble Space Telescope. As a kind of a 28th Hubble birthday gift for all of us, the space agency has posted astounding videos and photos of whatâ€™s known as the Lagoon Nebula.

The main video takes viewers from far away into the very heart of the massive, colorful nebula, what NASA calls a â€œraucous star nursery full of birth and destruction,â€ 4,000 light-years away from Earth.

At the Lagoon Nebulaâ€™s heart is a massive â€œyoungâ€ star (the million-year-old Hershel 36), 200,000 times brighter and eight times hotter than Earthâ€™s sun. It roils the region with ultraviolet radiation and winds carving out an exploding, undulating â€œfantasy landscape of ridges, cavities, and mountains of gas and dust,â€ gushes NASA.
The space agency has also released a video that dissolves to an infrared version that cuts through gas and dust to reveal a multitude of stars:
This is an imagined three-dimensional flight across the core of the Lagoon Nebula using images from Hubble:

Hubble was launched April 24, 1990, aboard the space shuttle Discovery and was a joint project of NASA and the European Space Agency. Once a year the telescope takes a break from its assigned observations to take a detailed image of a particular spot of the cosmos.

The Hubble â€œhas offered a new view of the universe and has reached and surpassed all expectations for a remarkable 28 years,â€ said NASA and the ESA. The telescope has â€œrevolutionized almost every area of observational astronomy.â€

otherData.headline: 9 Democrats Sign Up To Help Wall Street Steal Cars
otherData.short_description: They're backing a bill to undermine the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

articleContent: If an ordinary person committed any of the abuses listed in the Consumer Financial Protection Bureauâ€™s latest complaint against Wells Fargo, other ordinary people might call it â€œtheft,â€ or â€œcar theft.â€

Alas, Wells Fargo is only considered an ordinary person when it spends money on elections. The rest of the time, it is a too-big-to-fail bank, and improperly relieving its customers of their automobiles is just one of a few â€œunfair acts and practicesâ€ to which it neither admitted nor denied when it agreed to settle a federal investigation on Friday.
But the bank will pay a very high price for these alleged misdeeds â€• $1 billion, the highest the CFPB has ever imposed against a financial institution.

The CFPBâ€™s description of Wells Fargoâ€™s behavior is breathtaking. The company â€œforcibly placed duplicative or unnecessary insurance on hundreds of thousandsâ€ of vehicles owned by customers who had taken out a car loan with the bank. This not only resulted in a typical charge of â€œover $1,000â€ to which these customers had never agreed, but â€œfor at least 27,000 customers,â€ the bureau wrote, â€œthe additional costs of the Force-Placed Insurance could have contributed to a default that resulted in the repossession of their vehicle.â€

In a better world, the Federal Reserve would prevent serial offender banks like Wells Fargo from existing, and the Department of Justice would prosecute mass car theft as a crime. But it is at least good that a federal regulator exists to levy fines against these outrages and give restitution to wronged families. The CFPB has only been around a few years, but prior to the Wells Fargo settlement, it had returned about $12 billion in ill-gotten gains to American consumers â€• a figure that is considerably higher after its biggest-ever settlement.

The bureau is a creation of the Democratic Party, signed into law by President Barack Obama and designed by Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.). Yet some congressional Democrats are joining Republicans supporting legislation that consumer advocates say would strip the CFPB of the power to bring cases like the one it just settled with Wells Fargo.

The bill, authored by one of the bureauâ€™s most ferocious critics, Rep. Sean Duffy (R-Wis.), has the backing of self-styled progressives, such as Rep. Gwen Moore (D-Wis.) and Sen. Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.), along with six more conservative House Democrats and Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.).

The legislation would deny the CFPB jurisdiction over companies that are subject to state insurance regulation that also engage in â€œoffering or providing a consumer financial product or service.â€ For such firms, which include essentially every major bank, the bureau would lose its authority â€œto the extent such [company] is engaged in the business of insurance.â€ State insurance regulators, which have a much weaker record of consumer protection enforcement, would replace the CFPB.

In January, the progressive advocacy group Americans for Financial Reform sent a sharply worded letter to members of Congress warning that the bill â€strikes a major blow against CFPB regulatory authority over large financial services firmsâ€ that â€œwould have called into question the CFPBâ€™s ability to investigate and punish the Wells Fargo scheme to sell unnecessary insurance to its auto credit customers.â€

A month earlier, 20 organizations, including the National Fair Housing Alliance, the National Consumer Law Center and the Consumer Federation of America, cited the Wells Fargo case as they brought their concerns to Duffy. Not only do state regulators have a weak record of enforcement, many states simply do not have effective consumer protection laws on the books.

â€œIn the weeks before the disclosure that Wells Fargo had falsely placed 800,000 lender-placed auto policies, state insurance regulators ... [claimed] there were purportedly no problems in that market,â€ the groups wrote.

Manchin and Moore have a long history of supporting bank-friendly legislation at the expense of American families, and both declined to comment for this article. A Baldwin spokesperson insisted that the bill doesnâ€™t actually do anything.

â€œThis legislation does not strip or change the agencyâ€™s authority to enforce compliance when an insurer offers CFPB-covered products,â€ Baldwinâ€™s staffer said. â€œThe bill simply clarifies that the CFPBâ€™s role is to enforce consumer protection laws and also reaffirms existing law on state-based regulation of insurance by State Insurance Offices and Commissioners. CFPB retains the oversight authority being used in its enforcement action against Wells Fargo, which Senator Baldwin has strongly supported.â€

Robert Hunter, director of insurance at the Consumer Federation of America, doesnâ€™t agree. He describes the language as â€œvery expansive,â€ with the potential to undermine enforcement against a vast array of abuses perpetrated by financial conglomerates. Birnie Birnbaum, executive director of the Center for Economic Justice, called the bill â€œoutrageous.â€

â€With the exception of a few states, the record of state regulators on this is terrible,â€ Birnbaum told HuffPost. â€œWells Fargo force-placed some 800,000 policies erroneously. No insurance regulator caught that.â€

The language of the bill is broad and vague, leaving a tremendous amount of activity susceptible to court challenge if the CFPB were to act against insurance providers. And it includes a provision stating that, when in doubt, â€œthe enforcement of this title shall be broadly construed in favor of the authority of a state insurance regulatorâ€ over the CFPB.

The bill passed the House Financial Services Committee in January by a vote of 37 to 18, with seven Democrats voting in favor: David Scott (Ga.); Emanuel Cleaver (Mo.); Gwen Moore (Wis.); Ed Perlmutter (Colo.); Kyrsten Sinema (Ariz.); Joyce Beatty (Ohio); and Josh Gottheimer (N.J.). It has yet to receive a floor vote in either chamber.
Clarification: One reference in this story has been amended to accurately indicate the total number of Democrats who backed the bill in question.

â€œIf the decision comes from President Trump to officially withdraw from the deal, then Iran will take decisions that have been provided for under the [agreement] ... as the United States has a habit of saying, â€˜all options are on the table,â€™â€ The countryâ€™s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said in an interviews on CBSâ€™s â€œFace the Nationâ€ Sunday.

The Iran nuclear deal was President Barack Obamaâ€™s signature foreign policy achievement and is therefore, not surprisingly, reviled by Trump. During the presidential campaign, he called it â€œthe highest level of incompetence.â€

Trump, so far, has not pulled out of the deal, but he has given himself a May 12 deadline to either waive sanctions against Iran, as outlined in the deal, or to leave it. Five other countries â€• the U.K., Russia, France, China and Germany â€• are also parties to the agreement.
Zarif said the United States would suffer a serious blow to its international standing if it doesnâ€™t hold up its end of the bargain because it would show that the country canâ€™t be trusted.

â€œIt will lead to U.S. isolation in the international community,â€ Zarif said. â€œThe reason that President Trump has not withdrawn from the deal over the past 15 months, in spite of the fact that he did not like the deal, has been the fact that everybody has advised the administration that this is not a bilateral agreement between Iran and the United States, and withdrawing from it would be seen by the international community as an indication that the United States is not a reliable partner.â€
â€œIt would not be pleasant for the United States â€• the reaction of the international community, and as I said Iran has many options and those options are not pleasant,â€ he added.â€

Providing relief for Iran from crippling economic sanctions is central to the deal. In return, Iran promised to halt its nuclear program. But Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin said that even if Trump refuses to waive the sanctions for Iran next month, that somehow doesnâ€™t necessarily mean the deal will collapse.

Another option, as Trump sees it, is to renegotiate the terms of the deal. The administration may try to get its European allies to at least commit to changing the deal over the time, in return for the United States sticking with it.

Britain, France and Germany are looking at imposing new European sanctions on Iran over its ballistic missiles program and its role in the Syrian conflict in an attempt to keep Trump from pulling out.
On Sunday, Zarif said that any such side agreement between the other nations would be unacceptable to Iran.

â€œWhat is important is for the Europeans to bring the United States into compliance because Iran has been in compliance with the deal,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s been the United States that has failed to comply ... President Trump has made it very clear that it is trying to dissuade our economic partners from engaging with Iran and thatâ€™s a clear violation of the deal.â€

Trump recently nominated Mike Pompeo, who was serving as his CIA director, to be his new secretary of state. Pompeo is expected to be more in line with Trump on Iran than was his predecessor, Rex Tillerson. He recently said he wanted to â€œfixâ€ the nuclear agreement.

International experts, as well as U.S. national security officials, have said Iran is complying with the deal â€• even though it continues to pursue other policies that the U.S. administration believes pose a threat.
Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.), chair of the Foreign Relations Committee, said he expects that Trump will pull out of the deal, unless something changes.

â€œI do think if nothing changes with the three European members weâ€™re dealing with right now on a framework,â€ Corker said on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Weekâ€ Sunday, â€œI do think he will move away from the agreement on May 12.â€

otherData.headline: Trump Considering 'Full Pardon' Of Late Boxing Champion Jack Johnson
otherData.short_description: Johnson, the first black heavyweight champion, was arrested for driving his girlfriend across state lines.

articleContent: President Donald Trump is considering pardoning the late heavyweight champion boxer Jack Johnson thanks to actor Sylvester Stallone.
The president tweeted about the potential posthumous pardon on Saturday, saying Stallone called him to tell him the story of the legendary boxer.
Johnsonâ€™s â€œtrials and tribulations were great, his life complex and controversial,â€ Trump said, adding, â€œYes, I am considering a Full Pardon!â€
The White House did not immediately return HuffPostâ€™s request for comment and representatives for Stallone declined to comment on Trumpâ€™s tweet.

Johnson, whose parents were former slaves, made history in the early 20th century as the first black man to earn the title of heavyweight boxing champion of the world. A powerhouse in the ring, Johnson rose in fame and wealth throughout his career â€• even at a time when vicious violence against African Americans was the norm.

The boxerâ€™s image was controversially smeared when he was convicted of violating the Mann Act, which banned traveling with a woman across state lines for an â€œimmoral purpose.â€ Johnson fled the country, continuing his boxing career overseas for years before he eventually surrendered to federal authorities and served time in prison.
In 1946, he died in a car crash.

Officials had initially refused to give Johnson a chance at the heavyweight title (African Americans were not allowed to participate at the time) until 1908, when Johnson faced off with champion Canadian Tommy Burns, according to â€œThe Boxing Register: International Boxing Hall of Fame Official Record Book.â€
Johnson won against Burns with a technical knockout in the 14th round, becoming the first black heavyweight champion. His fame, however, still didnâ€™t earn him respect from his white peers.
Lawmakers, including Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), have asked past presidents to posthumously pardon Johnson for years. McCain has supported a pardon for Johnson since 2004.

In a 2016 letter to President Barack Obama, McCain, the now-retired Sen. Harry Reid (D-Nev.), Rep. Pete King (R-N.Y.) and Rep. Gregory Meeks (D-N.Y.) called Johnsonâ€™s conviction â€œimproper and unfair,â€ claiming that Johnson was â€œtransporting his white girlfriend across state lines.â€

â€œWhile it is unfortunate that this unjust conviction was not corrected during the boxerâ€™s lifetime, a posthumous pardon today represents the opportunity to reaffirm Jack Johnsonâ€™s substantial contributions to our society and right this historical wrong,â€ the lawmakers wrote.
The U.S. Commission on Civil Rights also urged Obama to pardon champion boxer that same year.
Johnson â€œwas a fierce critic of Jim Crow laws and the prevailing enforced customs of racial segregation,â€ the commission wrote in a June 2016 letter.
Rep. King urged Trump to absolve Johnson on Saturday, tweeting, â€œObama wouldnâ€™t do it. Trump ... now considering it. Would correct a terrible injustice.â€
In an interview with the Los Angeles Times earlier this year, Johnsonâ€™s great-great niece Linda E. Haywood suggested that a posthumous pardon would allow Johnsonâ€™s past to be corrected.
â€œKnowing that he was treated unfairly, and unfairly convicted and targeted because of his choice of companions, who happened to be Caucasian, thatâ€™s wrong,â€ Haywood told the Times.
â€œThe last thing you want to do is die and have your name tarnished. Thatâ€™s wrong. You donâ€™t want it to be tarnished if youâ€™re living.â€
CORRECTION: A previous version of this story misidentified Tommy Burns as Australian. He was Canadian.

otherData.headline: The Tiny Soccer Club Fighting For Survival Against A New York Investment Fund
otherData.authors: Angus Harrison, On assignment for HuffPost
otherData.short_description: Evicted from its stadium, Dulwich Hamlet, a 125-year-old soccer club with strong community ties, is standing firm.

articleContent: SOUTH LONDON, U.K. â€• Cut grass prickles under the rising heat as the first waves of coaches and players mill around the dugout. Itâ€™s the latest home game that tiny South London soccer team Dulwich Hamlet has been forced to play away from Champion Hill, the ground itâ€™s called home since 1912.
The mid-April match, against Thurrock F.C., takes place at the home field of local rivals Tooting and Mitcham and is some nine miles from Dulwich.

The clubâ€™s displacement is due to a rift between Southwark, the local council, and a multinational property development firm Meadow Residential, an affiliate of New York City-based property fund Meadow Partners, which owns Champion Hill and wishes to knock down the current stadium to build apartments.

At the start of March, when Southwark Council rejected Meadow Residentialâ€™s proposal for a $112 million-plus apartment development on the site â€• partly for its failure to meet rules on providing a set percentage of affordable housing â€• the company evicted the 125-year-old club. One of Meadow Residentialâ€™s subsidiaries even went as far as to trademark â€œDulwich Hamletâ€ and send a letter to the club demanding it cease to use its own name (the company has since withdrawn the demand).

Meadow has filed new proposals that include building a new stadium for the club on public land next to the development, but the club says it would be much smaller and not fit for a soccer team that regularly draws crowds of 1,500.

Yet Dulwich Hamlet, despite its size, has refused to capitulate, mounting an unprecedented fight back thatâ€™s won mainstream media support, the backing of leading British politicians and even garnered interest from ex-England international star Rio Ferdinand. Strong community ties and the unique network of personalities that make up its team and supporters are keeping Dulwich Hamlet alive.

The clubâ€™s manager, Gavin Rose, played for Dulwich Hamlet 16 years ago and returned as a manager nine seasons ago after working at a handful of other clubs. He has tried to protect his players from the clubâ€™s difficulties, but media attention and moving grounds have made that difficult. â€œThere are a lot of boys who have come through the academy at various times, so theyâ€™ve got a lot of trust in us,â€ he explained.

Thurrock F.C., Dulwich Hamletâ€™s opponents, will cease to exist at the end of the season due to its chairmanâ€™s ill health, and Dulwich Hamlet has offered the visiting fans free entry to the game. Club closures are not unusual in the world of non-league soccer â€“ which floats below the big money top leagues in the U.K. and is a mixture of amateur and semi-professional soccer â€“ a sad fact that makes Dulwich Hamletâ€™s resolve all the more impressive.

Rose attributed the clubâ€™s resilience to its place within the community, specifically its initiatives to reach the â€œforgotten parts of society,â€ as he put it. â€œThat sort of spirit is probably what has stood us in good stead when weâ€™ve had our own battles to face.â€

Mishi Morath, who has supported Dulwich Hamlet since 1974, is the clubâ€™s community officer, and responsible for many of these initiatives. Growing up in a public housing block behind the ground, he was 7 years old when he watched his first game. â€œOnce you pick your local team, youâ€™re stuck with them,â€ he shrugged, masking his affection.

Under his watch, the club has worked with local schools and youth groups, run trade union days, raised funds towards the Syrian refugee crisis, organized collections for local food banks, supported local living wage campaigns and played a landmark friendly against Stonewall FC, Britainâ€™s premier gay football team, with all money from ticket sales going to the Elton John Aids Foundation. However, these efforts have come to a halt due to the teamâ€™s current challenges.

â€œNot being at [our ground] means we havenâ€™t got a community, our community has got to travel to us,â€ Morath stewed, one eye on the game. â€œNot just that, but East Dulwich [the local neighborhood] is feeling it as well. Without the crowds weâ€™ve built up over recent years, the local pubs have had to lay off staff on Saturdays.â€ He attributed Meadow Residentialâ€™s conduct to pure pettiness â€• â€œthe kid in the playground taking the football away so nobody else can play.â€

Meadow Residential did not respond to HuffPostâ€™s emails or calls asking for comment. The companyâ€™s website says it has supported Dulwich Hamlet to the tune of just over $1 million, but has been â€œunable to financially support the Clubâ€ while the dispute with Southwark Council over the development continues.

Tom Cullen â€• a content producer and social media strategist â€• came to the club in 2013. After taking over Dulwich Hamletâ€™s online presence in 2016, he was soon invited to become a committee member, going on to become the director the following year. It was during his tenure that relations with Meadow Residential broke down. Heâ€™s spent the past six months working pro bono, alongside Rose and fellow board member Liam Hickey, to keep Dulwich Hamlet afloat.

Cullen sees the fight as an opportunity for Dulwich Hamlet to set a political precedent. â€œThis isnâ€™t just about us,â€ he insisted. â€œWe want to spearhead change to legislation so that other clubs know what to do.â€

The Save Dulwich Hamlet campaign has attracted the attention of London Mayor Sadiq Khan, along with Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn. Cullen credits the clubâ€™s unique following for its continued survival.

â€œ[Meadow] could have picked any other club in the country at our level or below and gotten away with it, frankly,â€ Cullen said. He is optimistic that a corner has been turned in the battle to save Champion Hill â€• with heavyweight political backing, he believes Dulwich Hamlet will be back home within two years.
Itâ€™s a sentiment shared by Hugo Greenhalgh and Ben Sibley â€• the faces behind â€œForward the Hamlet,â€ an irreverent podcast and Twitter account.

Greenhalgh and Sibley also sense a sea-change in the clubâ€™s fortunes, pinpointing a recent Friday when Helen Hayes, member of Parliament for Dulwich and West Norwood, raised the clubâ€™s plight in the House of Commons â€• a motion that resulted in Tracey Crouch, the minister for sport, promising the involvement of an independent mediator should negotiations with Meadow Residential fail. â€œ[Hayes] finished this powerful speech by saying â€™Forward the Hamlet,â€™â€ Greenhalgh explained, beaming.
â€œI lost my shit,â€ Sibley added.

Greenhalgh and Sibley represent the new wave of fans contributing to the clubâ€™s boom in popularity in recent years â€• young creatives drawn to a different sort of football in the capital. This has led some to write off Dulwich Hamlet as a â€œhipster club,â€ but itâ€™s a caricature that fails to recognize its rich heritage.

During the match, weâ€™re introduced to people who have been with the club for decades, like volunteer turnstile operator Paul Griffin and Jack McInroy, unofficial club historian, who leans on the far corner pitch barrier to share his personal collection of old shirts and newspaper clippings. Dulwich Hamletâ€™s roots are deep and speak to the vacuum that would be left in its absence.

In the seats of the main terrace sits 98-year-old Bill Kirby. Heâ€™s supported the Hamlet since 1932, and has always lived within a mile of Champion Hill. His memories of the teamâ€™s interwar heyday are vivid. He recalls average crowds of 10,000, special trains to ferry supporters to local derbies in Wimbledon or Kingston, and drinking shandy from the amateur cup in 1937. â€œTo be honest, I wasnâ€™t 18,â€ he whispers, confessing he hadnâ€™t reached the legal drinking age, â€œbut I went home pissed that night.â€

In its match against a dogged Thurrock F.C. on April 14, Dulwich Hamlet scraped its way to a 2-1 victory, keeping the team in the mix for promotion at the end of the season. The fight is far from over, but hope is in the air.

articleContent: NEWNAN, Ga. â€” A heavily militarized police force of some 400 officers aggressively patrolled a small neo-Nazi rally in this city 40 miles southwest of Atlanta on Saturday and arrested about 10 counterprotesters, many for the crime of wearing a mask.

Police officers arrived before the rally began and approached a group of about 50 anti-fascist protesters. They demanded the protesters remove their masks or face arrest. The officers â€” who wore bulletproof vests and helmets, and carried semi-automatic rifles â€” cornered the anti-fascist protesters, then grabbed those who were still masked, tossing them to the ground and handcuffing them.
At one point, an officer pointed what seemed to be a modified AR-15 at the faces of counterprotesters, none of whom appeared to be armed.

The lead officer in the arrests said the counterprotesters were breaking a state law regarding masks, likely referring to a seldom-enforced 1951 law originally aimed at combating hooded Ku Klux Klan members. Anti-fascist protesters â€• many belonging to chapters of antifa groups, known for sometimes violently confronting white supremacists â€• often wear masks to avoid being identified by both law enforcement and neo-Nazis.

â€œThe irony of enforcing masking laws to prosecute leftists is just incredible,â€ said Molly, a counterprotester from Charlottesville, Virginia, who traveled to Georgia to protest neo-Nazis. She asked that her last name not be published for fear of retribution. â€œThose are anti-Klan statutes.â€
â€œAnd to be roughing up anti-Nazi protesters while handling literal Nazis with kid gloves... itâ€™s absurd,â€ added Molly, who said she saw one of her friends get arrested Saturday.

The rally in Newnan was the latest, and one of the most pitifully attended, neo-Nazi events to be held in the South since the deadly â€œUnite The Rightâ€ rally in Charlottesville last August, when a neo-Nazi drove his car into a crowd of anti-fascist protesters, killing one person and injuring 19 others.

Certain seemingly innocuous items, including balloons, were not allowed at the rally. But Georgia has an open carry gun law, so people could bring their weapons; HuffPost saw one neo-Nazi and one anti-fascist protester carrying semi-automatic rifles.

The Newnan rally was organized by the National Socialist Movement, an older neo-Nazi group that favors explicit Third Reich iconography over the more coded racist memes of the so-called alt-right. Fewer than 30 NSM members, along with a small contingent of the white supremacist group League of the South, showed up for the event.
The city granted NSM a permit to hold the rally at Greenville Street Park, and security and police presence for the event is expected to cost taxpayers thousands of dollars.

NSM members arrived about an hour late for their rally. Then they stood on a stage in the park, looking out over hundreds of counterprotesters yelling from behind a fence some 100 yards away as police helicopters and drones circled overhead.

Jeff Schoep, the so-called commander of the NSM, rambled about the need to keep Confederate statues. He referred to himself and his companions as â€œAlpha malesâ€ and complained about men who look like â€œhomosexualsâ€ by wearing skinny jeans. He also lashed out against the â€œZionist mediaâ€ for portraying NSM as a hate group.
NSM members flanking him threw up Nazi salutes.

Schoep then left the stage to address a gaggle of reporters. When asked by HuffPost about NSM members throwing up Nazi salutes, Schoep claimed they were actually â€œRoman salutes.â€ He then threatened to have HuffPost removed from the park for being â€œdisrespectful.â€

At 5 p.m. local time, less than an hour after the rally had started, police appeared to pull the plug on the sound system. An officer speaking into a megaphone issued a dispersal order, warning the neo-Nazis that they would be arrested if they didnâ€™t leave the park. They left without incident.

The paltry NSM showing was indicative of the gradually diminishing strength of the so-called alt-right since the Charlottesville rally last year. That rally, the largest of its kind of over a decade, was attended by upwards of 1,000 white supremacists.

Since then, alt-right figurehead Richard Spencer canceled a planned campus speaking tour after being humiliated by anti-fascist protesters at the University of Florida and Michigan State University. Last month, a domestic dispute precipitated the collapse of neo-Nazi group the Traditionalist Workers Party. Infighting has also severely fractured the rest of the alt-right.

NSM and League of the South now appear to be the white supremacist groups most willing to hold rallies. On Friday night, they held a meeting at a bar in Bremen, Georgia. The annual gathering is typically held on or near April 20, the birthday of Adolf Hitler.
There were times on Saturday when Newnan looked as if it was under military occupation. Armored vehicles and heavily armed officers, some in military fatigues, patrolled the streets.

Ahead of the event, Newnan Police Chief D.L. â€œBusterâ€ Meadows appeared to draw an equivalency between the racist and anti-Semitic neo-Nazis â€” who argue for creating a white ethnostate in America â€” and the anti-fascists showing up to protest them.
â€œNeither one of these groups represent who we are and what we stand for,â€ he told local news outlet The Newnan Times-Herald.
It was a sentiment shared by some of the other 39,000 residents of Newnan, a town whose city square is home to two monuments exalting the Confederate Army.

Jeff Nelms, a Newnan resident who works as a millwright, went to a friendâ€™s gun shop Saturday to make sure no one vandalized the store during the dayâ€™s chaos. He called both the neo-Nazis and the anti-fascists â€œscum.â€

Julio Gilgorri, 26, who has lived in Newnan for five years, had a different take on the anti-fascists arriving to drown out the neo-Nazis. Gilgorri was among hundreds of residents who attended a festival in the city square on Friday night, at which local businesses, churches and charities handed out #NewnanStrong T-shirts. Children drew chalk hearts and rainbows on the sidewalks, while adults wrote messages like â€œNazis suck.â€

â€œNewnan has taken me in as a Hispanic American and someone whoâ€™s looking for a new home. I felt accepted since the moment I stepped foot here,â€ Gilgorri said. â€œIf we shut up and stay quiet and allow these guys to rally without any opposition, my opportunity might not happen for other people down the line.â€

â€œIâ€™m absolutely glad that people are coming to be heard because, at the end of the day, there truly are more voices on our side than theirs,â€ he added. â€œHistory has already shown whoâ€™s right here.â€

America does not do a good job of tracking incidents of hate and bias. We need your help to create a database of such incidents across the country, so we all know whatâ€™s going on. Tell us your story.

articleContent: Four young protesters and a police officer were killed in increasingly violent clashes over social security cuts in Nicaragua, Associated Press reported Friday.

Protests began Wednesday after a new law was signed increasing tax contributions and cutting pension income in the social security system. Some demonstrations began peacefully, with protesters waving placards and chanting, â€œViva Nicaragua libre!â€ (â€œLong live a free Nicaragua!â€)

But in some areas, pro-government forces clashed with protesters, police lobbed tear gas and fired rubber bullets from behind shields, and buildings were set afire. A police officer and protester were fatally shot on Thursday in Nicaraguaâ€™s capital, Managua, where thousands took to the streets, and another protester was shot dead in Tipitapa, northeast of the capital, the Red Cross told Reuters.
AP reported that two protesting university students were killed on Friday.

One eyewitness reported on Twitter that five buildings, among them the National Lottery in LeÃ³n and the student center at the National Autonomous University of Nicaragua, were burning Friday afternoon. Protests had reportedly spread to at least 10 cities.
Lisseth Guido, a spokeswoman for the Red Cross of Nicaragua, told Reuters on Friday that 48 people were treated for various injuries.

The government shut down most main news sources other than La Prensa, a protester who asked her name to be withheld told HuffPost. La Prensa was reporting that police were switching from rubber bullets to live ammunition.

The United Nationsâ€™ human rights office urged the government in a statement to â€œfulfill its international obligations to ensure people can freely exercise their rights to freedom of expression and freedom of peaceful gathering and association.â€

The protester, who works for a local nongovernmental organization, said that demonstrations began peacefully but violence erupted in clashes with pro-government protesters and security forces. She said the protests have been â€œflashingâ€ across the country and are largely organized on social media.

â€œThis is spread nationwide ... itâ€™s young people going out to the street protesting, especially students, protesting against these reforms. And each time itâ€™s been a peaceful protest. [But when] theyâ€™ve been met with the pro-government movement, they have been violent,â€ she said.

The protester told HuffPost she was protesting with a group Friday in Nindiri, outside of Masaya in western Nicaragua, when a group of pro-government protesters appeared armed with flash or stun grenades and confronted them. When a leader of the protest against the social security changes declared â€œItâ€™s our right to protest peacefully,â€ someone â€œcame up and pushed this guy on the ground, and he hit his head and started to bleed,â€ she recounted.
Security forces have seized vehicles carrying provisions for protesters, and invaded an area near Managuaâ€™s Metropolitan Cathedral where the church had been collecting donations.

The protests are the largest to hit Nicaragua in the 11-year presidency of onetime Sandinista guerrilla Daniel Ortega, who was also president in the 1980s. The country erupted in the wake of the new law, which the government insists is necessary to protect the survival of the social security system. Ortega has yet to comment on the protests, La Prensa reported.

Though the change in the social security law was the trigger for the protests, discontent has been growing over a variety of issues. Critics complain that Ortega has betrayed the Sandinista principles with a power grab and crackdown on dissidents, and blamed government ineptness and even alleged corruption for the failure to effectively fight a massive fire in a protected tropical forest earlier this month.

â€œThe protests are a consequence of years of unsatisfied demands and growing repression and censorship to dissident groups,â€ Manuel Orozco, senior fellow at the Inter-American Dialogue think tank in Washington, D.C., told The New York Times.
The protester said that â€œpeople are just wanting to be heardâ€ and they want social program changes to â€œbe repealed and evaluated to be more equitable.â€

On a â€œdeeper level, [we want] government change, but we donâ€™t even have a proper opposition,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s just individual people coming out on the street. I come from a Sandinista family, my friends come from Sandinista families; we no longer consider ourselves part of the party. It doesnâ€™t matter what party people are from, they just want change.â€
