articleContent: Indiana now lets DACA recipients apply for professional licenses. â€œDreamersâ€ have thrived for two years in Nebraska with a similar policy.
By Matt Vasilogambros

OMAHA, Neb. â€” Dania Cervantes Ayala is the kind of nurse you want when you receive a life-changing diagnosis. Itâ€™s not a task for her, it feels personal. She cares for patients at her part-time job at the Nebraska Medicineâ€™s Buffett Cancer Center with both sharp knowledge and deep compassion â€” traits of a skilled third-year nursing student at the College of Saint Mary who will soon take the stateâ€™s nursing license exams and move on to a doctorate of nursing program.
Sheâ€™s part of the future of nursing in eastern Nebraska. She was also brought to this country illegally in 2003 when she was 6 years old.

Up until two years ago, Cervantes Ayala, who is from Mexico, would not have been allowed to become a nurse in her state because of her immigration status. In Nebraska she, along with nearly 3,400 other â€œDreamersâ€ â€” named after the DREAM Act, which never passed in Congress â€” could not apply for or receive professional or commercial licenses. That changed with the enacting of a 2016 state law, and has since led to a wave of young people becoming lawyers, nurses, cosmetologists, accountants and dozens of other licensed professionals.

â€œIâ€™m finally comfortable in my own skin,â€ said Cervantes Ayala, who often looks back on her parentsâ€™ perilous journey across the border. â€œItâ€™s like everything that we have worked hard for is finally paying off. Weâ€™re out of the shadows.â€

Nebraska is one of 10 states that allow certain immigrants â€” such as Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) recipients, legal immigrants and unauthorized immigrants â€” to apply for professional licenses, which often require Social Security numbers. In many of those states, the door is only open for specific professions, such as for teachers in Nevada and lawyers in Florida.

Last month, Indiana lawmakers enacted a law similar to Nebraskaâ€™s, becoming the latest state to give young undocumented immigrants a chance at an advanced career in a country theyâ€™ve always called home. Republican Gov. Eric Holcomb said the stateâ€™s DACA recipients should be allowed â€œto skill up and work here in Indiana.â€
Nebraska, like Indiana, is a conservative state. But the debate two years ago defied partisan norms on immigration and already has had an impact on DACA recipients.
The Long Fight in Nebraska

Alejandra Ayotitlaâ€™s voice still quivers when the Dreamer, who crossed the Mexican border as a 9-year-old in 2004, thinks back to the moment Nebraska enacted a law that would allow her to one day pursue a legal career.

A week before the measure became law in 2016, Pete Ricketts, the stateâ€™s Republican governor, vetoed the bill supported overwhelmingly by lawmakers of his own party, citing a concern it was unfair to immigrants who came to the country legally. The chamber of the unicameral Legislature was silent as senators cast the final vote to override the governorâ€™s veto.

When the votes were in, the bill had 31 supporters â€” one more than was needed to override the veto. As someone in the chamber gallery full of Dreamers erupted in applause, most of the senators turned, stood up and returned applause back to the dozens of young people they had gotten to know over the many years it took to get to this moment.
â€œIt was really powerful,â€ Ayotitla said. â€œI have no words to describe it.â€

The enthusiastic passage of the Nebraska law that gave undocumented immigrants with work authorization, including DACA recipients, a chance at getting professional licenses is a far cry from some of the anti-immigrant measures state leaders enacted just seven years earlier.

In 2009, the state enacted a law that took away many public benefits, including professional, commercial and driverâ€™s licenses, from undocumented immigrants. Then-Gov. Dave Heineman said the law would ensure â€œthat state and local benefits go to those who truly qualify.â€

Three years later, Heineman, a Republican, spoke vehemently against the Obama administrationâ€™s DACA program, which allowed those who were brought to the country illegally as children to work legally, while members of the Legislature tried to pass an Arizona-style â€œshow me your papersâ€ bill.
But as that was happening, support for changes to immigration policy was building in the state â€” not just among activists, but also among business leaders.
Dreamers Won the Argument

That support continues. Nebraska needs workers, said Jennifer Creager, the senior director of public policy for the Greater Omaha Chamber, in an interview. Like many rural states, Nebraska is exporting too many of its young people to sustain a statewide workforce, she said. With an unemployment rate of 2.8 percent and some 50,000 job openings across the state, immigration is a â€œpure workforce issueâ€ for Creager and other business people. The new law could allow more Nebraska Dreamers to help fill the gap.

â€œIt makes absolutely no sense to educate kids here, to put state resources into them with public schools and higher education, to basically train them to work, and then say we donâ€™t want them to work here or pay taxes here,â€ she said. â€œNot only do we want you. We need you.â€

Those same economic arguments are what drove business leaders such as Jim Partington, the executive director of the Nebraska Restaurant Association, to form a coalition to study immigration in Nebraska, a state with an aging and declining population. Between 2011 and 2015, nearly 12,000 Nebraskans 25 and older with at least a bachelorâ€™s degree were leaving the state every year. Meanwhile, Nebraskans 65 and older are expected to increase by 75 percent between 2010 and 2030, according to the AARP.

The restaurant group, along with the Nebraska Cattlemenâ€™s Association and other industry groups, soon became some of the loudest voices pushing the state Legislature to remove barriers for immigrants in state law. Those barriers, such as being the last state in the country to not allow DACA recipients to receive driverâ€™s licenses, were in direct conflict with state officialsâ€™ economic goals, Partington said. (The Legislature gave DACA recipients the ability to get driverâ€™s licenses after overriding a Ricketts veto in 2015.)

â€œI donâ€™t think you can meet these people and then take a position that we want to deport them,â€ Partington said. â€œTheyâ€™re so valuable to have here. Theyâ€™re teachers. Theyâ€™re accountants. Some of them are studying to become lawyers. Theyâ€™ve got a great future ahead of them.â€

Ultimately, it was meeting students such as Ayotitla that inspired lawmakers to make a final push, said Darcy Tromanhauser, the director of the immigrants and communities program at Nebraska Appleseed, a Lincoln-based advocacy group. Many of the DACA recipients grew up in small, rural communities across the state, such as the majority-Latino towns of Schuyler and Lexington, and the young people wanted to give back and become the next generation of skilled professionals in those areas.

â€œSenators felt like they got to know youth, and care personally,â€ Tromanhauser said. â€œThereâ€™s a lot more community support that is playing out that is wildly different than the national dialogue would make you think.â€

Since the law was enacted, advocates at Nebraska Appleseed said they are unaware of any snags in its implementation, and they have not heard of any applicants being denied because of their status as DACA recipients. Administrative offices across the state were prepped and ready for new DACA applicants the day after the policy went into effect, Tromanhauser said.

Officials at the Nebraska Department of Labor said they do not track the number of DACA recipients who have applied for professional and commercial licenses. To be sure, Tromanhauser and other advocates said there is no easy way of measuring how many DACA recipients have taken advantage of the new policy, but countless stories of Dreamers applying for new licenses continue to pour into their offices.

According to the Migration Policy Institute, across the country, 9,000 DACA recipients are teachers, 14,000 are health care practitioners and in health care support roles, and 2,200 are financial specialists â€” roles that may require the Dreamers to hold a professional license.
In New York, one of the states that allows teachers to receive certifications, around 700 DACA recipients are in the education field, according to MPI.

Many more DACA recipients are studying to become skilled workers. Almost 17 percent of DACA recipients are pursuing an advanced degree, according to a 2015 survey by the National Immigration Law Center and the Center for American Progress. Further, more than 50 medical schools now consider applications from DACA recipients nationwide, according to the law center.
Ayotitla even decided to change her career path from becoming a school psychologist to becoming a lawyer because of this fight. She starts at the Nebraska College of Law in the fall.
Confusion Around DACA

More than 80 state organizations and local leaders â€” from chambers of commerce to mayors â€” have publicly supported the deferred action program since the license law was enacted, said Omaid Zabih, the federal policy director at Nebraska Appleseed. Just after President Donald Trump was inaugurated, the state Legislature passed a resolution in support of the program.

â€œI look at it as one very powerful moment in an ongoing movement,â€ Zabih said of the license law. â€œThat didnâ€™t happen in a vacuum. It built momentum for what we want, which is common sense immigration reform.â€
Ricketts, however, has publicly agreed with Trumpâ€™s decision to end the â€œunconstitutionalâ€ program.

Still, Washingtonâ€™s confusion over whether DACA recipients, who have only temporary protection from deportation, have a future in the country, including congressional inaction, remains a worry for young Nebraskans like Armando Becerril.

Becerril came to the country flying through the air. When he and his family got to a fence at the U.S. border in 1997 in the pouring rain, soaked and muddy with only the clothes on their backs, his uncle threw the then-4-year-old over the barrier into California. His mother, father and uncle hopped the fence too.

Over the next two decades, Becerril and his family settled in and created a life here. When people ask him where heâ€™s from, he always says York, Nebraska â€” the town of 8,000 where his father worked as a meatpacker. Growing up, he excelled at school, and numbers especially came naturally to him. â€œThey were my thing,â€ he said.
When college rolled around, Becerril received both undergraduate and graduate degrees in accounting at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. He still doesnâ€™t miss a Husker football game.

Now working at the Omaha office of prestigious international tax and auditing firm KPMG, the DACA recipient is six months away from finishing his certified public accountant exams. Two years ago, he couldnâ€™t have become a CPA in Nebraska.

But he may soon lose his protected status, as Congress and Trump have failed to come to an agreement on the program that expired in March, but has continued indefinitely while a federal court considers its legality.
â€œI donâ€™t know how things are going to unfold with DACA,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™re talking about everything I worked for for years. It could have been a waste.â€

Unlike other DACA recipients in Nebraska, however, Becerril has options. His firm, knowing his status, has offered to employ him in the companyâ€™s Mexico City office if he is deported. He says heâ€™s luckier than most. But he still wants to live in his home state.

â€œWeâ€™re positive, contributing members of this society,â€ Becerril said. â€œIf weâ€™re forced to leave, this country is going to lose a lot more than if they provide us this opportunity that we earned.â€

According to The Washington Post, Trayon White Sr., a member of the D.C. Council, and his staff made several unusual observations about the exhibitions. Then, White abruptly left, citing an event he had to attend, only to be spotted later on the sidewalk outside the museum.

During his time inside, White pointed to an image of Nazi stormtroopers surrounding a woman who was wearing a sign that read: â€œI am a German girl and allowed myself to be defiled by a Jew.â€ He asked Lynn Williams, the museumâ€™s director of leadership programs, if the stormtroopers were â€œprotecting her.â€

â€œI think theyâ€™re humiliating her,â€ Williams explained, per the Post.

â€œMan, it just started snowing out of nowhere this morning, man. otherData.headline: Lance Armstrong Settles $100 Million Federal Fraud Case For $5 Million
otherData.short_description: The former cycling champion was accused of defrauding his sponsor, the U.S. Postal Service, by using performance-enhancing drugs.

articleContent: (Reuters) - Former cycling champion Lance Armstrong on Thursday agreed to pay $5 million to settle a federal suit claiming he defrauded his sponsor, the U.S. Postal Service, by using performance-enhancing drugs, his attorney and federal officials said.

The settlement ends the long-running false claims suit brought by fellow cyclist Floyd Landis and joined by the U.S. government, which had sought $100 million in damages on behalf of the Post Office, according to statements from Armstrongâ€™s attorney, Elliot Peters, and the U.S. Department of Justice.

â€œNo one is above the law,â€ Acting Assistant Attorney General for the Justice Departmentâ€™s Civil Division Chad Readler said in a statement. â€œThis settlement demonstrates that those who cheat the government will be held accountable.â€

By phone, Peters told Reuters that he thinks the Postal Service realized it could not prove damages to it caused by Armstrongâ€™s behavior. He said the settlement was reached ahead of a scheduled May 7 trial date.
Armstrong, who is now 46 and lives in Austin, Texas, won the biggest race in professional cycling, the Tour de France, a record seven times, six of them while riding for the Postal Service team.

He was stripped of his titles and banned for life from the sport in 2012 by the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency after it accused him in a report of engineering one of the most sophisticated doping schemes in sports. Armstrong admitted to the cheating in a January 2013 televised interview with Oprah Winfrey.
This is the last legal matter related to Armstrongâ€™s doping, Peters said.

â€œIâ€™m looking forward to devoting myself to the many great things in my life â€• my five kids, my wife, my podcast, several exciting writing and film projects, my work as a cancer survivor, and my passion for sports and competition,â€ Armstrong said in a statement provided by Peters.

The settlement also calls for Armstrong to pay $1.65 million for the court costs of his former teammate Landis, who also used performance-enhancing drugs and who was stripped of his 2006 Tour de France championship.

Landis originally brought the lawsuit in 2010 under a federal law, the False Claims Act, that lets whistle-blowers pursue fraud cases on behalf of the government, and obtain rewards if successful. Landis will receive $1.1 million as his share of the settlement.
The Justice Department joined the case in February 2013 after Amstrongâ€™s public confession.

otherData.headline: California Lawmakers Consider Bill That Treats Conversion Therapy Like Consumer Fraud

articleContent: California lawmakers are considering a bill that would make selling or advertising gay conversion therapy a violation of the stateâ€™s consumer fraud laws.

The state Assembly passed Bill 2943 on Thursday. The legislation, which targets the practice of trying to change a personâ€™s sexual orientation, now heads to the state Senate. If enacted, the bill would make â€œadvertising, offering to engage in, or engaging in sexual orientation change effortsâ€ to the list of fraudulent business practices already banned in California.
Assemblyman Evan Low, a leader of the legislatureâ€™s LGBT Caucus, proposed the bill.

â€œThis is a very personal issue to me,â€ Low said before the vote on the Assembly floor. â€œThis notion that we would accept as a legal practice that conversion therapy works is antithetical to my very existence in this body.â€

Major mental health associations have thoroughly discredited conversion therapy. The American Psychological Association has said that attempts to change sexual orientation through therapy have â€œserious potential to harm young people.â€

A 2012 law already bars mental health providers from attempting conversion therapy on minors, The Associated Press reported. Lowâ€™s bill seeks to offer consumer protections to adults who accuse people of defrauding them by advertising sexual orientation change efforts.

Several Republican Assembly members were concerned that the bill would infringe upon the right to freedom of religion. They cited the ability of churches to sell books about conversion therapy, for example, or invite a therapist to speak about the subject at a church event.
â€œThis is a bill that would be overturned by a higher court on the grounds of the First Amendment,â€ Assemblyman Matthew Harper, a Republican, said.

Low said that the bill is limited to conversion therapy offered as a service in exchange for monetary compensation. He said it would not prevent people from speaking or writing on the subject, and it would not apply to the sale of books.

â€œYou can still try to pray the gay away if youâ€™d like, but it hasnâ€™t proved to be effective,â€ said Assemblywoman Susan Talamantes Eggman, a Democrat who supports the bill. â€œTo advertise that you can change someoneâ€™s orientation is simply that â€” fraudulent.â€

The bill has the support of the American Academy of Pediatrics, the California Psychological Association, and civil rights groups like the Human Rights Campaign. Conservative religious rights groups, such as the California Family Council and the Alliance Defending Freedom, are opposing the legislation.

Low told Californiaâ€™s Assembly members on Thursday that he too had wondered if he could change his sexual orientation as a teenager. He said he ultimately suffered from depression and experienced suicidal thoughts.

â€œGrowing up with so much hate, I too wanted to find out if I could be changed and if anything could work because of the societal pressures that we have,â€ he said during an emotional speech on the floor. â€œThere is nothing wrong with me. There is nothing that needs to be changed.â€

articleContent: Actress Natalie Portman has pulled out of accepting a prestigious award in Israel because she said her conscience prevented her from doing so, the Genesis Prize Foundation said.

The Jerusalem-born â€œBlack Swanâ€ actress was scheduled to accept the Genesis Prize, a so-called Jewish Nobel, in June, but the Genesis Prize Foundation said in a news release on Thursday that a rep for Portman explained the Oscar winner would not attend because of â€œrecent events in Israel.â€

The foundation quoted Portmanâ€™s rep as saying that â€œrecent events in Israel have been extremely distressingâ€ to the actress, and that â€œshe cannot in good conscience move forward with the ceremony.â€
Portman later posted her own statement:
The prize was established in 2013 to honor those who inspire Jewish values. Former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, actor Michael Douglas and violinist Itzhak Perlman are among its winners.
The foundation said it respected Portmanâ€™s right to disagree with the policies of the Israeli government, but was saddened that political reasons would prevent her participation.
â€œWe fear that Ms. Portmanâ€™s decision will cause our philanthropic initiative to be politicized, something we have worked hard for the past five years to avoid,â€ the foundation said.

Portmanâ€™s announcement follows Israelâ€™s response to demonstrations along the Gaza border this month, killing dozens of Palestinians. Portman, who said she was proud of her Israeli roots and Jewish heritage after hearing in November that she would receive the prize, has been critical of Netanyahu.
This article has been updated to include Portmanâ€™s statement.

otherData.headline: No, Hours Of Raging, Deadly Prison Violence Is Not Normal
otherData.short_description: Violence that killed seven inmates in a South Carolina prison could have been prevented, prison experts say.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• The violence that left seven inmates dead and a score more injured in a South Carolina prison this week was inevitable, Henry McMaster, the stateâ€™s Republican governor, suggested Monday. â€œItâ€™s not a surprise when we have violent events take place inside the prison, any prison in the country,â€ he said.

In fact, a night of unchecked prison violence that ends in more than a half-dozen deaths is extremely unusual. States have a responsibility to protect inmates and prison staffâ€”and well-funded, properly staffed prisons can and do prevent widespread inmate violence or stop it swiftly when it occurs, prison experts say.

Lee Correctional Institution, the high-security prison where inmate fights broke out on April 15, houses violent offenders with longer sentences, as well as people with behavioral issues. The incidents started around 7:15 p.m., but a large emergency response team didnâ€™t enter the first of three dorms until 11:30 p.m., officials said. The team entered the last dorm hours later.

CBS News obtained leaked video (not independently verified) that shows what McMaster apparently finds unsurprising: An eerie dystopia featuring an inmate smearing blood against a white wall and another roaming shirtless with a weapon that resembles a kitchen knife.

This is not a typical prison scene. As far as the death toll goes, the most recent comparable event was an 11-day riotâ€”in which inmates took multiple hostagesâ€”that left nine inmates and one officer dead in an Ohio prison way back in 1993.

Prison violence â€œshouldnâ€™t be an expectation,â€ said Robert Ayers, who worked at Californiaâ€™s San Quentin State Prison from 1968 to 1987 and went on to serve as the warden at four California prisons. â€œItâ€™s almost, â€˜well, seven people died, but they were just inmates, and these are violent guys anyway ... so itâ€™s no big loss to society.â€™ Thatâ€™s extrapolating a lot, but I think thereâ€™s an undercurrent out there that believes that.â€

People need to be asking questions of the governorâ€™s office and the legislature, said Anthony Newland, a former warden of California State Prison Solano and former chief compliance officer for that state prison system. â€œItâ€™s no surprise that this kind of problem can happen â€” when there isnâ€™t enough money to run the system,â€ Newland argued. â€œThese things are preventable in prisons,â€ he added.
Prisons need to have enough staff to keep inmates and officers safe

Lee Correctional Institution has an understaffing problem. Security staff numbers continued to â€œlag behind the authorized strength [like officers],â€ according to a FY2017 South Carolina Department of Corrections report. On April 1, 2017, there were 90 vacancies for frontline security positions at Lee â€” approximately half the facilityâ€™s authorized positions, a state DOC spokesman told HuffPost. Those numbers have improved due to recruitment and retention effortsâ€”the number of vacancies was down to 52 as of April 1, 2018.

But a former Lee employee, who worked there from 2004 to 2012 and declined to be named due to pending litigation, said he still found those staffing numbers concerning. â€œYou have to have a certain number of bodies in a certain number of places or you canâ€™t operate normally,â€ the former employee said.

Crises are the result of an inadequately funded prison system, one Democratic lawmaker argued. â€œYes, stuff happens â€” stuff happens because you neglect things, you underfund them, and you put people in danger,â€ said state Rep. Todd Rutherford (D). He said that he doesnâ€™t blame the current DOC director, whoâ€™s been â€œsounding the alarm bells about how understaffed and underfunded he is, how bad the prisons are, how hard his correctional officers are working.â€

South Carolina has had a large number of violent inmate deaths in recent years compared to other states. When there arenâ€™t enough officersâ€”or people like mental health professionals and maintenance staffâ€”staff may fear for their safety, and that in turn can allow violence to flourish. â€œI donâ€™t blame the officers for what happened,â€ the mother of a Lee inmate told the Anderson Independent Mail. â€œMy son says the gang members do what they want to. That they will pull out shanks right in front of the guards.â€

Itâ€™s impossible to talk about understaffing without mentioning the nationwide push to reform mandatory minimum sentences and end mass incarceration in the U.S., issues that contribute to spiraling, problematic prison systems that disproportionately impact people of color.

McMasterâ€™s office did not respond to HuffPost requests for comment. But â€œthe governor is committed to continuing to fund raises at the agency and will continue to do that as long as the agency is in need,â€ a spokesman for the governor told NBC News. (South Carolinaâ€™s average starting salary for officers this year was $33,289, according to NBC.)
Cellphones: Potentially a symptom of a bigger problem

Officials have blamed the violence on gang conflicts over territory and contraband, particularly cellphones, which can be used to coordinate illegal activity. Officials are using the incident to push for signal-jamming at prisons.

But contraband is not a new issue, nor unique to South Carolina. And cellphones can be a symptom of wider security problems, prison experts say. (A prison can be fully staffed and still have security problems, though substantial understaffing makes things worse.) When staff canâ€™t adequately sweep for forbidden items, an economy can spring up that includes weapons. Some inmates may also feel like they need gang protection because they donâ€™t feel safe in the facility.

â€œCellphones did not stab people,â€ said Justin Bamberg, a state representative and attorney who represents the family of an inmate killed in a different state prison on New Yearâ€™s Eve. â€œWhat did were some of those [multi]-inch blades.â€

When thereâ€™s severe understaffing, youâ€™re â€œnot going to enforce simple rules and regulations, much less more serious stuff,â€ the former Lee employee said. â€œYouâ€™re going to stay somewhere itâ€™s safe, which is like a staff area in the middle of the unit, where you donâ€™t see and you donâ€™t hear. And who can blame them?â€

Staff â€œroutinelyâ€ search correctional institutions for contraband, the South Carolina DOC spokesman told HuffPost, though he declined to provide more information about routines, citing security. The agency is installing netting at certain facilities to thwart people from throwing over contraband, he said.
This photo shows a man covered in blood sitting against a wall as another man approaches him during the prison riot.
Why did it take hours to get control of the dorms?

Lee conducts monthly emergency training, the DOC spokesman said, and there are three teams with specialized training that assisted in responding to the violence. Lee is located in a rural area, about an hour from Columbia, which may have increased the time it took to gather sufficient numbers of staff to respond to the crisis.

But experts have wondered how the violence was able to spread unchecked to multiple dorms, rather than the facility being swiftly secured. Itâ€™s also concerning how long it reportedly took an emergency team to re-enter and take control of the areas under siege, Jeffrey Schwartz, a consultant who has worked with correctional agencies and law enforcement for more than 30 years, told HuffPost. â€œWhether itâ€™s staff or inmates,â€ he said, â€œyour commitment to saving life has to be the same.â€
And thatâ€™s why prison reform advocates find the governorâ€™s statement so troublingâ€” it suggests prison is supposed to be a violent place.

The incident is â€œmore than just a tragedy,â€ a group of state Democratic lawmakers wrote to McMaster on Thursday. â€œWe are concerned it is indicative of much bigger problems within correctional facilities in South Carolina.â€
â€œI was hurt. I wept. Because these were lives that were snuffed out,â€ James Murray, a former inmate who now is a chaplain for South Carolina prisoners, told local news station ABC Columbia.
â€œWeâ€™ve been tough on crime,â€ he added. â€œBut actually, weâ€™ve been tough on people.â€

One inmateâ€™s brother reflected on the violence at Lee in an op-ed for the Charlotte Observer. â€œSmall indignities add up,â€ Issac Bailey wrote. â€œYet some officials feign surprise when those treated inhumanely behave in inhumane ways.â€

otherData.headline: Exclusive: 'Everyday Guy' Describes How He Brought Down An American Terrorist Cell
otherData.short_description: Dan Day -- a gun-toting Kansan -- felt a "calling from God" to work with the FBI to prevent militiamen's attack on Muslim refugees.

articleContent: WICHITA, Kan. â€• Three anti-Muslim domestic terrorists who plotted to blow up a Garden City apartment complex where many Somali Muslim immigrants lived were convicted on Wednesday on federal charges that could send them to prison for life. Five weeks into the trial, jurors deliberated for less than a full day before finding Kansas militiamen Patrick Stein, Curtis Allen and Gavin Wright guilty on all charges.
But it wasnâ€™t just the trio on trial.

So too was Dan Day, the FBI informant whose hours of recordings â€• which featured vile discussions of planned violence against Muslims, who the men called â€œcockroachesâ€ â€• were the centerpiece of the federal governmentâ€™s case against a group that dubbed themselves â€œThe Crusaders.â€

Dayâ€™s testimony was at the center of the trial. Federal prosecutors would not have had a case without him. Defense attorneys said the plot would never have moved forward were it not for Day pushing the group to action.

The two sides offered up competing portraits of the 49-year-old Day in court. The government portrayed him as an â€œeveryday guy,â€ a patriot and a hero who risked his life and stepped up to prevent a looming attack that would have killed countless men, women and children because of their faith, race and national origin. Defense attorneys said Day was an unemployed wannabe who jumped at the chance to become an undercover FBI informant and was willing to do whatever the federal government needed for a check.

In an exclusive interview with HuffPost, Day said itâ€™s a relief to put this experience behind him. â€œItâ€™s just so hard to believe this actually happened,â€ he said. Heâ€™s glad â€œjustice was servedâ€ in the case, and thinks divine intervention led to his involvement, he added.

â€œI felt like it was a calling from God, honestly,â€ Day said of taking the risk of becoming an informant. â€œIâ€™m not an over-religious person, but I believe in God and I believe he put me there at the right time, the right place, if that makes any sense.â€

The father of two high school-age children and the youngest of 14 kids, Day grew up in Garden City, Kansas, home to the apartment complex the defendants ultimately targeted. Up until a few years ago, he worked as a probation officer and in juvenile detention before that.
His path to becoming an informant for the FBI is completely unique.

It began in July of 2015 with a trip to the local library with his son. He saw what he considered an anti-Israel poster, which featured a Palestinian flag and described the situation in Israel as apartheid. He tore it down.
â€œThey have the right to put that up, and I have the right to take that down, in my opinion, so I did,â€ Day said of the incident.
Then he passed along a photo of the poster to a friend who eventually posted about it on Facebook. The post went viral.

Day was soon invited to a cookout attended by a number of members of a militia group in Kansas. Somewhere along the line the story got mixed up, and people in the militia believed that Day had found an ISIS recruiting poster. That wasnâ€™t the case at all.

But the FBI, which was looking into rumors of the ISIS poster, interviewed Day and ended up being interested in him because of his connection to the militia. It wasnâ€™t long before Day was working on the bureauâ€™s behalf, giving the federal government an inside look at the larger militia group.
Then Day met the defendants. The difference between them and the larger group, federal prosecutors said, was that the defendants werenâ€™t just talking â€• they were ready to take action.

Kansas-based Assistant U.S. Attorney Tony Mattivi, who prosecuted the case alongside two prosecutors from the Justice Departmentâ€™s Civil Rights Division, told jurors that Day was an â€œaverage guyâ€ who stepped up at the right moment to stop men who wanted to â€œblow up a bomb, flatten the building and murder every single man, woman and child inside.â€

Day could have walked away, like the other members of the larger militia group who knew a plan was in motion but did nothing to stop it, Mattivi said. â€œThat guyâ€™s a patriot. Heâ€™s a hero,â€ he added.

Defense attorneys saw it differently. They accused the federal government of overreaching and said the case wouldnâ€™t have gone anywhere if it hadnâ€™t been for Dayâ€™s involvement. They frequently mentioned that Day was working for the FBI before he ever came into contact with the defendants.
â€œThe FBI owns Dan Day and they own the words that he said,â€ argued Melody Brannon, the top federal public defender in Kansas who was representing Allen.

Day said the defenseâ€™s attacks on him were unfair and only happened because defense attorneys couldnâ€™t dispute what the defendants said in the tapes he recorded. â€œThey had to attack me, and they had to attack the FBI,â€ he said. â€œI put my whole life out there so they could knock me down.â€™â€
But Day said he was also uncomfortable with the prosecutionâ€™s glowing depiction of his role. â€œIâ€™m no hero, man, believe me,â€ he said. â€œIâ€™m not a perfect person, but Iâ€™m truthful.â€

Working in remote areas of Kansas, there was no backup team standing by when Day attended meetings with the militiamen. He had a phone that was constantly recording in the background that even he couldnâ€™t turn off.
It was scary at times, Day said. He noted he was armed, and â€œwouldâ€™ve did what [he] had to doâ€ if he was discovered.

Being undercover, observing and participating as the men spewed Islamophobic rhetoric, Day said the defense attorneys and the media overplayed the influence that President Donald Trumpâ€™s anti-Muslim remarks had on the defendants. He called it a â€œTrump cardâ€ used as an excuse for the militiaâ€™s behavior.

â€œThese guys had a hate in their heart towards all Muslims, long before Trump came along in the picture,â€ said Day, who described himself as â€œanti-Hillaryâ€ and said he would have voted for Trump had he not been preoccupied with the case right before the 2016 election.
Still, Day said he would have liked Trump to have toned down some of his more extreme rhetoric about Muslims.

â€œTrump should not have ever said those things. I donâ€™t agree with him saying that, you know?â€ he said. â€œRegular Muslims, if they come over and theyâ€™re vetted, thatâ€™s our country, man. Thatâ€™s a free country. Thatâ€™s how my grandparents got here.â€
Day, like a lot of Americans, said he personally hasnâ€™t had much interaction with Muslims. He said he had concerns about radical Islam, but said he â€œnever had a bad viewâ€ of Muslims as a whole.

Itâ€™s rare for the federal government to deploy informants and undercover officers in terrorism stings against non-Muslim defendants. The Interceptâ€™s Trial and Terror project identified 310 terrorism sting operations that involved international terrorism, meaning groups like the self-described Islamic State.

Most of the high-profile cases typically involved young Muslim men who became the focus of FBI investigations because of what theyâ€™d written online. Those cases primarily resulted in material support charges unavailable in cases against domestic extremists.

Day said he doesnâ€™t know whatâ€™s next for him. As defense attorneys noted, heâ€™ll probably get a conviction bonus from the FBI for his work on the case, in addition to the more than $30,000 he has already received. He wouldâ€™ve made more money working a regular job, he said, and heâ€™ll start looking for one soon.

He said he found some of the defenseâ€™s comments in closing arguments to be laughable. Stein was compared to a â€œchild playing at warâ€ who had a â€œwillingness to believe the fantasticalâ€ and an â€œinflated sense of self.â€ Wright was portrayed as someone who just wanted to fit in and thought Day was his friend.
Day said it was particularly ridiculous that Wrightâ€™s attorney brought up the defendantâ€™s parentsâ€™ divorce more than 35 years ago, when Wright was 14.
â€œCome on, man,â€ Day said. â€œGive him a puppy, I donâ€™t know.â€

Day added that he doesnâ€™t want to sound like heâ€™s overly happy about what happened to the defendants and that heâ€™s particularly conscious of the effect their convictions will have on their families. But he doesnâ€™t have much sympathy for the defendants themselves, who he said had plenty of opportunities to back away from the plot.
â€œIâ€™d tell them fuck off,â€ Day said. â€œThey made their choices.â€

otherData.headline: Coroner Reclassifies A Man's Suspicious Death After HuffPost Investigates
otherData.short_description: An incarcerated woman said that she and her partner were involved in Shawn Arthur's death.

articleContent: NEW ORLEANS â€• The death certificate for Shawn Arthur, a man who died after meeting a woman through a dating app, has been changed from â€œaccidentalâ€ to â€œundetermined.â€
While the reclassification might eventually push the case into a courtroom, itâ€™s not sitting well with Arthurâ€™s father, who wanted it changed to â€œhomicide.â€
â€œI am truly disappointed, but not totally surprised,â€ Bob Arthur, 69, told HuffPost. â€œObviously the investigative facts were ignored or twisted.â€
The change in classification comes two weeks after HuffPost detailed what 27-year-old Dominique Berry said about what really happened to Shawn Arthur.

A Louisiana native with a lengthy criminal record, Berry claims that she and her partner, 36-year-old Randy Schenck, drugged Shawn Arthur so they could steal his belongings in late February 2017. When the 40-year-old was found dead in his apartment shortly afterward, his death was labeled â€œaccidental,â€ despite compelling evidence suggesting foul play.

The issue with the revised death classification is that â€œundeterminedâ€ still encompasses accidental, natural or homicide. It basically means there is no one theory that outweighs the others regarding the cause and manner of a personâ€™s death.
A homicide classification would have required only that the coronerâ€™s office find that Arthurâ€™s death resulted from a deliberate act by another person, not necessarily with an intent to kill.

Berryâ€™s account, along with other evidence uncovered by HuffPost and two private investigators working for the Arthur family â€“ Michelle Gomez and Jane Holmes â€“ was among the materials examined last week by the Jefferson Parish Coronerâ€™s Office. The evidence, which prompted the involvement of federal authorities, shows how Berry and Schenck allegedly targeted men on dating apps in at least six states. Berry estimated that she and her partner, who are behind bars in Georgia in connection with another case, victimized up to 100 men.

Dr. Marianna Eserman, the forensic pathologist who performed the original autopsy, and other members of the coronerâ€™s office were among those to sit down and review the Arthur case last week. The Arthur familyâ€™s attorney, Michael Kennedy, said he was not permitted to attend the meeting.

In a Tuesday statement to Kennedy, Eserman said the review of the case was complete and it was determined that Arthurâ€™s death did not meet the criteria to be ruled a homicide. The pathologist said that while Berry had admitted to drugging men, sheâ€™d never said that â€œshe remembers Shawn Arthur or his apartment.â€

Yet prior to the meeting, Kennedy had provided Eserman with copies of three interviews in which Berry discussed the Arthur case. Among them was a Feb. 27 interview with HuffPost, in which Berry acknowledged going to Arthurâ€™s apartment.
â€œI just called him and went to his house,â€ Berry said of her interactions with Arthur after they connected on a dating app.
Berry not only admitted drugging Arthur, but also claimed she was at his apartment when he passed out.
â€œHe was snoring very loudly,â€ she recalled.
Kennedy said he is â€œoutright angryâ€ that the coronerâ€™s office is claiming they cannot place Berry at the crime scene â€• especially since police already have.
â€œHer fucking fingerprint was found there, so she was obviously there,â€ Kennedy told HuffPost.

Eserman gave HuffPost a different explanation as to why the case could not be reclassified a homicide. â€œWe have no definitive proof under what circumstances Mr. Arthur ingested medications and alcohol,â€ she said in a Thursday email.
Eserman said Berryâ€™s interviews were reviewed, but she did not respond to a follow-up email that pointed to specific statements Berry had made about drugging Arthur.

In her interview with HuffPost, Berry said sheâ€™d first attempted to drug Arthur by mixing a cocktail of prescription drugs with liquor. She said that attempt failed when the drugs did not completely dissolve and wound up stuck to the bottom of the glass.
â€œHe didnâ€™t drink it because there was like the ones that was still stuck in the cup,â€ Berry said.
The sheriffâ€™s report indicates a shot glass with an unknown substance was found during a search of Arthurâ€™s apartment.

In a Feb. 15 interview with Holmes, one of the private investigators, Berry said she found it was easier to mix the drugs with beer. Empty beer bottles were found in Arthurâ€™s apartment, along with several pill capsules in which Berry had allegedly concealed the drugs.
â€œOf course, I drugged him,â€ Berry told Holmes. â€œI gave him two capsules of pills, then I took him to the bed, laid him down, massaged him and relaxed him, and he fell asleep.â€
Berry told HuffPost that generally after drugging a victim, sheâ€™d encourage the individual to consume large quantities of alcohol.
â€œWhen they drink half a bottle of beer, thatâ€™s when you put the pill in because it wonâ€™t fizz over,â€ she said. â€œThen Iâ€™ll do like a chug game or something like that.â€

Several alleged victims of Berry and Schenck told HuffPost that they have no memory of what happened from the time they consumed an allegedly spiked drink until they woke up hours later, with a bad hangover.

Dr. Gerry Cvitanovich, the Jefferson Parish coroner, did not respond to a request for comment Thursday as to whether Eserman, who is married to a detective who worked on the case, should have performed the autopsy and been involved in the case review.
The relationship between the pathologist and the detective should have been disclosed to his family, Bob Arthur contends. He said he was unaware of it until he reviewed the investigative documents.

â€œMrs. Eserman should have never been the person leading on the response regarding the new information on the case,â€ Bob Arthur said. â€œThere is clearly a conflict of interest on her part along with her husband, Sgt. Travis Eserman. There is always a possibility that Mrs. Esermanâ€™s response was written to protect her husband and the other detectives for their shoddy investigation.â€
The Jefferson Parish Sheriffâ€™s Office, which reopened the investigation into Shawn Arthurâ€™s death after HuffPost started raising questions, did not respond to a request for comment.

Whether the reclassification of Arthurâ€™s death will have any impact on the Jefferson Parish District Attorneyâ€™s Office is yet to be seen. A spokesman for the office declined to comment on the case.
Kennedy said he plans to reach out to each of the relevant agencies to raise questions about the reclassification of Arthurâ€™s death.

â€œWe feel strongly that this is a homicide and will be working to provide additional information to the coroner to have that change made,â€ Kennedy said. â€œIn the meantime, it is our hope the Jefferson Parish Sheriffâ€™s Office will take notice and look more closely at the case, so we can get justice for Shawn.â€

otherData.headline: Michelle Williams Gives The Kookiest Performance Of Her Career In 'I Feel Pretty'
otherData.short_description: How a baby-doll voice, NPR, a puppy dress and Ivanka Trump's hair led to this tour de force.

articleContent: At one point in â€œI Feel Pretty,â€ after the newly emboldened protagonist, Renee Bennett (Amy Schumer), has landed her dream job as a receptionist at a haughty cosmetics company, she is in the cafeteria when the couture-clad CEO, Avery LeClair (Michelle Williams), spots her. Bosses at bustling beauty enterprises are, the average story goes, bloodthirsty. Avery, on other hand, is thirsty for an understanding of how normal people â€• ones whose grandmothers arenâ€™t the namesake of an imperious brand â€• live their lives.
Naturally, thatâ€™s something of a struggle for someone whose privilege butts up against her eccentricities. â€œI thought I smelled animal products,â€ she meows upon seeing Renee.

If an actor is fortunate, at some point sheâ€™ll give a performance so unlike anything weâ€™ve ever seen her do that itâ€™s downright startling. This week, Michelle Williams is that actor. Even though Williamsâ€™ first lead in a movie was playing an airheaded teenager who inadvertently exposes Richard Nixonâ€™s Watergate break-in in the 1999 satire â€œDick,â€ sheâ€™s since matured into a so-called serious actress with indie clout and four Oscar nominations to her name â€• a fact that makes her bonkers work in â€œI Feel Prettyâ€ all the more delicious. Itâ€™s the type of role thatâ€™s only memorable coming from an established performer, especially one known for dramatic heft like â€œBrokeback Mountain,â€ â€œBlue Valentineâ€ and â€œManchester by the Sea.â€

Maybe your jaw will drop as low as mine did upon first hearing Williams speak in â€œI Feel Pretty,â€ which opens this weekend. Instead of the velvety innocence that usually accents her on-screen persona, Williams speaks with what co-directors Abby Kohn and Marc Silverstein call â€œhigh-pitched vocal fry.â€ Itâ€™s an odd confluence of Valley Girl lilt, enunciated baby-speak and spacey stonerisms, further underscored because the character actually fits none of those attributes. Avery, we learn, has an MBA from Wharton and clerked for a Supreme Court justice before taking a leadership post at Lily LeClair.

Coupled with the bamboozled but relentlessly relaxed aura Williams brings to the film, Averyâ€™s flat cadence skirts the dragon-lady stereotype that defines the high-powered fashionistas portrayed by Meryl Streep in â€œThe Devil Wears Pradaâ€ and Tilda Swinton in â€œTrainwreck.â€ She carries herself with the weight of a feather, gliding along as if oblivious to her surroundings at all times.

Kohn and SIlverstein, longtime creative partners who also penned â€œNever Been Kissedâ€ and â€œHeâ€™s Just Not That Into You,â€ had written Averyâ€™s intonation into their script, but they had no idea what Williams would do with it until a couple of weeks before she arrived on set. Williams sent Kohn and Silverstein an NPR story from 2015 about a woman incapable of feeling fear. The womanâ€™s speech, which sounds almost identical to the voice Jenny Slate created for the adorable stop-motion creation Marcel the Shell, was Williamsâ€™ inspiration, though the results were still a work in progress when she tested it for Kohn and Silverstein over the phone. They didnâ€™t hear the final version until they went to Williamsâ€™ trailer on her first day shooting the movie.
â€œTruthfully, the thing she did for us on the day in the trailer was not like anything weâ€™d talked about before,â€ Silverstein said. â€œIt was so much better.â€
â€œWe were like, â€˜Can you sustain it? How is it to do a voice like that?â€™â€ Kohn recalled. â€œShe was like, â€™Yes, I got it. I can do it. Itâ€™s part of the whole thing.â€™â€

Averyâ€™s wardrobe completes the â€œwhole thing.â€ Costume designer Debra McGuire, who was attracted to â€œI Feel Prettyâ€ because its empowerment message works in opposition to the â€œtight, sexyâ€ clothing she felt obligated to use while working on â€œFriendsâ€ in the â€™90s, based Averyâ€™s grandmother (Lauren Hutton) on a cosmetics guru she once knew who dressed head to toe in Chanel. With that in mind, McGuire wanted Avery to put a â€œfunâ€ twist on high-end fashion, bringing a California ease to the officeâ€™s cutthroat New York setting.

Furthermore, Avery and the self-effacing Renee needed to work as complements, not foils Ã  la Streep and Anne Hathaway in â€œThe Devil Wears Prada.â€ When Renee falls off a SoulCycle bike and knocks her head, her feelings of unworthiness vanish. Convinced she is suddenly thinner and more conventionally beautiful â€• â€œModeling is an option for me,â€ she later tells Avery and her colleague (Naomi Campbell) â€• Renee encounters a series of contrivances that ultimately lead her to realize she got the job (and a boyfriend) without actually shapeshifting or altering her appearance.

Normally, McGuire would have designed Averyâ€™s attire from scratch. But she didnâ€™t have access to Williams during pre-production, as the actress was filming another movie in Europe (presumably â€œAll the Money in the World,â€ which Williams shot in Rome immediately before â€œPrettyâ€). Instead, McGuire scouted Tom Ford, Dolce & Gabbana and Gucci boutiques. Knowing that Kohn and Silverstein didnâ€™t want Williams to wear the same sort of regalia she dons in real life, McGuire sought an â€œau currentâ€ metropolitan sensibility accentuated by straight, flowing blond locks. â€œThere was an Ivanka Trump vibe going on there,â€ she said half-jokingly.

That dichotomy â€• corporate gloss meets puerile squeal â€• is best evidenced in a baby-blue dress Avery wears with pink flowers and golden retrievers all over. A Dolce & Gabanna original that McGuire said was inspired by the designersâ€™ own dogs, the blithe garment reflects Averyâ€™s lifelong struggle to cultivate a personality despite the fact that no one takes her seriously. The movieâ€™s producers first balked at the canine frock, thinking it might be too distracting, but McGuire, who had the directorsâ€™ support, wasnâ€™t budging. â€œThat dress was going to be on camera even if I had to stomp over anybody who didnâ€™t want it,â€ she said. â€œI felt this was just a perfect place to show part of who this character is because thereâ€™s a snobby vibe to the Lily LeClair aesthetic. To come to work in a puppy dress, youâ€™ve gotta be some kind of woman to do that.â€

Averyâ€™s accouterments and wispiness mask a crippling insecurity. â€œI sound like a freaking moron,â€ she moans in an uncharacteristically candid moment, listing the line items on her astoundingly intellectual biography to prove how belittled she is because of her voice. In the same way that Schumer learns to value her body by the movieâ€™s end, Avery is meant to better understand her place in the class-conscious, image-obsessed world. She is the face of Lily LeClair, but itâ€™s her inability to muster the confidence needed to excel that encourages her to extend the brand to reach more than just snobby rich women. That arc is baked into Williamsâ€™ oddities.

â€œOn the first day, she did this one thing where she, like, leaned on her hands together like she was posing for a picture while she was talking,â€ Silverstein said. â€œAvery has seen human behavior and tries to emulate it in ways that are not right: â€˜Oh, this is what a person would do right now. They would lean on this table as they talk.â€™ [Williams] really got into that. This is the story of a person of privilege, yet someone whoâ€™s grown up with a lot of obstacles in her way and maybe without a lot of personal connections and without a lot of real human interaction. Itâ€™s just a really fun thing to watch her do this and find the line.â€

articleContent: A charter school network has apologized for an assignment asking students to list the positive and negative aspects of slavery, calling the worksheet a â€œclear mistake.â€

â€œTo be clear, there is no debate about slavery,â€ Aaron Kindel, superintendent of Great Hearts Texas, said in a statement posted on Facebook Thursday. â€œIt is immoral and a crime against humanity.â€

On Wednesday, Roberto Livar posted a photo of a worksheet he said his son, Manu, was asked to complete in his eighth-grade American history class at Great Hearts Monte Vista in San Antonio. The worksheet is titled, â€œThe Life of Slaves: A Balanced View.â€
Livar told HuffPost that his son was uneasy about the nature of the assignment and felt compelled to bring it home and show his parents. Livar said he was â€œpissedâ€ as soon as he saw the worksheet.

â€œWe are fully aware that there is a concerted effort by the far-right nationally to reframe slavery as being â€˜not that badâ€™ and trying to revise the civil war as being about â€˜states rightsâ€™ and not about slavery,â€ he told HuffPost in a Facebook message. â€œWe were concerned that this assignment fell in line with that ideology and were naturally concerned, as well as other parents.â€

Other families and members of the community upset about the worksheet began sharing Livarâ€™s post, including Rep. Joaquin Castro (D-Texas). Castro called the assignment â€œabsolutely unacceptableâ€ in a tweet on Thursday.

Kindel said in his statement that the incident was â€œlimited to one teacher at just one campus,â€ and that the teacher has been put on leave while Great Hearts â€œcollect[s] all the facts.â€ He added that Great Hearts will â€œconduct an auditâ€ of the book that inspired the worksheet to see if it should be permanently replaced.

Livar told HuffPost that Great Hearts staff invited his family and other concerned parents to a meeting on Thursday to discuss the matter, and that Manu was â€œcommended for his action of bringing this to light and was even told he was â€˜very brave.â€™â€
However, he noted that his son has been â€œattacked by many at his schoolâ€ for supposedly harming its reputation.
Livar, who said he and his family are Mexican-American and identify as Chicano, chalked the whole ordeal up to a lack of diversity at the school among the student body and staff.
He added that he sees what happened as a sign of problems stemming beyond his sonâ€™s school.
â€œThese issues are not isolated to one school or one book,â€ Livar said. â€œThese issues are systemic and continue up the chain all the way to the Texas School Board of Education.â€

articleContent: The â€œFearless Girlâ€ statue, which faces Wall Streetâ€™s "Charging Bullâ€ sculpture in lower Manhattan, is slated to be moved by the end of the year.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio (D), in partnership with State Street Global Advisors, the management group that commissioned the statue, announced on Thursday that Fearless Girl will moved from its current location by the Bowling Green park to face the New York Stock Exchange. The move is due to safety concerns and pedestrian traffic, The New York Times reports.

â€œWe are proud to be home to the Fearless Girl. She is a potent symbol of the need for change at the highest levels of corporate America â€• and she will become a durable part of our cityâ€™s civic life,â€ de Blasio said. â€œThis move to a new location will ensure that her message and impact will continue to be heard, as well as improve access for visitors.â€

Fearless Girl, a bronze work sculpted by Kristen Visbal, stands in a narrow spot in a corner of Bowling Green. According to city officials, this creates a safety hazard due to the large number of tourists visiting the spot every day. Other officials expressed concerns that the mix of Fearless Girl, Charging Bull and the volume of pedestrians could attract an attack similar to last yearâ€™s in lower Manhattan, when a driver killed eight people.

â€œI am thrilled Fearless Girl will remain in New York, inspiring global collaboration between genders for better decisions, and an improved environment at every strata of society,â€ Visbal said in a statement.

De Blasioâ€™s press secretary, Eric Phillips, said that Charging Bull â€• a 1989 work by Arturo Di Modica â€• will â€œalmost certainlyâ€ be moved with Fearless Girl, although thereâ€™s no exact timeline.

Fearless Girl was erected in March 2017. Ron Oâ€™Hanley, State Streetâ€™s CEO, described the work as a call for companies to â€œincrease gender diversity on their boardsâ€ and celebrate women leaders in business. However, in October, the Department of Labor alleged that State Street had paid women and black executives less than their white male counterparts. State Street disputed the Labor Departmentâ€™s findings but agreed to pay a $5 million settlement over the claims.

Critics have accused Fearless Girl of being an empty symbol and an avatar of capitalism rather than of justice, but itâ€™s been a hit with many people and has kicked off conversations about female empowerment in different workspaces.

â€œIâ€™m thrilled that the Fearless Girl will have a long-term home in the heart of New Yorkâ€™s financial district,â€ Rep. Carolyn Maloney (D-N.Y.) said in a statement this week. â€œThe Fearless Girl called attention to the severe lack of women sitting on corporate boards but she connected with so many women and girls because [she] embodies the resiliency that each woman must possess to get ahead.â€

otherData.headline: Congress Still Hasn't Dealt With Its Sexual Harassment Problem
otherData.short_description: A bill to overhaul how complaints are handled on Capitol Hill has stalled because some senators don't want to pay out of pocket for misconduct.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• Two months ago, it looked like Congress was ready to crack down on its embarrassing problems with sexual harassment.

Thatâ€™s when the House passed a bill to overhaul the Congressional Accountability Act, a decades-old law that set up the process for handling workplace complaints about harassment and discrimination on Capitol Hill. Support for the bill was a no-brainer â€• it passed unanimously, on a voice vote â€• and it made badly needed updates, like banning sexual relationships between members of Congress and their staffers. It also eliminates a requirement that House staffers go through a 30-day counseling and mediation period before filing a workplace complaint.

But the bill has gone nowhere in the Senate since February, and nobody can say when or if similar legislation will move forward. The reason? Some senators donâ€™t like the billâ€™s requirement that they would have to pay out of pocket if they are found personally liable for harassing or discriminating against employees.
Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.), who chairs the rules committee and is involved in negotiations on the bill, said Tuesday that the panel is â€œtrying to come to a conclusionâ€ on the bill.

Asked why itâ€™s been so delayed, he carefully considered his words. â€œI think anytime youâ€™re dealing with membersâ€™ personal liability, you ought to be sure that the members understand what theyâ€™re asked to vote on,â€ he said.

It speaks volumes about the Senate that itâ€™s struggling to pass a bill to make it easier for Capitol Hill victims of sexual harassment or discrimination to file a complaint â€• and that itâ€™s because anonymous senators donâ€™t want to have to personally pay for misconduct claims when they are found liable.

The Senateâ€™s inaction comes after a string of lawmakers resigned over allegations of sexual misconduct, including Reps. John Conyers (D-Mich.), Trent Franks (R-Ariz.) and Blake Farenthold (R-Texas), and Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.). Rep. Patrick Meehan (R-Pa.) said in January that he wonâ€™t seek re-election after a former female aide said he lashed out at her after she rejected his romantic advances. Meehan called the aide his â€œsoul mate.â€

Congress clearly needs to deal with this. Four out of 10 female congressional aides believe sexual harassment is a problem on Capitol Hill, according to a 2016 CQ Roll Call survey. The same survey found that 1 in 6 said they had been personally victimized.

Supporters of the Hill harassment bill thought the Senate would just tuck it into last monthâ€™s must-pass omnibus spending package and be done with it. But according to two senior Democratic aides familiar with negotiations on that package, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) refused to roll the harassment bill into it unless they stripped out its provision requiring lawmakers to be personally liable.

â€œHe wanted to do that in order to put it into the omnibus,â€ said one of the aides. â€œBut [House Minority Leader Nancy] Pelosi and [California Democratic Rep. Jackie] Speier objected to the change.â€

McConnell spokesman Don Stewart denied that it was McConnell himself who had problems with that provision. He pointed to a statement previously issued by another McConnell spokesman, David Popp, who said, â€œSen. McConnell supports members being personally, financially liable for sexual misconduct in which they have engaged.â€
Itâ€™s unclear who, exactly, is opposed to this provision. But the Senateâ€™s inaction is infuriating lawmakers in both parties who believe this should not be difficult.

Last month, all 22 female senators of both parties ripped McConnell and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) for not making the bill a priority. On Thursday, every male Democratic senator â€• plus Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), who co-authored the Senateâ€™s version of the harassment bill â€• wrote to McConnell demanding action on the issue.

Sen. Amy Klobuchar (Minn.), who is the ranking Democrat on the rules committee and involved in negotiations on the bill, expressed optimism that senators would get some version of the bill out the door.

â€œWe are continuing to push on this,â€ Klobuchar told HuffPost this week. â€œThe letter that we had with all the women senators â€¦ I think that was really significant. Letâ€™s just say, it got noticed.â€
She said sheâ€™s hopeful a bill will be ready â€œin the next month or two.â€

But the longer this bill hangs out there, the less clear it becomes what must-pass bill it can be attached to. And as it gets closer to the November elections, action in the Senate will significantly slow down. That could mean the bill gets delayed even further, or possibly lost in the shuffle of other matters.

Speier, the sponsor of the House bill, said if McConnell truly supports lawmakers paying out of pocket when they harass or discriminate against their staff, it makes no sense why he wonâ€™t give her bill a vote now.
â€œStop giving us lip service and pass the bill,â€ Speier said.

articleContent: The Department of Justice released copies of the so-called Comey memos to congressional leaders on Thursday. In the documents, the former FBI director detailed his early encounters with newly-minted President Donald Trump, including Trumpâ€™s obsession with disproving allegations in the infamous Steele dossier and his demands for aidesâ€™ loyalty.

The memos, which contain no notable information that Comey hasnâ€™t already discussed in congressional testimony or his new memoir, were leaked to a swath of news outlets late Thursday. Redacted copies of the seven documents can be seen below.

Throughout the memos, the former FBI chief details Trumpâ€™s lack of familiarity with established channels of communication between the White House and the Justice Department. In one instance, Comey describes Trump asking him to discuss then-national security adviser Michael Flynn in â€œprivate,â€ prompting Comey to reply that â€œit was important that communications about any particular case go through that channel to protect us and to protect the WH from any accusations of improper influence.â€

otherData.headline: German Theater Gives Free Hitler Play Tickets To People Wearing Swastikas
otherData.short_description: Prosecutors declined to investigate, saying the giveaway is protected as artistic expression.

articleContent: Prosecutors declined to investigate a theater in Germany thatâ€™s offering free tickets to patrons who wear swastikas to a satirical play about Hitlerâ€™s youth.

Authorities in the southern city of Konstanz determined that the production is protected under artistic expression, rejecting criticism that the offer of free tickets violated German laws banning the production, distribution and display of Nazi symbols. The laws date back to 1945, when Allied forces in power after World War II banned the swastika. Even denying the Holocaust is punishable in Germany.

A representative of the public prosecutorâ€™s office told The New York Times that, although they received many complaints and launched an initial probe, the office declined to investigate further since the situation was â€œclearly coveredâ€ and protected under artistic expression laws.

The theater will go ahead with its production of the farce â€œMein Kampf,â€ written by Hungarian dramatist George Tabori in 1987, as planned on Friday â€• Hitlerâ€™s birthday. Directed by well-known political satirist Serdar Somuncu, the show â€œbegins with the ticket purchase,â€ according to the productionâ€™s website. Those who pay full price have the option to wear a Star of David â€œas a sign of solidarity with the victims of National Socialist tyranny.â€
Those who opt for a free ticket must wear an armband with a swastika during the performance. The armbands will be given out at the entrance to the auditorium and must be returned after the show.
Daniel Morgenroth, spokesman for the theater, said in an interview that the ticket offer was meant to show the fragility of peopleâ€™s convictions.
â€œThis artistic impulse seeks to show how easily people are corrupted and can be made to wear the symbol of millionfold suffering for saving a few euros,â€ Morgenroth said.
â€œArt, if it wants to be relevant, has to be controversial sometimes,â€ he added.

Members of the Jewish Community of Konstanz argued the show is misusing Nazi symbols to prompt a political discussion, when such conversations could easily start without using the swastika. Group members also are offended the play is planned for Hitlerâ€™s birthday. The group has called for a boycott of the show, and asks that the Nazi symbols be removed and that the director engage in talks with the local Jewish community.

â€œWe donâ€™t believe the play or the theater or Serdar Somuncu are anti-Semitic. We just think what they did was not thought through thoroughly,â€ Arthur Bondarev, vice chairman of the Jewish Community of Konstanz, said in an interview. â€³The people who this play concerns were not involved. Holocaust survivors, or at least the Jewish community, were not involved at all.â€

The satire on Hitlerâ€™s attempts to make it as a young artist in Vienna has been in production since the late 1980s. No previous presentation of the play has included the use of swastika armbands or Stars of David.

â€œNow, no one is interested in the play, they are only concentrating on the ticket sale gimmick,â€ Bondarev said. â€œThe only picture that will live on from the production will be of people wearing swastikas.â€

The play occurs as anti-Semitism is growing in Germany and other parts of Europe. â€œEven though they didnâ€™t intend it, they enhance these anti-Semitic structures when they misuse the symbol in this way,â€ Bondarev said.

Leaders in post-World War II Germany enacted laws banning Nazism and its corresponding symbols. The country also passed measures to safeguard freedoms that the dictator undermined, particularly artistic expression.

In addition to the well-documented Holocaust that is the hallmark of World War II, the Nazis confiscated roughly 16,000 pieces of what they deemed â€œdegenerate art.â€ In July 1937, the party hosted two art shows in Munich â€• one to exhibit art Hitler found acceptable, and another to show the works he deemed immoral. Many of the â€œdegenerateâ€ works were modern and abstract pieces. Works by Jewish artists were also considered â€œdegenerate,â€ and many of the pieces from the show were burned.
Today, freedom of artistic expression is highly protected in Germany, while symbols of the Nazi era are strictly prohibited.
Still, critics argue that in spite of the legalities, using Nazi symbols in art is unjustified.

â€œIt was always a taboo to use Nazi symbols in an artistic way,â€ Bondarev said. â€œNow, the production, of course, kind of broke this taboo. Itâ€™s kind of an irony ... but you always had the mutual understanding that you donâ€™t misuse these symbols for artistic reasons â€• without further discussion or showing the idea behind it.â€

otherData.headline: Germany Confronts Rising Anti-Semitism After Rap Duo With Holocaust Lyrics Wins Award

articleContent: Mainstream manifestations of anti-Semitism are causing Germans to take a harder look at what is permissible in the name of artistic expression, after a rap duo whose lyrics some have interpreted as denigratory toward Holocaust victims won a major music award.

Some of the lyrics on the album include the mention of bodies that are â€œmore defined than an Auschwitz prisonerâ€ and the warning that â€œIâ€™m doing another Holocaust, coming with a Molotov cocktail.â€

The two artists have apologized to those, including Holocaust survivor Esther Bejarano, who expressed outrage in the face of the lyrics. Bang said in a Facebook post that â€œthe past cannot be forgottenâ€ and he hopes something positive can emerge from the debate.

â€œRecent news reports have produced shocking evidence of a new wave of anti-Semitism in German schools,â€ CEO Hartwig Masuch said in a statement. â€œBMG is utterly opposed to anti-Semitism. We know our artists and employees are behind us. We want to ensure that something positive emerges from the debate surrounding the ECHO Awards.â€

â€œWe emphatically apologize to you and everyone else whose feelings were hurt by this,â€ Florian Druecke, chairman of Germanyâ€™s BVMI music industry association, said in a letter to Holocaust survivor Charlotte Knobloch.

Yet the group also defended its decision to ask the duo to perform during the awards given their popularity, stating that the debate around the lyrics â€œis an appeal to the industry to pay even more attention in the future and to take a closer look at the contents of the texts of published artists.â€

Other artists have even taken a stand against the lyrics. Some Echo winners handed back their awards in protest. Campino, the lead singer of the countryâ€™s most prominent punk band, slammed the rappers in his own Echo acceptance speech.
â€œIt crosses the line of acceptability when lyrics include misogynistic, homophobic, right-wing extremist and anti-Semitic insults,â€ he said.
The debate around the lyrics has pitted those defending self-expression against those decrying the overt and covert forms of anti-Semitism that have cropped up across Germany in recent years.

On Wednesday, German police were investigating an assault on two young men in Berlin wearing kippahs. It comes on the heels of a variety of reports that Jewish children are being bullied in German schools and subjected to name-calling. More than 1,400 anti-Semitic incidents were recorded in Germany in 2017 â€• about four per day â€• which represents a more than fivefold increase in the last seven years.

The uptick also comes at a time when views seem to be shifting to the right. Alternative for Germany, a far-right party, won enough votes in September to enter the countryâ€™s parliament for the first time. And the countryâ€™s Interior Ministry has said that the vast majority of anti-Semitic incidents are perpetrated by right-wing extremists.
â€œThis fight against such anti-Semitic excesses must be won,â€ German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Wednesday.

otherData.headline: South Korea Working To Formally End The Korean War. Yes, That Korean War.
otherData.short_description: For more than 60 years, an official peace treaty has remained elusive. Until now.

articleContent: South Korean officials have discussed ways to formally end the Korean War with their counterparts in the United States and North Korea, officials in Seoul confirmed this week.

The move comes amid thawing tensions on the Korean Peninsula and just days ahead of an April 27 meeting between North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un and the South Korean President Moon Jae-in. Moon is expected to set the groundwork for Kim to abandon a contentious nuclear weapon program, something the North has said it was open to if certain security guarantees were met.

Diplomats have tried to forge a lasting peace treaty between the two countries for decades. The Korean War has never technically ended since it began in 1950, although a truce, called the Korean Armistice Agreement, was forged in 1953. That led to the creation of the Demilitarized Zone that divided the peninsula in two and effectively ended the conflict.

A permanent peace treaty would replace the armistice and would need to be signed by both Koreas, as well as by the United States and China, who were signatories to the original agreement after backing the two countries during the war.

Chung Eui-yong, the Southâ€™s national security adviser, said he had discussed such a treaty with U.S. national security adviser John Bolton ahead of President Donald Trumpâ€™s own meeting with Kim, expected to take place sometime in May or June, The New York Times reported.

â€œWe held in-depth discussions on various ways of how to end hostilities and eventually establish a peace regime on the Korean Peninsula, how to address the North Korean concerns and how to ensure a bright future for the North if it makes the right choice,â€ Chung said Wednesday, according to the Times. â€œMr. Bolton made it clear to me that he will do his best as an honest broker in successfully implementing President Trumpâ€™s peace policy on the Korean Peninsula.â€

Chung said he and Bolton had also discussed ways to appease the Northâ€™s demands for security and regime survival were the country to come to the negotiating table, according to the Korea JoongAng Daily.

China, a longtime ally of Pyongyang, has already signaled some support for the treaty but has not formally endorsed the idea, the Times reported. A spokeswoman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry said at a media briefing that the countryâ€™s â€œattitude is open and supportive to any peaceful means to resolve the Korean Peninsula issue through consultations.â€

Activity around North Koreaâ€™s meeting with South Korea and the U.S. has rapidly picked up in recent days. CIA Director Mike Pompeo secretly met with Kim over the Easter weekend to prepare for talks with the U.S. Trump confirmed the encounter on Twitter this week, saying the meeting â€œwent very smoothly and a good relationship was formed.â€
â€œDenuclearization will be a great thing for the World, but also for North Korea!â€ he wrote.

Trump has expressed optimism ahead of the talks but has continued with some of his traditional bluster. On Wednesday he vowed to cancel the summit or â€œrespectfully leaveâ€ it if the meeting â€œis not fruitful.â€
â€œI think weâ€™re going to be successful,â€ he said at a news conference from his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. â€œBut for any reason if I think weâ€™re not, we end.â€
