articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• A Florida attorney has filed a House ethics complaint against Rep. Ron DeSantis (R-Fla.) for previously renting a condo from campaign donors who are executives at a defense contractor that lobbies the federal government.
The complaint, a copy of which HuffPost obtained Wednesday, also alleges that DeSantis paid â€œwell belowâ€ fair market value to stay at the condo, though that appears inaccurate.
Attorney Richard Ruben of Miami filed the complaint with the Office of Congressional Ethics on April 6. Hereâ€™s a copy:
The complaint comes after Kent Stermon and Matt Connell, both executives at defense contractor Total Military Management, rented out a condo to DeSantis for five months in 2016.
The two of them and a political action committee tied to their company have given more than $53,000 to DeSantisâ€™ congressional campaigns, according to campaign finance records.

It certainly doesnâ€™t seem appropriate for a member of Congress to rent a condo from top campaign donors who lobby the federal government. Total Military Management has spent between $50,000 and $190,000 per year lobbying Congress on defense-related issues over the past six years. DeSantis is the chairman of the House Oversight and Government Relations Committeeâ€™s subcommittee on national security, which oversees the Defense Department, among other things.
But itâ€™s not clear to HuffPost that DeSantis violated any House rules.

Lawmakers are not allowed to accept â€œgifts,â€ and Ruben says DeSantis may have broken this rule by paying $2,000 a month to stay at the Florida condo. Ruben claims he talked to a realtor in the area who told him the cost to rent similar condos is $2,500 to $2,800.

â€œI am troubled that Rep. DeSantis was potentially gifted, by a close campaign contributor and lobbyist, a condominium to reside in, at well below fair market value,â€ reads the complaint. â€œI, as well as all of Rep. DeSantisâ€™s past, current and future constituents, are led to question what exactly Rep. DeSantis promised these campaign contributors and lobbyists in exchange for receiving such a sweetheart deal.â€
But it does not appear that DeSantis paid less than he should have. Zillowâ€™s estimate for renting that condo is $2,000 a month. Another similar condo in the building is listed at $1,695 a month.
DeSantis is currently running for governor, and his spokesman says Rubenâ€™s complaint is â€œa politically motivated smear tactic.â€

â€œThis should really be a story about how people use the ethics complaint system to unfairly attack office holders and then use bogus complaints that they know wonâ€™t go anywhere in campaign advertising,â€ said DeSantis campaign manager Brad Herold.
Itâ€™s not clear who Ruben filed the complaint on behalf of, or if he filed it on behalf of himself. Reached by HuffPost, he would not answer any questions.
â€œI canâ€™t talk about it,â€ Ruben said before hanging up the phone. â€œIâ€™m sorry.â€

Herold speculated that Ruben could be filing the complaint on behalf of a right-wing group called Uncle Samâ€™s Misguided Children, which describes itself as â€œcommunity founded by United States Marine Veterans to bring awareness of the lame stream media.â€ The group has made absurd and false claims about DeSantisâ€™ voting record on immigrants and food stamps.
Herold also said that DeSantis was friends with Connell before he entered politics and that Total Military Management â€œhas never lobbied DeSantis or his office on any issue.â€
Reached by HuffPost, Stermon, too, said he and Connell have been friends with DeSantis â€œfor a long timeâ€ and that neither of them is a lobbyist.

â€œRon DeSantis has never involved himself on a single issue impacting our business,â€ Stermon said in an email. â€œWe have intentionally always just tried to be nothing but a friend to Ron in an atmosphere where it is hard to have true friends.â€

That may be true. But executives at Total Military Management certainly have an agenda when they and their companyâ€™s political arm donate tens of thousands of dollars to DeSantisâ€™ congressional campaigns.
The Office of Congressional Ethics declined to comment, citing its own ethics rules.

The office periodically gets requests from the public for ethics investigations, but requests do not trigger the start of an investigation. The officesâ€™ independent board members decide whether to launch a formal review.
Paul Blumenthal contributed to this report.

otherData.headline: Desperate For Teachers, Districts Beg Retirees To Come Back
otherData.short_description: "Itâ€™s difficult not to respond when you hear there is such a significant need.â€

articleContent: By Avis Thomas-Lester, The Hechinger Report
Hymethia W. Thompson was happily retired after 46 years as an educator when she saw a television news conference last summer that changed her life.

The interim school superintendent of Jackson, Mississippi, where Thompson lives, issued a plea to retired teachers to come back. The Jackson Public School District was experiencing a shortage of certified teachers and there was a desperate need for qualified former instructors.

â€œI hadnâ€™t thought about returning to the classroom, but when I heard they needed certified teachers that badly, I had to help,â€ said Thompson, who won numerous awards during her career as an English, speech and drama teacher in Mississippi and Wisconsin. â€œI called and got the information and a few weeks later I was back in the classroom.â€

Thompson, 70, is among a small cadre of retired educators who returned to Jackson classrooms for the 2017-18 school year to teach science, math and English, the courses for which the school district has the direst need. She is currently teaching 11th grade English at Jacksonâ€™s historic Lanier High School, marking the first time the school has had a licensed 11th grade English teacher in four and a half years, she said. Thompson teaches three 90-minute periods per day â€” equal to six classes.

Freddrick Murray, who has been serving as Jackson Public Schoolsâ€™ interim superintendent since November 2016, said he issued the call for retired teachers because the school district has had difficulty attracting adequate numbers of certified instructors. The problem is so significant, educators said, that many of Jacksonâ€™s schools depend on long-term uncertified substitutes to augment the teacher rolls. The school district has 58 schools, 1,800 teachers and about 26,000 students. There are 184 long-term subs working in Jackson schools this year, according to JPS spokesman Sherwin Johnson.

â€œEven with the retirees coming in, there is still a serious shortage,â€ said Bishop Ronnie Crudup, senior pastor of New Horizon Church International of Jackson and a member of the Better Together Commission, a group formed to spur school improvements in Jackson. â€œItâ€™s a huge challenge and there doesnâ€™t seem to be an end in sight.â€
Forty-eight retired educators are working in the schools this school year, according to Johnson. The school district wants to hire dozens of teachers.

Rural school districts across Mississippi and around the country are facing similar staffing challenges, often made more difficult by their remoteness. Alvin Thornton, former chair of the Maryland Commission on Education Finance, Equity, and Excellence, said bringing back retired teachers may be a good temporary fix for urban and rural districts alike, but it should not be considered a solution. The Maryland group, known as the Thornton Commission, was created to equalize educational opportunities and funding for students in Marylandâ€™s 25 public school districts.

â€œWhat states have to do is invest in more well-funded teacher colleges,â€ he said. â€œThere need to be incentive programs that offer people who go teach in low-income or rural areas inducements starting with [free] tuition and subsidization of expenses such as housing, etc.â€

He added public school districts also need to get back to the basics that will make them successful: well-paid teachers who live in the communities where they work, small classes and parents and community members who are involved in childrenâ€™s education.

In Jackson, Geraldine Bender, president of the Mississippi chapter of the American Federation of Teachers (AFT), said the district loses teachers to better-paying neighboring school districts and nearby states such as Texas, Georgia and Tennessee.

Among the reasons why pay is not competitive, she said, is a state legislature that â€œdoes not care a whole lot about funding inner city schools.â€ Suburban school districts are growing as Jackson families leave the city, in part because of concern about the underfunded schools, she added.

Murray, the interim superintendent, said JPS has been underfunded for years. According to JPS spokesman Sherwin Johnson, â€œthe current [Mississippi Adequate Education Program] formula uses a base student cost of $5,381.52; at the current funding level â€¦ our actual funding is at $4,882.77 base student costâ€ â€” a difference that puts the district $498.75 in the hole for every student enrolled, a deficit that runs into the millions.
The shortage negatively impacts students and teachers alike, said Bender, of the AFT.

â€œFor the students, itâ€™s a situation of â€˜Am I getting the best education because I have a sub in the classroom instead of a certified teacher?â€™â€ Bender said. â€œFor the teachers, itâ€™s class overload. You are working without an assistant and you have 35 students in a classroom, for example a French class or a math class or a science class. You are expected to reach each of those 35 students every class period. Thatâ€™s an awesome task.â€

JPS has recruited retirees by increasing financial incentives. The district pays them $225 per day, up from $125 per day previously. But hiring retirees is an imperfect solution to the districtâ€™s staffing woes; some retired teachers can only work for half a year or theyâ€™ll lose their retirement benefits. Others, like Hymethia Thompson, came out of retirement to teach, trading their retirement pay for a regular salary based on their education level and years of experience.

Thatâ€™s why Murray said Jackson is also stepping up efforts to hire new teachers by increasing starting pay and offering curriculum support and professional development opportunities. The school district offered a signing bonus of $2,500 for teachers who were hired this school year, he said. School district officials are also attending job fairs and aggressively pursuing students coming out of college education programs, he added.

The teacher shortage resulted, in part, from the retirement of a number of teachers in recent years, Murray said. At the same time, the number of new college grads with degrees in education has been declining, so many positions are left unstaffed when veteran teachers leave. About 1,000 of the districtâ€™s 1,800 teachers have worked in classrooms for three years or less, Murray said.

Crudup, of the Better Together Commission, said he is eager for the teacher shortage to be resolved. â€œI believe one of our tasks will be to create a better environment that will be more attractive for people to want to come to Jackson and be part of the public schools,â€ he said.

In the interim, the district has conducted a multi-media blitz to entice retired teachers back to the classroom. Officials took their campaign to the public, doing interviews with local print and broadcast news outlets, purchasing billboards, advertising and spreading the word any way they could.
Murray even made phone calls to retired teachers he knew, asking if they were interested in coming back and requesting names of other retirees who might want to work with students again.
â€œIt was a major priority for us,â€ Murray said. â€œWe found that the pool of retired teachers was extensive.â€

Viola Owens is one of the retired teachers who came out of retirement to help. She taught English for 33 years â€” 14 of them in Jackson Public Schools â€” before retiring in 2014 to take care of her disabled son. She was widowed in 2013, and lost her son in 2015. At loose ends after this double loss, she looked for volunteer work, donating her time to local police and other groups.

So, when she heard veteran teachers were needed, going back to school seemed ideal. Like Thompson, she teaches full time on a salary. A former educator of the year in Canton, Mississippi, who retired from Jackson Public Schools, Owens now works at Provine High School teaching three classes of 10th grade English per day, with one planning period.

â€œI like helping the young people,â€ she said. â€œSome of them need so much help and guidance. Things have changed quite a bit since I started teaching. A lot of the kids are behind socially and educationally.â€

Indeed, the Jackson Public Schools serve many students with great needs, and many are behind academically. Many of the students hail from economically disadvantaged households; 78 percent of the students in the school system qualify for free or reduced meals. Just over 20 percent of JPS students scored proficient in reading, and only 16.9 percent were proficient in math based on assessments for grades three through eight.
Even though itâ€™s not easy, Owens said she has been â€œdelightedâ€ to see some of the students she taught at John Powell Middle School before she retired.
â€œThey know that means they are going to have to work!â€ she said.

Eric Knapp, is one of those teachers deeply embedded in his community that Alvin Thornton, of the Maryland Commission on Education Finance, Equity, and Excellence, suggests districts should be trying to attract. He taught Language Arts in Jackson for 29 years before retiring in 2009. He returned to Jackson schools as a substitute three years ago. â€œI guess after working with children, walking away was kind of boring,â€ he said. â€œI made the decision to go back to help out.â€

Knapp said heâ€™s had a positive response from students and parents since he joined the faculty of Brinkley Middle School in northwest Jackson as a retire/rehire. The best part is â€œseeing the smiles on their facesâ€ when students master a task.
â€œTeachers are generally concerned about kids and that calling never leaves you,â€ Knapp said. â€œSo, you go when there is a need.â€

Shimelle Mayers, principal at Brinkley Middle School said having retired teachers in the building has been a positive experience all around. She has two retired/rehired teachers among 38 staffers teaching the schoolâ€™s 465 students.
â€œGood tactics stand the test of time,â€ she said. â€œThey are good at looking at the diverse needs of the students, their strengths and weaknesses, and working with them to address those needs.â€
She said the retired teachers also bring â€œstructure, order and disciplineâ€ that beginning teachers may not have mastered.
Mayers said the veterans and beginners learn from each other. The retired teachers share their knowledge of classroom management while the younger teachers help them understand new technology.

Retired Jackson Public Schools teacher Anne Johnson, who now teaches students at her church and volunteers for the Jackson chapter of the NAACP, said the educators who have returned are committed to education in a school system in which good teachers have the potential to make a big difference in childrenâ€™s lives.

â€œTeaching is a ministry,â€ said Johnson. â€œYou teach because you are interested in helping children be the best they can be. Sometimes itâ€™s not something that you can just put down, especially when you know there is a need. You have spent years helping children to learn and thrive. Itâ€™s difficult not to respond when you hear there is such a significant need.â€

otherData.headline: Itâ€™s Time For Drag Kings To Detoxify Masculinity On TV
otherData.authors: Goldie Peacock, On Assignment For HuffPost
otherData.short_description: A â€œDrag Raceâ€-style show could showcase us, and our maleness, in all of our variety. Why hasnâ€™t it arrived?

articleContent: He glows in the spotlight, cameras flashing, millions of fans screaming and crying as heâ€™s crowned â€œAmericaâ€™s Next Drag Superstar.â€ Heâ€™s not clad in a gown and pumps like all of the previous titleholders, though. Instead, he sports a brightly colored, perfectly tailored suit. Admirers of his chameleonic style span the entire gender spectrum. From his glimmering glitter beard to his smooth dance moves, he is magnetic and magnanimous, cool and congenial, the life of the party. Heâ€™s the first-ever drag king to win.

Is this a recap of last seasonâ€™s â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Raceâ€ finale? Of course not! In no uncertain terms, the show has specified that its competition is for queens and queens only, and a particular type at that: assigned male at birth (AMAB), pre-op if male-to-female trans, and willing to (mostly) present at a particular femme frequency.

Instead, the aforementioned scene imagines a future in which kings explode onto our own televised platform and, with a smile and a wink, flamboyantly challenge the toxic masculinity that pervades mainstream culture.

According to Dr. Ruth C. White, a mental health expert and activist, the term toxic masculinity â€œrefers to the social expectations that men, and thus also boys, should be sexually aggressive, physically violent, unemotional, homophobic and should also devalue womenâ€¦ It is also the type of behavior that emphasizes competition based on physical power, risk-taking and sexual prowess and promiscuity.â€

Many people who perform as drag kings have experienced the firsthand effects of toxic masculinity. While kings (myself included) do not always identify as women outside of drag and may find ourselves elsewhere on the gender spectrum, the majority of us are assigned female at birth (AFAB). As a result, weâ€™re often particularly attuned to the far-reaching cultural consequences of strict definitions of masculinity.

â€œIâ€™ve experienced a number of close encounters with men attempting to dominate my physical space, inappropriately touching me and asking personal or revolting questions,â€ said Adam All, a London-based king. Allâ€™s stories are too familiar, and if I were to quote them in their entirety plus list my own, Iâ€™d need to up this articleâ€™s word count by several thousand.

Brooklyn-based king K.James, who identifies as transmasculine, initially had a difficult time finding a community that wasnâ€™t replicating toxic masculinity â€œby conforming to certain masculine ideals that are in conflict with feminism and respecting women and femmes.â€ For K.James, â€œbecoming a drag king and part of the drag community opened up the definition of masculinity for me as I navigated my trans identity â€• one that is queerer and less strictly defined.â€

Iâ€™ve heard many of my fellow drag artists and industry peers characterize drag king performance as an embodiment or critique of masculinity. But by definition, what we always perform is maleness. We are called male impersonators, not masculinity impersonators, and we do not all parody or embody stereotypical alpha-male masculinity; we demonstrate variety in our portrayals.

â€œI try to bring three completely different characters and expressions to every show that I do,â€ said Damien Dâ€™Luxe, a Minneapolis-based king known for his elaborate makeup and costuming. All describes himself as â€œa man who embraces bright colours, emotions, vulnerability and positivity, offering a warm and gentle persona utterly void of toxicity or aggression, though still presenting maleness.â€ According to K.James, his â€œqueer, campy drag style is influenced by iconic masculine images. â€¦ My goal isnâ€™t impersonation â€• itâ€™s about taking these elements and remixing them and showing that these masculine ideals can belong to anybody and any body. It deconstructs the idea that masculinity only belongs to cis men.â€

This multiplicity is innately at odds with the toxic version of masculinity, which thrives on conformity. That drag kings can transmute the lived trauma of having experienced gender-based oppression and emerge onstage as the men of our dreams (or satirically presented nightmares) is a revolutionary act. A â€œDrag Raceâ€-style show could showcase us, and our maleness, in all of our variety. It could pay homage to the attributes of various masculinities while lambasting their destructive sides.

K.James and Vigor Mortis, both members of the legendary Brooklyn drag collective Switch Nâ€™ Play, perform a brilliant fan-favorite piece that perfectly exemplifies the paradigm shift that we kings can facilitate with our art. The number is their take on a classic â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ skit in which Adrian (Patrick Swayze) and Barney (Chris Farley) duked it out for a job stripping at Chippendales. With K.James as Adrian and Mortis as Barney, the kings replicate the start of the original skit with tear-away tuxes and plenty of sass, charmingly and cheesily shaking it to Loverboyâ€™s â€œWorking for the Weekend.â€ Eventually, the judges name the muscular Adrian as the one who gets the gig.

Whereas the old skit then descended into fat-phobic humor, the kings have a fresh spin. Robynâ€™s â€œDancing on My Ownâ€ sashays gaily into the mix, spurring impassioned lip-synching, hand-clasping and collaboration between the two performers. When dialogue from Raven and Jujubeeâ€™s famous tie episode on Season 2 of â€œDrag Raceâ€ bursts forth, punctuated by â€œshantay, you BOTH stay,â€ the kings eschew competition for the throes of queer bromance, enveloped by the deafening cheers of the audience.

Drag kings have been climbing toward a certain apex of recognition over the past few years. Media attention (including from the likes of Vogue, Elle and BuzzFeed) has been rolling in, we have performers in our ranks with tens of thousands of followers on social media, we tour internationally, a number of documentaries about us are currently in post-production, and we regularly share the stage with the worldâ€™s most famous queens. Thereâ€™s no point in wondering why we arenâ€™t â€œthereâ€ yet, if â€œthereâ€ is defined as being national-TV-level household names. We are doing the damn thing. â€œThereâ€ is nearer than ever before, and weâ€™re ready for our close-up.

â€œI absolutely think there should be a â€œDrag Raceâ€-style national TV show for kings,â€ Dâ€™Luxe said. â€œDrag kings deserve to have the same amount of exposure and visibility as drag queens in the industry.â€ All agrees that exposure is â€œessential to our growth as performers and as a community,â€ although he â€œwould want a focus on collaboration and encouragement more than competition.â€ While we may not have a unifying vision of what our hit TV show should look like, I have yet to encounter another king who thinks that more visibility would be a bad thing.

But back to the parallel universe of our king-centric drag race: Here, weâ€™re still cheering on our regal king, whoâ€™s basking in all of his newfound glory. And then, suddenly, another spotlight appears illuminating another king. And then another, and another, until the whole stage is awash with glittering kings. In a shocking plot twist, they are all winners! The show has not only cemented a new spot for kings in the annals of pop culture; itâ€™s exploded the assumption that only one of us deserves to win.

What queer art has always done is render the seemingly impossible possible, taking the lemons that society has thrown at us and serving up the most heavenly, haute lemonade in bejeweled goblets that people of all persuasions canâ€™t help but clamor for. Drag kings are one of the cornerstones of this movement, and itâ€™s high time that we claim our crowns.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• Two Democratic lawmakers asked President Donald Trump on Thursday to explain how it was legal for him to bomb Syria last week without first getting congressional authorization.

â€œWe share your outrage and disgust at the horrific use of chemical weapons by the Syrian regime,â€ reads a letter from Sen. Tim Kaine (Va.) and Rep. Adam Schiff (Calif.). â€œHowever, the legality of military action is not a secondary consideration â€• it is a central question of vital importance under our Constitution and our system of checks and balances.â€
Hereâ€™s a copy of their letter:

The two also pushed for Trump to release a memo that is apparently floating around within the administration that lays out a detailed legal justification for taking military action in Syria. The problem with not releasing that memo, they argued, is that it could be used as precedent for the Trump administration to take additional military action against other countries without Congressâ€™ approval.

Kaine and Schiff wrote a similar letter to Trump a year ago, asking how it was legal for him to launch 59 Tomahawk missiles on a Syrian government airfield in April 2017 â€• the first-ever direct military strike by the U.S. against President Bashar Assadâ€™s regime. They never got a reply.

Itâ€™s not just Democrats insisting that the president has to come to Congress before taking military action against Assadâ€™s regime. Hours before Trump bombed Syria on Friday, dozens of lawmakers in both parties said he needed to get signoff from them.

Congress is constitutionally required to authorize any sustained military action. A president can only use his or her authority as commander in chief to order U.S. forces into military action if the safety or strategic interests of the United States are threatened. Neither was the case last week, nor last year.

Republican Hill leaders, who really donâ€™t want to deal with a war authorization debate, insist Trump is legally justified in taking military action against Assad. Yet they canâ€™t explain why. House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) said Trump can lean on a sweeping 2001 authorization for use of military force against al Qaeda, which has nothing to do with Assadâ€™s regime. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said the administration believes it is on â€œfirm footing,â€ so itâ€™s probably fine.

The White House did provide Congress with a vague legal explanation for its actions in an April 15 letter. It says the president acted â€œin the vital national security and foreign policy interests of the United Statesâ€ under his authority as commander in chief.
Kaine and Schiff say that explains nothing.

â€œThis is not sufficient information for the American public to understand what limits, if any, you and your Administration believes constrains you as the President from taking military action anywhere in the world for any purpose â€˜to defend important U.S. national interests,â€™â€ they said. â€œWe reiterate that your Administration must provide a legal basis for both the 2017 and 2018 strikes.â€
Asked for comment, White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders told HuffPost that Defense Secretary James Mattis â€œhas addressed this.â€

Sanders did not clarify when. Presumably she meant Mattisâ€™ testimony to the House Armed Services Committee last week, before the strikes occurred, when he was asked directly by Rep. John Garamendi (D-Calif.) about the legal justification for Trump to attack Assad without Congressâ€™ authorization.
Mattis said only that Trump has the right â€œunder Article II,â€ which lays out the authority of the commander in chief. But he couldnâ€™t say why.
â€œIâ€™ll have the lawyers get back to you for the broader issue,â€ he said.

otherData.headline: Senate Confirms Climate Change Denier To Lead NASA
otherData.short_description: Rep. Jim Bridenstine (R-Okla.) will take over control of the space agency after seven-month standoff.

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€” The Senate on Thursday narrowly confirmed Rep. Jim Bridenstine (R-Okla.), a former Navy pilot with no scientific credentials and who doesnâ€™t believe humans are primarily to blame for the global climate crisis, to lead NASA.

Bridenstine will become the first elected official to hold the NASA administrator job. He joins a Cabinet already loaded with people who question the near-universal scientific consensus that climate change is real and that human activity is the primary cause.

The final vote â€• which was 50-49 along party lines â€• came one day after the Senate narrowly advanced Bridenstineâ€™s nomination, thanks to an about-face from Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) and a key vote from Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.). Rubio, who in September told Politico that he worried about Bridenstineâ€™s nomination â€œcould be devastating for the space program,â€ said in a statement Wednesday that he decided to support the nominee in order to avoid â€œa gaping leadership voidâ€ at NASA.

Much like the procedural vote on Wednesday, which was temporarily deadlocked at 49-49, Thursdayâ€™s confirmation ultimately hinged on Flake, who voted in favor only after a bit of drama that included a long discussion with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) and stepping out for a phone call, as CNNâ€™s Manu Raju reports.
Bridenstine will replace Robert Lightfoot Jr., who has been serving as acting administrator since previous NASA administrator, Charles Bolden Jr., resigned from his post in January.

In a statement following Thursdayâ€™s vote, Bridenstine said he is humbled by the opportunity. â€œI look forward to working with the outstanding team at NASA to achieve the Presidentâ€™s vision for American leadership in space,â€ he said.

The Senate confirmation comes more than seven months after President Donald Trump tapped Bridenstine for the post. Democrats skewered Bridenstine during the confirmation process, pegging him as â€œextremeâ€ and unqualified to oversee a scientific agency with an annual budget of more than $18 billion.

Echoing previous statements, Sen. Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) said on the Senate floor Wednesday that he finds Bridenstineâ€™s behavior in Congress â€œas divisive as any in Washington.â€ And he called Bridenstineâ€™s previous comments about climate change â€œtroubling.â€
Sen. Brian Schatz (D-Hawaii) said before Thursdayâ€™s vote that it is â€œdownright dangerousâ€ to put someone without the appropriate expertise in charge of NASA.
â€œAnd quite frankly it is even more frightening to have a leader who has made a career out of ignoring scientific expertise,â€ he said.

In a June 2013 speech, Bridenstine peddled a debunked argument made by climate change skeptics, claiming that global temperatures â€œstopped rising 10 years ago.â€ He said â€œthe people of Oklahoma are ready to acceptâ€ an apology from then-President Barack Obama for what Bridenstine called a â€œgross misallocationâ€ of funds for climate change research instead of weather forecasting.

Critics have also pointed to Bridenstineâ€™s history of opposing equal rights for same-sex couples â€• in 2013, he suggested LGBTQ people are sexually immoral â€• and voiced concern about his ability to manage an agency of more than 17,000 employees. Bridenstine has no formal background in science or engineering.

The former Navy Reserve pilot previously served as executive director of the Air and Space Museum & Planetarium in Tulsa, Oklahoma. During his tenure, the nonprofit suffered financial losses, and an investigation by the Project On Government Oversight found that Bridenstine used the nonprofitâ€™s resources to benefit a company he co-owned, according to a report from The Daily Beast this week.
Republican lawmakers, including Sens. Ted Cruz (Texas) and James Inhofe (Okla.), have flocked to Bridenstineâ€™s defense.

On Wednesday, Cruz called Bridenstine a â€œstrong leaderâ€ and said he could think of few people more inspirational or qualified. And he blasted â€œcynical politiciansâ€ for â€œattempting to malign his character.â€

In a Twitter post, Inhofe said Bridenstine â€œhas the experience to take our space program to new heights b/c of his background as an aviator, passion for space & work to modernize our nationâ€™s space program.â€
At his confirmation hearing in November, Bridenstine said NASA was â€œat a critical time in its historyâ€ and that he would build off the hard work of the previous administration.
â€œHumanity is ready to go to deep space for the first time in 45 years,â€ he said.

articleContent: Carrie Underwood is finally giving us details about the November accident that left her with a broken wrist and 50 stitches on her face.

â€œI just fell down. I was just taking the dogs out to go do their thing before bed and I just got clumsy and I just tripped,â€ the â€œCry Prettyâ€ singer told SiriusXM host Storme Warren on his show Thursday.

â€œI held onto the dog leashes in my left hand and went to catch myself with my right and just missed a step. There was one lone step. I said if I had fallen anywhere else I would have been absolutely fine, but it was one step that messed everything up,â€ she said.
Underwood said that initially, she thought sheâ€™d just â€œbustedâ€ her lip (the singer told Bobby Bones on his radio show Thursday that she fell â€œaround my mouthâ€).

â€œI went to go survey the damage and I was like â€˜Oh nooo,â€™â€ she told Warren, adding that while she may seem calm now, she wasnâ€™t then. â€œIt wasnâ€™t pretty. I had a little chipped tooth, but it was just my skin â€• thank the good lord.â€
Later on in the interview, the singer added that the hardest part about the aftermath of the fall was losing the use of her wrist.
â€œI canâ€™t use my appendage, and I try to pick my kid up and make food and do mom stuff,â€ Underwood said. â€œI have a metal plate in my wrist, but itâ€™s good now.â€
While Underwood told fans about the accident â€• minus the details â€• in January, she warned her followers that she was â€œstill healing and not quite looking the same.â€

Though Underwood periodically gave her fans a few updates, she still kept her face fairly hidden until her comeback at the Academy of Country Music Awards last Sunday, where she said she was â€œstill shaky.â€
The singer said that she kept details vague about the accident because she wanted to focus on her new music, first and foremost.

â€œBack when I injured myself, you really donâ€™t know how things are gonna turn out when you in it [with] stitches,â€ she said Thursday. â€œWe put a memo out to the fan club just cause I was like, â€™Somebodyâ€™s gonna catch me at the Kroger! Iâ€™m gonna be buying groceries and somebodyâ€™s gonna post something on Instagram and people are gonna be like â€˜Whatâ€™s going on?â€™â€
But now that her single is out, the star said she knew sheâ€™d eventually have to talk about the accident.
In a note to her fan club last week, Underwood shared that was â€œhealing pretty nicelyâ€ ahead of her performance at the ACMâ€™s.

â€œFirst off, physically, Iâ€™m doing pretty darn good these days! My wrist is almost back to normal, about 90 percent thereâ€¦and the docs say that last 10 percent will come in time,â€ she wrote. â€œAnd my face has been healing pretty nicely as well. I definitely feel more like myself than I have in a while.â€

otherData.headline: Don't Let Nikki Haley Fool You
otherData.short_description: She had her moment this week, but that doesn't excuse the role she plays in the Trump White House.

articleContent: It was momentarily glorious to hear Nikki Haley, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, stand up for herself against her male colleague at the White House. But donâ€™t let that moment blind you.
Responding to the suggestion, made by Trumpâ€™s newly appointed economic adviser Larry Kudlow, that there was â€œconfusionâ€ about the White House plan for Russian sanctions, Haley shot back.
â€œWith all due respect, I donâ€™t get confused,â€ she said in a statement to Fox Newsâ€™ Dana Perino, who read the comment during her Tuesday show.

It was the rare power move made by the rarest of creatures â€• an actual woman (of color!) in the Trump administration. Kudlow even apologized later that day, though that doesnâ€™t mitigate the fact that Haley was left out of critical decision-making and made to look like a dupe.

Haleyâ€™s words were enough to charm CNN chief political correspondent Dana Bash, who tweeted that the line â€œshould go down as one of the best by a female leader. Ever. Said so much, with so few words.â€

Indeed, it was hard not to feel a little bit heartened by Haley in that moment. While a strong woman standing up for herself isnâ€™t exactly novel in the Me Too era, spotting one in the male wilds of the White House is definitely a noteworthy occasion.
But a tossed-off strong comeback doesnâ€™t let Haley off the hook. She still works for â€• and consistently defends â€• a notorious misogynist accused by more than a dozen women of sexual misconduct.

The Trump administration, Haleyâ€™s team, has worked relentlessly to curtail womenâ€™s rights, beginning in its earliest days when, surrounded by men, the president signed the so-called global gag rule that bars international health organizations from receiving funding if they mention abortion as a family planning option and may lead to a rise in maternal deaths around the world.

The administration is also working tirelessly to roll back reproductive rights in the U.S., has killed reforms that would have helped close the gender wage gap and has made it more difficult for women to report sexual discrimination.

Still, even if you vehemently object to those policies, Haley does hold an allure. Particularly compared to the handful of women in Trumpâ€™s Cabinet, the most male group of secretaries since the Reagan era. She is clearly an intelligent woman who knows what sheâ€™s talking about. Itâ€™s a low bar, but one Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has had trouble clearing. Haley also hasnâ€™t vanished into obscurity like Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao or Small Business Administrator Linda McMahon. (The fifth woman in the Cabinet is Kirstjen Nielsen, who runs the Department of Homeland Security and recently said she wasnâ€™t sure if Norway is predominantly white to deflect racist comments made by her boss.)

Haley is also clearly better than White House senior adviser Ivanka Trump when it comes to playing the strong, confident female leader in the press â€• even as she backs the administration in its role curbing womenâ€™s rights. Indeed she is strong-willed, competent and principled enough that she seems to now be in danger of losing her job. The New York Times reported on Wednesday that Trump is unhappy with Haley and she may be in line to take a Tillerson-like fall.

Still, Haley is out there defending the White House. She argued in favor of the global gag rule just this week in an interview with Marie Claire. Haley smoothly responded to a question about a possible rise in unsafe abortions, a likely result of the Trump policy, by talking about womenâ€™s rights.

â€œI think the only thing youâ€™re seeing is, instead of us funding and supporting abortions, what weâ€™ve tried to do is fund and support clean facilities where mothers give birth,â€ she said, adding that, though there may be disagreement on abortion, â€œwe should never disagree on the fact that we want the strongest, healthiest, most educated women we can have out there.â€

It was an artful dodge that obscures the harm being done to women by the rule, which human rights groups say is putting millions of women in peril by cutting off access to birth control and crucial health care.

Haley also deflected a question about what itâ€™s like to be a woman in an administration with a â€œchallenging record on womenâ€ by saying she always tells Trump the truth. â€œWhether itâ€™s the #MeToo Movement, whether itâ€™s the rumors, whether itâ€™s facing any other challenges that come along the way, I just try to be as honest as I can,â€ she said.

Haley, who was the first woman ever elected governor in South Carolina, wasnâ€™t always so clearly on team Trump. She first became known nationally when she pushed to remove the Confederate flag from the South Carolina statehouse â€• not exactly a Trumpian move.

And itâ€™s worth noting that back in 2016 Haley was a fairly vocal critic of Trump, specifically calling him out on his rhetoric around Muslims and once even saying Trump was everything a governor wouldnâ€™t want in a president. They even had the requisite Twitter spat, with Trump calling her an embarrassment to the state and Haley hitting back with a classic Southern put-down:
But those days seem long ago.
To Marie Claire, Haley also spoke about often being the only woman in the room. Indeed, there is a definite dearth of women in politics, particularly in the Republican Party.

â€œI push just as hard whether itâ€™s women or men in the room. Iâ€™m not intimidated by men at all,â€ she said. â€œDo I wish there were more women? Always. I would love to have more girlfriends all around me. But until that happens Iâ€™m going to keep trying to represent. What I try to do every day is show itâ€™s doable.â€

Itâ€™s inspiring until you think about the rooms she is operating in now, with a president whoâ€™s making a mockery of our democracy on the world stage and who has at every turn humiliated and undermined women (and men, too).
Sometimes there are no women in the room because the room is a bad place to be.

otherData.headline: Ellen Burstyn Predicts The Future: 'We'll Be The Dogs Of The Robots'
otherData.short_description: The 85-year-old Oscar winner has a lot to say about the singularity, dark energy and humanity's place in the universe.

articleContent: Ellen Burstyn is good at talking.

Seated in her living room overlooking Central Park on a brisk February afternoon, a wire-haired pooch perched at her feet, Burstyn registers as thoughtful, engaged and exceedingly well-read. Cluttered bookshelves line the walls. Crystals garnish the windowsill near our armchairs. A white piano sits across the room. Art from all corners of the globe hangs throughout her apartment, evincing an 85-year-old life full of adventures.

As quickly as we delve into the annals of her career â€• from an auspicious Broadway debut to defining roles in â€œThe Last Picture Show,â€ â€œAlice Doesnâ€™t Live Here Anymore,â€ â€œThe Exorcist,â€ â€œRequiem for a Dream,â€ â€œDivine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood,â€ â€œInterstellarâ€ and â€œHouse of Cardsâ€ â€• the conversation shifts to Burstynâ€™s spiritual fortification. Sheâ€™s as infatuated with the cosmos and metaphysical ideology as she is anything to do with Hollywood, where she has gone from primo leading lady to venerated elder stateswoman.

In the next several weeks, Burstyn will appear in two movies: â€œThe House of Tomorrowâ€ (opening April 27) and â€œThe Taleâ€ (premiering May 26 on HBO). In the former, sheâ€™s an environmentally conscious grandmother obsessed with Buckminster Fuller, an architect and theorist who popularized the term â€œSpaceship Earthâ€ (and a real-life friend of Burstynâ€™s; more on that later). In the latter, which was one of the most renowned films at Sundance this year, sheâ€™s a mother whose globetrotting daughter (Laura Dern) is reinvestigating a sexually abusive episode from her childhood. Onscreen, Burstyn has always had a crisp elocution that wobbles only to reveal charactersâ€™ vulnerability â€• a trait seen in both â€œThe House of Tomorrowâ€ and â€œThe Tale.â€

For an hour, Burstyn and I had a conversation so articulate and wide-ranging we must have solved at least some of the worldâ€™s problems. We discussed the state of American politics, her Vietnam War protests in the 1970s, the injury she sustained on â€œThe Exorcist,â€ the evolution of Hollywood and, yes, the mysteries of the universe.

â€œThe Tale,â€ which I saw at Sundance, is going to be a big conversation starter about sexual abuse. Itâ€™s a weird movie to love because itâ€™s so difficult to process, but itâ€™s really remarkable, especially because itâ€™s autobiographical.

I think so, too. I think the way [director Jennifer Fox] mixed the two â€” documentary and narrative â€” is so unusual and innovative. Itâ€™s a lot of things. Itâ€™s an exploration of memory and itâ€™s an expose of the seduction of children and young people. I think we always have an idea of an abuser as being ugly. I mean, when I met [Fox], she was still referring to [the predator seen in the movie] as her first boyfriend. So it was the whole process of investigating it and reawakening the memory when she started to think about it. I immediately liked her. Have you seen her?
Oh yes, I saw her speak at the Sundance premiere.
You know, I got in such trouble for that remark.
For speaking out against Trump during the Q&A afterward? What kind of trouble?
Oh, just Twitter outrage.
Oh, of course. Do you pay attention to all of that?
Iâ€™ve never experienced anything like that before. My remark just came out because I was so unsettled by the film. Itâ€™s a little elusive.
How does social media fodder get filtered to you? How do you find out people are saying certain things about you in certain contexts?
People tell me.
People being â€”
My family. My son. I try not to get into that too much. I just say, â€œOK.â€
Not that youâ€™re someone whoâ€™s stoked a lot of outrage throughout your career, but do you have a more zen approach to that now than you did in the past?

Probably. Probably I would have been more upset when people say bad things about me, but I have learned over the years how to separate it â€” not taking it personally, necessarily, not letting the knife go in, just saying, â€œThatâ€™s them. OK.â€ I probably shouldnâ€™t have said anything.
From where I was sitting, it seemed invigorating. The audience certainly responded to it.

Well, the thing is, I always forget that what I say in a room is going to leave the room. If I had been on TV, I probably wouldnâ€™t have said it. But I was with like-minded people, so I didnâ€™t censor myself. But no, I should know that lesson by now. It always gets out somehow. Whatever.
Was there a time in your career when you didnâ€™t handle criticism as well?

Oh yeah, when I first started out, I started with a lead on Broadway [in â€œFair Gameâ€]. In my first interview for a newspaper, I had lunch and I talked. And then when I read it, I went, â€œOh my god.â€ I had to learn that what you say actually gets into print. Itâ€™s easy to forget.
Before that Broadway debut, youâ€™d been a nightclub dancer and a model. Did you feel welcomed among the serious theater crowd?

Well, I auditioned and I got the part. It was the part of a model, so there was some reasonable decision-making. And Moss Hart was there. He was the one that told me I got the part, so if itâ€™s OK with Moss Hart, it should be OK with everyone else. And then when I did the play, there were people in the play â€” one guy in particular â€” who were very resentful of me doing a lead on Broadway when I hadnâ€™t studied or anything. There was resentment, but that was my journey and that was how it started. What are you going to do?

Youâ€™ve talked about deciding you werenâ€™t ready to be a lead actress while making â€œGoodbye Charlieâ€ in 1964. But fast-forward a decade and you were one of, if not the, primo actresses of the â€™70s.

Well, I had that moment when I auditioned for â€œFair Game.â€ I said, â€œOK, Iâ€™ve decided to be an actress. Iâ€™m going to do a Broadway play this fall. Does anybody know how I get an audition?â€ It was that moment. The thing with â€œGoodbye Charlie,â€ I was on the set and I had that thought, OK, next step is I play Debbie Reynoldsâ€™ part. And then this voice in my head that speaks to me every once in a while said [in a low, guttural tone], â€œI donâ€™t want it.â€ I was shocked. I mean, when that voice speaks, I donâ€™t budge.
What does that voice sound like?

It doesnâ€™t sound like my voice, or a male or a female voice. Itâ€™s just a voice, and itâ€™s always flat. Just, boom. When it speaks, I donâ€™t have any doubt that thatâ€™s the truth. Sometimes I think of it as an inner teacher, but I donâ€™t know if thatâ€™s really what it is. I donâ€™t know what it is. So that was the moment when I left Hollywood and went back to New York and studied with Lee Strasberg. Thatâ€™s what it meant to me: I didnâ€™t want that career when I saw I was on that track. I wanted to learn how to really act.
Studying was the reaction to the voice?
Investigating the art form, as opposed to doing what comes naturally and getting by on whatever comes without really knowing.
Or chasing the fame, knowing that a lead role in a Hollywood production often equates some level of fame. You never set that as a goal. The fame followed the craft.
Thatâ€™s a good way to say it.
The New York Times did once say you were the most honored and respected actress of the 1970s. Did you feel that at the time?

No. Somebody asked me once, â€œWell, what was it like to be working in the golden age of Hollywood?â€ I said, â€œNobody told me it was the golden age.â€ I was on the jury of the Cannes Film Festival, and I was reading about the festival in a newspaper, and they were writing about the jurors. They said, â€œEllen Burstyn, considered the most intelligent actress in Hollywood.â€ I said, â€œI am?! I didnâ€™t know that! Why doesnâ€™t somebody tell me these things?â€ I donâ€™t know, itâ€™s weird.
And who is on the committee that lines up every actress and ranks her according to intelligence?
Right, exactly. Who considers? And how did you hear about that?
What did you do with your first big paycheck?

What comes to mind is my piano. That was in Detroit. I was very happy to be able to buy a piano. I took it with me. When I went to New York, it came with me. When I went to California, it came with me. I finally sold it. I think my son was 2, and Iâ€™d finally let go of this piano.
At 85, do you find yourself yearning for anything?

You know, I yearn for things. Iâ€™d like to understand the cosmos better. I spend a lot of time thinking about, â€œWhat is dark energy? What could be it be? What could it mean that we know itâ€™s there but we donâ€™t know what it is? And if we donâ€™t know what it is, then maybe itâ€™s an alternate universe.â€ So I spend a lot of time out there. Iâ€™m yearning to know, Iâ€™m yearning to understand.
And religion is important to you.
Spirituality.
How has that evolved over the years? How would you have answered the question â€œWhat does spirituality mean to youâ€ in 1970 compared to how you answer it today?

Well, I was brought up Catholic, and I rejected that around 17. For a few years, I just read about science. I wasnâ€™t religious at all, but I felt this yearning. It felt like something was missing. So then I started reading various kinds of spiritual books, and then I came upon â€” have you ever heard of Gurdjieff? Gurdjieff was a teacher who came from the Caucasus between the two wars in Europe. He had a school, and people went there and did work on themselves. And I read his books and books by other people who studied with him, and I got interested in that work because it was really work on getting conscious.

And then I found out that he was a Sufi, and then I got interested in Sufism. And then I found a Sufi teacher â€” an Englishman â€” and I went to Europe and studied with him for a while, and then I met somebody he was associated with, and he became my teacher. Now, Sufis traditionally are Islamic, but my teacher wasnâ€™t. He welcomed all, so there were Jewish Sufis and Catholic Sufis, and it was spiritual work without being identified with a religion. I notice that on the internet they say Iâ€™m Islamic. Iâ€™m not. Iâ€™ve never been, nor do I want to be, associated with any one religion. Iâ€™m interested in all of the various approaches to the divine, to the sacred ground, whatever that is.
I want to understand the whole thing. I want to understand what itâ€™s all about.
And where has that led you today?

Right now Iâ€™m reading an ecotheologian. His name is Thomas Berry. I was introduced to him by a woman whoâ€™s a professor at Yale University. Heâ€™s into the sacred connectedness to nature, or in nature, as opposed to separate from nature. Because weâ€™re separate from it, thatâ€™s why the earth is suffering so much. Thatâ€™s why we can abuse it so badly. Iâ€™m just into exploring all these realms, being open to them and not saying, â€œThis is what I believe and everything else is wrong.â€

Maybe you donâ€™t think about it this concretely, but how much do you think that spiritual quest has informed you a storyteller, as an actress inhabiting othersâ€™ lives, in terms of both the roles youâ€™ve chosen over the years and how you piece those roles together?

Well, Iâ€™ve never thought about it, but thank you for asking that question. I think it would have to. You know, empathy is such a large part of an actorâ€™s work â€” feeling into the character and into other human beings. Empathy seems to me to be one of the virtues that weâ€™re blessed with. I think itâ€™s a large part of my work. Now, how that connects with the spiritual explorations, Iâ€™m not sure â€” except that I do feel compassion for my characters, whatever their story is. I try to offer that up. I do think whatever makes us deeper as human beings makes us richer as artists.

Thinking back to the Twitter outrage from the Sundance premiere, how are you working through the current political turmoil and what led us to a Trump presidency, in light of having educated yourself about larger forces influencing the world?

You know, my first Sufi teacher used to say, â€œEverything manifests in reverse.â€ So we achieved the first black president, and this is the reaction. Itâ€™s a pendulum swing. I trust that we will survive it and will get back to some center. Itâ€™s very painful.
When â€œRequiem for a Dreamâ€ opened in 2000, you talked about a conversation with a doctor friend of yours, saying you both felt like the state of medicine and other professions â€”
The standards were lower?

Yes. And then in August 2016, you said, â€œI donâ€™t believe Trumpâ€™s going to win. I donâ€™t believe the universe will allow it.â€ We all said that around August 2016. But those two ideas seem to work hand in hand: the degradation of professional standards and Trumpâ€™s ability to become president. Do you think thereâ€™s a connection there?

Probably. When I think about my childhood, we didnâ€™t lock the doors when I was in Detroit. So in the years that Iâ€™ve spent on the planet, thereâ€™s been a huge change. Social media has made it possible for the alt-right to speak to other alt-right people on the other side of the country that they didnâ€™t know were there. Theyâ€™re more organized, there are more of them. There are a lot of things that, as we developed technology, have advanced us in many ways, but at the same time the reverse goes along with it. So how we handle it and get out of it and grow with it, I donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s very scary and weâ€™re in the midst of it.
When there was the Industrial Revolution, that was such a huge change in the culture. Weâ€™re in that kind of revolution â€” social revolution â€” and we donâ€™t know how itâ€™s going to come out.

Do you know â€” oh, whatâ€™s that word? The moment where technology advances to the point where it takes over. I lose this word a lot. The singularity! And when we get there â€” weâ€™ve never been there in the history of the planet â€” we have no idea whatâ€™s going to happen. Somebody has suggested that possibly we will become pets to the technology, however itâ€™s manifesting. Weâ€™ll be the dogs of the robots. We have no idea what weâ€™re in for.
Did you consider yourself politically active in the â€™70s?

Well, donâ€™t forget there was the Vietnam War. I was very active during that. I was in the streets in Los Angeles. At the first Women Strike for Peace march, I was pushing my kid in a baby carriage. And I was with a group called STOP, Speakers and Talent Organize for Peace. We went out speaking to Rotary Clubs against the war. I was at the Democratic Convention in 1968. I was at a fundraiser for Eugene McCarthy when Martin Luther King was assassinated. We were supporting Martin Luther King, and we expected when Bobby Kennedy got California that he would get the nomination and we would then change our votes to Kennedy, and then he got assassinated. So Iâ€™ve always been political, and Iâ€™ve always been a Democrat.

How much do you think being around Hollywood at the time further galvanized your activism? Obviously Jane Fonda is a figurehead for celebrity politics in the â€™70s, but the decadeâ€™s upheaval really defined Hollywood, on-screen and off.

I donâ€™t know, itâ€™s hard to say. I think, if I were still living in Detroit, I would have been against that war. We were in an unjust war, just like we are now in the Mideast. I think I just happened to live in Los Angeles at the time, but I think wherever I was thatâ€™s what I would have been doing: fighting.

Letâ€™s talk about a few movies. Did you pay attention to the news about Uma Thurmanâ€™s injury on the set of â€œKiIl Billâ€? Her lack of protection sounds similar to what happened to you on the set of â€œThe Exorcist,â€ where you permanently injured your spine after being pulled to the ground for a stunt. You had asked your director, William Friedkin, to have the stuntman pull you more gently, but he didnâ€™t listen.

Well, I wasnâ€™t talked into doing it. I was telling him, â€œNo, heâ€™s pulling me too hard.â€ I was aware that I was in danger, and I said it. [Friedkin] went behind my back. So I didnâ€™t agree to it. I think finally Uma did â€” I donâ€™t know that for a fact, but from what I understand, she got talked into it. One does have to finally be able to say no, which I did. I mean, people have died making movies, especially stunt people. So one has to really learn how to protect oneself. I wouldnâ€™t ever be in that position again.
Did you ever have any experiences like that again, where you were taken advantage of on a set?
No.
Do you think itâ€™s because that experience firmed you up?
Maybe. Possibly. People donâ€™t mess with me too much.

Thatâ€™s good. Youâ€™ve talked many times over the years about having a hand in selecting a young Martin Scorsese to direct â€œAlice Doesnâ€™t Live Here Anymore.â€ If that movie were being made today, there might be some sort of conversation about whether a woman should make it. I assume there were no women for you to lobby for at the time?

No. Absolutely not. Although I have to say, an executive did ask me to direct it, and I said I didnâ€™t want to act and direct at the same time. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m doing now [with the comedy â€œBathing Floâ€]. And I was right. It wouldnâ€™t have been as good a movie.

Thereâ€™s a scene in â€œHouse of Tomorrowâ€ where your character watches footage of your younger self and processes her former life. It made me think about what itâ€™s like for you to be interviewed. Is it cathartic to be asked to recall the details of your younger self? Is it redundant? Intrusive?

Well, I shot that footage and had it to offer to the director, which he didnâ€™t know when he asked me to do the film. He didnâ€™t know that I knew [architect and theorist Buckminster Fuller, who appears in the footage] and that I had shot the film with him. It was pretty serendipitous. When people ask me, â€œWell, why did you shoot that film?â€ I donâ€™t know. I just did. I have no explanation for it. I shot that 40 years ago. Forty? Thirty anyway. Between 30 and 40. And of course I donâ€™t know if everybody knows itâ€™s real when they see it.

It was wonderful to be able to offer it to the director when he offered me the part not knowing I was friends with Bucky. He was an amazing man. I was really grateful to know him. He was a great mind. Have you ever read any of his books?
I havenâ€™t.
Heâ€™s a very strange writer. He makes up languages. He combines words into new words. Iâ€™ll show you. [Burstyn rises from the seat and retrieves a well-worn hardback book from a bookshelf.]

I have a lot of his books, most of them. Well, no. He wrote 30 books, and I donâ€™t have 30. This one is actually autographed to me by him. [She opens to a passage called â€œIntuition: Metaphysical Mosaic,â€ written in verse, and hands me the book.] Read this.
[I proceed to read the two-page passage, which concludes with the line â€œThis is why consciousness identified the basic increment of time as being a second.â€]

Thatâ€™s the way he writes. And by the way, thatâ€™s his definition of God: the a priori mystery, the mystery that exists before anything. He defines â€œuniverseâ€ as a series of partially overlapping, simultaneous events. Thatâ€™s the way his thinking is multidimensional. With his writing, Iâ€™m like, â€œWhat, Bucky?! What are you saying?â€
How did you meet him?

I was interested in Margaret Fuller, who was an associate of Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau. I thought she was a great 19th-century woman writer and editor of their newspaper, The Dial. I was thinking about her and reading about her â€” I had many books â€” and I was also reading about him. He gave a lecture at Carnegie Hall while I was shooting â€œThe Exorcist.â€ I went to the lecture, and while I was sitting there, I went, â€œMargaret Fuller, Buckminster Fuller, Boston.â€ I made the connection, and I wrote to him and told him I was interested in talking to him about his aunt. His secretary called back and said, â€œYou can have two hours in the Boston airport at this date, or you can have five hours in the Chicago airport on this date.â€ So I picked the Chicago airport and flew there, and we had five hours together. Then we became friends. He was an amazing man.

You mentioned earlier not knowing the â€™70s were a golden age. Today when we talk about the â€™70s, we talk about the decadeâ€™s movies in very political terms. They were responses to the Vietnam War and social change and second-wave feminism and so forth. In thinking about â€œThe House of Tomorrowâ€ and â€œThe Tale,â€ as well as the other movies youâ€™ve made in recent years, do you think todayâ€™s movies, or more specifically todayâ€™s studios â€”
[Burstyn shakes her head.]

OK, maybe not the studios. Letâ€™s say todayâ€™s filmmakers. Do you think the type of filmmakers youâ€™re involved with â€” the type whose movies premiere at festivals, for example â€” are making movies that respond to todayâ€™s political and social mores the way we say movies in the â€™70s did?
Well, â€œMudboundâ€ did. â€œGet Outâ€ did. â€œShape of Waterâ€ kind of does. â€œFlorida Projectâ€ did. â€œThree Billboards,â€ kind of. â€œThe Post.â€ So I think the answerâ€™s yes.

We both shook our heads when I mentioned studios. But most of the movies you named are not getting the type of attention that â€œAlice Doesnâ€™t Live Here Anymoreâ€ got when Warner Brothers released it in â€™74.
No. No. No, the studios are doing â€œSpider-Man 12.â€ Thatâ€™s the brand. The filmmakers are in the independent film world. Itâ€™s a different business.
You had an Oscar nomination in 1981 and then a gap until your next, for â€œRequiemâ€ in 2001. By that point, Oscar campaigning had ballooned into an entire industry. Did you notice that shift?

Well, I know, for instance, with â€œRequiem,â€ that we didnâ€™t have money for a campaign, and that made a huge difference. I still have people go by me on the street and go, â€œYou were robbed.â€ Iâ€™ve had that experience more than once. And it wasnâ€™t originally a problem not to have money for a campaign.
It hurt the movieâ€™s chances in a way that it might not have 20 years earlier.

Right. I think. Not to take anything away from Julia Roberts, who was wonderful in â€œErin Brockovich.â€ But they had a wonderful campaign, and we didnâ€™t. Itâ€™s not reasonable to think you can get by without a campaign, not anymore.
I recently watched the pilot of â€œThe Ellen Burstyn Show,â€ which only lasted 13 episodes. What happened with that show?

otherData.headline: Cardi B Doesn't Owe You Anything
otherData.short_description: Remember: Cardi's success is not ours.

articleContent: Fresh off the debut of her new record, â€œInvasion of Privacy,â€ Cardi B addressed reactions to her revelation on â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ that she is pregnant. These things were intertwined, the album and the baby, if not in reality then in the hyperreality Cardi B inhabits. Both were treated by certain corners of the public as bits of creative output to be consumed and judged, and last week on the â€Ebro in the Morningâ€ radio show on New Yorkâ€™s Hot 97, Cardi B seemed annoyed with this arrangement.
Itâ€™s just like, you know what? Iâ€™m a grown woman. Iâ€™m 25 years old. Iâ€™m going to say this in the most humblest way: Iâ€™m a millionaire. And Iâ€™m prepared for this.
She went on a little later:

I see a lot of women online like, â€™Oh, I feel sorry for you, oh your career is over.â€² And itâ€™s like, why canâ€™t I have both? As a woman, why canâ€™t I have both? Why do I gotta choose a career or a baby? Like, why canâ€™t I have both? I want both.

Cardiâ€™s frustration is understandable, but so, too, is the public preoccupation with her rise to fame. For the first time there was tension in what had been an unprecedentedly sunny relationship between Cardi and her fans, and it told us something about stardom based the sort of authenticity Cardi embodies. People cherish authenticity in a celebrity, it seems, until the celebrity is too authentically a person of her own.

The affection for Cardi isnâ€™t hard to understand. Everybody loves an underdog story. In fact, thereâ€™s a science behind our need to root for the underdog, the unlikely hero, the rags-to-riches story. Psychological studies exploring this phenomenon, specifically in sports, have found that people are more likely to root for teams they perceive to be putting in â€œmore effort with less ability,â€ because it creates a compelling narrative.

Cardi B is the ultimate underdog. She is, by her own description, just a â€œregular degular girl from the Bronx,â€ a former stripper who leveraged her charisma and humor and authenticity on social media into a rap career.

Throughout a three-year trajectory, from Instagram star to reality TV star to hip-hop princess, Cardi surmounted obstacles. She was dismissed as a rapper because she is a woman and a former sex worker. She was too unapologetically ratchet ever to win over the respectability crowd. She was too Dominican and too 161st Street ever to be taken seriously by the country at large. Classism, racism, misogyny â€” she seemed to fly directly into all the usual cultural headwinds and wound up a superstar anyway.

But having her own life constantly served up for the purposes of vicarious identification brought its own set of problems, as evidenced by the conversation about Cardiâ€™s pregnancy. On blogs like The Shade Room and Industry on Blast, indeed in the comment sections of her own Instagram, people reacted with pity, confusion, even downright disdain toward Cardiâ€™s pregnancy. The comments have come from haters and fans alike.

The give and take of fame is always tricky, especially in the age of social media. Cardi gained popularity, after all, by sharing nearly every aspect of her life on the â€™Gram, something sheâ€™s always been proud of. On the song â€œBest Lifeâ€ from her new album, she raps, â€œNever been afraid to show yâ€™all the real me/hair when itâ€™s fucked up/crib when itâ€™s filthy.â€

Part of Cardiâ€™s charm is how transparent sheâ€™s been about her past, about the fact that she is, essentially, winging this fame thing. This quality is also what makes â€œInvasion of Privacyâ€ such a great record â€• an album that hops from thot anthems like â€œBickenheadâ€ to confessional ballads like â€œBe Carefulâ€ in which Cardi admits that Offset, her (allegedly) cheating fiancÃ©, has â€got me trippinâ€™/got me lookinâ€™ in the mirror different/Thinkinâ€™ Iâ€™m flawed because you inconsistent...â€

But she gives so much of herself that it has created a sense of ownership for her fans, not just over her work but over her personal choices. This has always been an aspect of the transaction of fame, but it has been intensified in the digital era, in which people mistake what they are shown or indeed what they share for actual intimacy.

Cardiâ€™s life itself is seen now as a performance in which her fans have a stake. This is how we wound up with people evaluating Cardiâ€™s pregnancy as if it were a new album â€” as if it were something about which aesthetic objections could be made.

The misogyny of criticizing Cardiâ€™s decision to have a child should go without saying, as should the misogyny of the double standard whereby some people question how she will juggle a baby and a career, but never ask the same of her fiancÃ©, Offset, who already has three children from previous relationships. Thereâ€™s an irony in this. She has soared beyond the sexism of the champagne room and the recording studio, only to find some of her own fans throwing it back at her in the comments of her own Instagram.

Cardiâ€™s crime was undermining other peopleâ€™s illusions. She had conjured a fantasy for people â€” anyone can make it on oneâ€™s own terms; anyone can find fame and fortune without losing oneself. And now the very real obligations of a child had intruded on that illusion. An unplanned pregnancy? That was too messily commonplace for anyoneâ€™s vicarious daydreaming. Fans want Cardi to be authentic, sure, but not to herself. They want her to be authentic to their fantasy.

And how does Cardi B feel about all this? During her performance at Coachella on Sunday, she wore all-white, her hair swept up and out in a style reminiscent of the late Lisa â€œLeft Eyeâ€ Lopes. She was visibly, heavily pregnant. As rapper YG paced the Coachella stage beside her, chanting at the crowd, â€œDat ass, dat ass, dat ass, dat ass,â€ Cardi dropped down low, twerked, flipped over and, holding herself up by her arms and bent knees, humped the air. If this wasnâ€™t a declaration of â€œI donâ€™t care what you think,â€ nothing is. It was a â€œfuck you,â€ authentically so.

Nassar, who also was Michigan State University team doctor, has been accused of sexually abusing over 260 young athletes under the guise of medical treatment. Heâ€™s now serving three concurrent prison sentences of up to 175 years for sexual assault and child pornography.
Maroney told Guthrie that Nassar groomed her by bringing her food â€• a show of affection in a sport that consistently starves its athletes.

Maroney signed a confidentiality settlement with USA Gymnastics in December 2016 barring her from sharing her story. The organization said in January it wouldnâ€™t seek to punish Maroney if she chose to break the agreement.

articleContent: An airman in the Tennessee National Guard has been removed from her position and is facing administrative actions after she appeared to use a dinosaur hand puppet to take her re-enlistment oath.

Master Sgt. Robin Brown, a senior noncommissioned officer with the Tennessee Joint Public Affairs Office, appeared to re-enlist Friday for the Guard by holding a dinosaur puppet in her right hand as she took the oath, according to WKRN-TV.

The ceremony was reportedly not an official re-enlistment, just something Brown created for her children, according to Air Force Times, which pointed out that in a screenshot of a conversation on an Air Force Facebook forum, someone claiming to be from the Tennessee Military Department said it was â€œnot an official reenlistment.â€
The person on the forum added that Brown â€œwas trying to create something her younger children would enjoy.â€
But senior officers werenâ€™t pleased when a video of the ceremony went viral on Facebook.
Lt. Gen. L. Scott Rice, director of the Air National Guard, griped about the video on his own Facebook page, saying it mocked â€œa cherished and honorable occasionâ€:

This action goes against our very foundation. Tennessee National Guard leadership is aware and addressing the issue. ... This single act does not reflect the selfless dedication and professionalism shown everyday by the outstanding Airmen of our Air National Guard in their service to our great nation.
On Wednesday, Brown was removed from her post at the Tennessee Guardâ€™s joint public affairs office, and she could be facing further administrative action, according to Military.com.

otherData.headline: Trump: 'Human Trafficking Is Worse Than It's Ever Been In The History Of The World'
otherData.short_description: The president is using the specter of human trafficking to push his U.S.-Mexico border wall.

articleContent: In comments advocating a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border on Thursday, President Donald Trump said, â€œHuman trafficking is worse than itâ€™s ever been in the history of the world.â€

â€œDrugs are flowing into our country,â€ he told reporters while visiting the Joint Interagency Task Force South in Key West, Florida. â€œWe need border protection. We need the wall. We have to have the wall. The Democrats donâ€™t want to approve the wall because they think itâ€™s good politically, but itâ€™s not.â€

He continued: â€œIf you look at whatâ€™s happening in California with sanctuary cities â€” people are really going the opposite way. They donâ€™t want sanctuary cities. Thereâ€™s a little bit of a revolution going on in California. Human trafficking is worse than itâ€™s ever been in the history of the world.â€

Though Trump did not clarify what metric he was using or whether he had accounted for world population growth, human trafficking is a critical issue today. According to the International Labor Organization, there are an estimated 24.9 million people around the world who are trapped in forced labor. Of those, 16 million are exploited for labor in the private sector, 4.8 million are sexually exploited, and 4.1 million forced into state-imposed labor.

Most victims of forced labor or sexual exploitation are in the Asia and Pacific regions. More relevant to Trumpâ€™s border wall, though, is human trafficking in the Americas, which accounts for roughly 1 percent of forced labor and 4 percent of sexual exploitation in the world, according to the ILO.

But the presidentâ€™s conflation of immigration with human trafficking serves an agenda. He has warned of â€œcaravansâ€ threatening to shuttle waves of dangerous immigrants across the U.S.-Mexico border â€• a fear-mongering tactic that echoes racist and derogatory comments he made on the campaign trail and in the first year of his presidency.

His comment also did not appear to address one of the most glaring historical examples of human trafficking: the centuries-long trans-Atlantic slave trade, during which over 10 million people were forcibly shipped from parts of Africa to North America, the Caribbean, and Central and South America.
The president has previously emphasized his commitment to fighting human trafficking, including in comments he made to law enforcement officials in Long Island, New York, last year.

â€œHuman traffickers. This is a term thatâ€™s been going on from the beginning of time, and they say itâ€™s worse now than it ever was,â€ he said, according to CNN. â€œYou go back 1,000 years, where you think of human trafficking, you go back 500 years, 200 years, 100 years, human trafficking, they say â€• think of it, what they do â€• human trafficking is worse now, maybe, than itâ€™s ever been in the history of this world.â€

Under the Trump administration, there were over 8,500 U.S. cases of human trafficking reported in 2017 â€• an increase of almost 1,000 reported incidents from the previous year, according to the National Human Trafficking Hotline.

CORRECTION: A previous version of this story misstated a statistic from the ILO about forced labor. The organization estimates 24.9 million people are trapped in forced labor, but more are trapped in â€œmodern-day slavery.â€
