otherData.headline: Activists Score Big Victory For Medicaid Expansion In Utah
otherData.short_description: A campaign to cover 150,000 uninsured people has collected enough signatures to put the question before voters this November.

articleContent: Utah voters are on the verge of getting a chance this November to do what the stateâ€™s GOP leaders wonâ€™t: expand health coverage to an estimated 150,000 low-income adults.

Utah Decides Healthcare, a coalition of activist groups, health care organizations and consumer advocates, submitted enough signatures from Utahns to place an initiative on the ballot this November that would expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act, the organization announced in a press release Monday. State officials have to review the signatures and are expected to decide next month whether enough are valid to put the initiative on the ballot.
Utah is one of three states where voters may get an opportunity to go around their governors and legislators to expand Medicaid.

There are similar campaigns underway in Idaho and Nebraska. Mainers voted for the Medicaid expansion last year, making it the first state to enact the policy through direct voter action. Maine Gov. Paul LePage (R), however, has thus far refused to implement the Medicaid expansion.

The Affordable Care Actâ€™s authors intended a nationwide expansion of Medicaid eligibility to anyone earning up to 133 percent of the federal poverty level, which is about $16,000 a year for a single person and $33,000 for a family of four. In 2012, however, the Supreme Court ruled that states could opt out of the expansion.

Utah, Idaho and Nebraska are among the 18 states that have refused to participate. The federal government covers at least 90 percent of the cost of the expansion, with states responsible for the remainder.

Medicaid expansion has been a subject of debate in Utah since the Supreme Court ruling. At times, Gov. Gary Herbert (R) has expressed support for some form of expansion, but it hasnâ€™t gained enough support in the majority-Republican legislature to move forward.

The Utah Senate approved a privatized version of the expansion two years ago, but the state House didnâ€™t act on it. Last year, the state implemented a small Medicaid expansion targeting about 6,000 homeless people and low-income people with substance-use and mental health problems.

In March, Herbert signed a bill that would expand Medicaid eligibility to up to 100 percent of the poverty level, which is about $12,000 for a single person and $25,000 for a family of four. The move would extend coverage to an estimated 72,000 people.
That partial expansion, however, depends on federal approval, which isnâ€™t assured.

The Affordable Care Act is explicit that the extra federal money available to states for broadening Medicaid eligibility only applies to expansions to 133 percent of poverty. President Barack Obamaâ€™s administration wouldnâ€™t permit these partial expansions, and President Donald Trumpâ€™s administration would be on shaky legal ground if they approved Utahâ€™s request. The Trump administration last month declined to approve Arkansasâ€™ request to scale back its Medicaid expansion to 100 percent of poverty.
Medicaid expansion enjoys the support of a majority of Utahns, according to a poll conducted in January by The Salt Lake Tribune and the University of Utahâ€™s Hinckley Institute of Politics.

The survey found that 62 percent of the stateâ€™s residents want to see Medicaid expanded. That includes 51 percent of Republicans who were polled, along with 93 percent of Democrats, the Tribune reported in February.

Utah Decides Healthcare had to collect 113,143 signatures by Sunday to put expansion on the ballot, a figure that represents 10 percent of the number of Utahns who voted in the 2016 presidential election. In addition, the signatures had to come from across the state, with at least 10 percent of 2016 presidential voters in 26 of 29 state Senate districts.
In the end, the coalition met the geographic requirements and exceeded the overall threshold by gathering signatures from more than 165,000 people, Utah Decides Healthcare announced.
Activists in Idaho and Nebraska are hoping to duplicate these results.

Reclaim Idaho, a grassroots outfit founded last year, has until May 1 to collect 56,000 signatures. As in Utah, they must come from all over the state. The total must be at least equal to 6 percent of the stateâ€™s registered voters, and they must meet the same threshold in 18 of Idahoâ€™s 35 state legislative districts.
In Nebraska, a coalition called Insure the Good Life â€• made up of progressive groups and health care advocates, including the Nebraska Hospital Association â€• is leading the campaign.

To put Medicaid expansion on the ballot, activists in Nebraska must gather 85,000 signatures, representing 7 percent of the stateâ€™s registered voters, by July 5. Nebraska also requires that the signatures be from around the whole state, so the activists must get signatures from 5 percent of registered voters in 38 of the stateâ€™s 93 counties.

otherData.headline: Weird 'Walking Dead' Finale Twists Cap Off Weirder Season 8
otherData.short_description: From "butthole cam" to buttheaded moves, the season finale was weirdsville.

articleContent: â€œWalking Deadâ€ Season 8 spoilers below.
For a show that forces us to accept that dead people come back to life, some pretty unbelievable shenanigans have occurred in Season 8 of â€œThe Walking Dead.â€
Sundayâ€™s finale kept to the theme, delivering strange twist after strange twist.

First of all, Eugene (Josh McDermitt) seemingly switched sides again after spending a couple seasons helping Negan (Jeffrey Dean Morgan) and the Saviors. During this episode, he rigged the Saviorsâ€™ bullets to explode in their guns when they tried to shoot Rick (Andrew Lincoln). It was a turning point in the war, leading to the Saviorsâ€™ surrender and Eugeneâ€™s redemption.
But, uh, what?

Just a week ago in the episode â€œWorth,â€ Eugene, who has been aiding the Saviors since Season 7, was briefly kidnapped by Daryl (Norman Reedus) and Rosita (Christian Serratos). He threw up on Rosita in order to escape and get back to the Saviors. If he was planning on switching sides again, why spit up lunch? Why not just tell Daryl and Rosita, â€œIâ€™m rigging all the bullets, so itâ€™s cool.â€ Hmmm.

Back to the finale: After Eugeneâ€™s show of loyalty, Rick slashes Neganâ€™s throat. But then he makes a speech to his followers and the Saviors, stating that heâ€™s in favor of saving Negan and living together as one. A similar scene happens in the comic books, but if this is the plan, Rick, you might want to shorten your speech, because Negan is still lying on the ground bleeding out.

To top it all off, in the most inexplicable twist Maggie (Lauren Cohan), Daryl and Jesus (Tom Payne) are plotting against Rick now. Yeah. They apparently arenâ€™t happy that Rick left Negan alive, so we get a brief scene of them scheming against their former leader.

Sure, earlier in the show thereâ€™s a scene with Jesus preaching to Morgan (Lennie James) about keeping people alive, but whatever. Itâ€™s all just a continuation of the other wild and wacky stuff thatâ€™s happened this season. Letâ€™s look back and reminisce ...
Carl died by tripping and falling.
What was even going on this year? After surviving into Season 8 of the apocalypse and getting shot (twice), Carl (Chandler Riggs) died after tripping and subsequently receiving a bite from a zombie.
The Season 8 finale began with Siddiq (Avi Nash) trying to explain to Rick how Carl died, and it still doesnâ€™t make a ton of sense. Why would Carl be so careless?
(Riggs has poked fun at his characterâ€™s carelessness on Twitter, too.)
Oh, and after he receives the bite, Carl shoots the zombie that bit him. I repeat: he shoots the zombie. Rick after learning Carl had a gun the whole time:
Same, dude. Same.
New rule: Zombie blood now turns you into a zombie.
If you havenâ€™t been keeping up, hereâ€™s a crucial Season 8 revelation for you: Zombie blood can turn people into zombies. Thatâ€™s a thing now.

Though this occurs in the comics, the TV show hadnâ€™t established that being exposed to zombie blood in a wound could turn you. In Season 6, we see Rick cut his hand on a blade thatâ€™s gone through a zombie â€• and heâ€™s totally fine.

This year, that all changed. A bunch of people at the Hilltop were hit with weapons covered in zombie blood and eventually turned into zombies. In the apocalypse, the first thing to die off is continuity.
Wait, another new rule: Everyone turns into a zombie except for Negan.
OK, so you got all that about zombie blood? Good. Now forget that hogwash.

In Season 8, Negan gets in a car crash while riding with a bucket of zombie blood. The blood goes everywhere. Heâ€™s totally fine. Then he gets hit in the arm with his barbed-wire covered baseball bat after itâ€™s been smothered in zombie blood. Heâ€™s cool after that, too.
Who knows why. Just donâ€™t think about it too much.
Finally, introducing butthole vision.
In the â€œWalking Dead,â€ Negan talks a lot about people being assholes, so this just seems like a natural progression.

When Father Gabriel (Seth Gilliam) becomes sick after putting zombie blood and guts on himself early on in Season 8 (see above for new rule on zombie blood), a dose of antibiotics saves him. But he suffers some vision problems thereafter. This gave the show the opportunity to add a funky new POV camera, which the internet has lovingly deemed â€œbutthole cam.â€

The camera view, which is probably not unlike seeing out of oneâ€™s bottom, also makes a brief appearance in Sundayâ€™s finale when Gabriel is trying to escape from Negan in the woods. With so many absurd plot points in Season 8, you canâ€™t blame the internet for being cheeky.

otherData.headline: Sean Hannity Was Apoplectic Over The FBI Raid Of Michael Cohen. Now We Know Why.
otherData.short_description: The Fox News host never disclosed his conflict of interest when covering the raid.

articleContent: Sean Hannity was livid the day that the FBI raided the office and hotel room of Michael Cohen, President Donald Trumpâ€™s longtime personal lawyer. He said it showed that special counsel Robert Mueller was â€œout to get the president,â€ and he blasted the media for giving the raid so much coverage.
â€œThe media, while they are obsessing over Michael Cohen â€• yeah, there are really important stories to bring to you,â€ Hannity said on his Fox News show.
But what he never revealed is why he doesnâ€™t want the media to pay attention to the story: because he is one of Cohenâ€™s clients.

Cohen has done legal work for just three clients since leaving his position last year as counsel for Trumpâ€™s private company. It was previously reported that the first two clients were the president and GOP fundraiser Elliott Broidy.
Broidy had an affair with a former Playboy model. She became pregnant during their relationship, and Cohen helped arrange payments to her to keep her quiet.
On Monday, Cohenâ€™s lawyer revealed that Hannity was Cohenâ€™s third, secret client, although itâ€™s unclear what the nature of the work was.

Cohen is under federal criminal investigation for possible bank fraud, wire fraud and campaign finance violations in connection with his business dealings. The U.S. attorneyâ€™s office in Manhattan is handling the case. Mueller, who is investigating Russiaâ€™s involvement in the 2016 election, referred the matter to the U.S. attorneyâ€™s office but has not been involved since.
Hannity said on his radio show Monday that he has known Cohen â€œa long, long timeâ€ and tried to play down his involvement in his life.

â€œLet me be very clear to the media: Michael never represented me in any matter. I never retained him in the traditional sense. ... I never received an invoice from Michael. I never paid legal fees to Michael,â€ Hannity said. â€œBut I have occasionally had brief discussions with him about legal questions. I wanted his input and perspective. I assumed those conversations were attorney-client confidential.â€
â€œNot one of any issues I ever dealt with Michael Cohen on ever, ever involved a matter between me and a third party,â€ he added.
He also tweeted that his discussions with Cohen were primarily about real estate.

Hannity appears to be specifically trying to put to rest any speculation that he was in a situation similar to Broidy. Federal investigators are also reportedly interested in records Cohen has regarding a payment he made to porn star Stormy Daniels, who claims to have had an affair with Trump and received money from Cohen to stay silent in the run-up to the election.
On Monday, Fox News hosts found themselves in the strange position of reporting breaking news on their own colleague.

Hannity never addressed his conflict of interest in his initial coverage of the Cohen raid. On his radio show on April 9, Hannity said the incident showed â€œthat thereâ€™s no limit at all into the fishing expedition that Mueller is now engaged in and if he has access to everything that his personal attorney has.â€
Jen Bendery contributed reporting.

articleContent: Two-time Olympian Desiree Linden became the first American woman to win the Boston Marathon in 33 years on Monday when she broke the tape at the finish line with a time of 2 hours, 39 minutes, 54 seconds.
Linden, 34, won with a time more than 14 minutes slower than her previous two races, but course conditions were not conducive to personal- or course-record performances.
Fellow American Sarah Sellers was second, 4:10 behind Linden.

In the menâ€™s 26.2-mile race, Japanese amateur Yuki Kawauchi won in 2:15:58, his first major marathon victory. Kawauchi is known in the running community but works full time for the government in Japan and is without sponsorship. He is not regularly viewed as an â€œeliteâ€ marathon runner.

Kawauchi, 31, appeared stunned and emotional at the finish line. While he is a seasoned runner with more than 80 marathon finishes in his career, Mondayâ€™s time in Boston adds to his record number of 2:20-and-under marathon finishes.
The temperature Monday morning at the start line was announced at 30 degrees and rain fell throughout the race, often heavily, to make for a slower overall pace.

The last Japanese man to win the Boston Marathon was Toshihiko Seko in 1987. Kawauchi is the ninth Japanese male to win Boston.

otherData.headline: A New Poll Shows The GOP Is More Trump's Party Than Paul Ryan's
otherData.short_description: The House speaker is well liked within his party, but most Republicans aren't especially sad to see him go.

articleContent: Retiring House Speaker Paul Ryan leaves behind a party thatâ€™s considerably more loyal to President Donald Trump than to him, a new HuffPost/YouGov survey finds.

A 53 percent majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say theyâ€™d support Trump in a hypothetical political disagreement over Ryan, and just 15 percent that theyâ€™d be on Ryanâ€™s side. The results are even starker among Trump voters, who say 63 percent to 12 percent that theyâ€™d side with the president over the outgoing speaker.

The current occupant of the White House, of course, is a natural figurehead for his party. Whether the presidentâ€™s grip on the GOP will strengthen or erode going forward isnâ€™t necessarily clear. Trump is as popular with his base as heâ€™s been in some time. But the current poll finds Trump favored over Ryan by a smaller margin compared to last March, when 62 percent of Republicans and Republican leaners, and nearly three-quarters of Trump voters, said theyâ€™d side with the president. A new NBC/Wall Street Journal poll also found that, for the first time in surveys dating back to last autumn, fewer than half of Republican and Republican-leaning Trump voters identified themselves primarily as supporters of Trump rather than backers of the GOP.

Ryan is still in his partyâ€™s good graces â€• 56 percent of Republicans and Republican leaners say they approve of the job he did as speaker of the House, according to the HuffPost/YouGov survey, while just 27 percent disapprove. That leaves him with a net +29 approval rating, significantly better than the net +8 rating they give the congressional GOP as a whole. Roughly three in 10 say Ryan is doing better than Republicans in Congress as a whole, 41 percent that heâ€™s about the same, and just a tenth that heâ€™s doing worse.

Republicans and Republican leaners are split, however, on their reactions to Ryanâ€™s announcement â€• 26 percent say they wish he wasnâ€™t retiring, and a nearly-equal 28 percent that theyâ€™re happy to see him go. The rest are unsure or profess not to care either way.
Overall, just 12 percent of Americans say they wish Ryan wasnâ€™t retiring, while about a third are happy to see him leave, with the rest unsure or indifferent.

The HuffPost/YouGov poll consisted of 1,000 completed interviews conducted April 11-13 among U.S. adults using a sample selected from YouGovâ€™s opt-in online panel to match the demographics and other characteristics of the adult U.S. population.

otherData.headline: EPA Spending On Scott Pruitt's Soundproof Phone Booth Broke Federal Law, Government Watchdog Finds
otherData.short_description: The agency spent $43,000 on the phone booth.

articleContent: Scott Pruitt, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, broke the law by spending $43,000 to install a soundproof phone booth, a government watchdog concluded in a report released Monday.

The Government Accountability Office found that the EPA violated the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act by spending more than $5,000 on the phone booth without notifying Congress.

The EPA defended the decision to install the phone booth, which it said the administrator required to make classified phone calls to the White House. The GAO declined to rule on the phone boothâ€™s necessity, but said its construction qualified as a furnishing under federal statute, meaning the â€œEPA was required to notify the appropriations committees of its proposed obligation.â€
The agency also found that the EPA violated the Antideficiency Act by spending more than the amount Congress approved.
â€œBecause EPA did not comply with the notification requirement, the funds were not legally available at the time EPA incurred the obligation,â€ the report concludes.

â€œEPA is addressing GAOâ€™s concern, with regard to Congressional notification about this expense, and will be sending Congress the necessary information this week,â€ Liz Bowman, an EPA spokeswoman, said in a statement to HuffPost.

The congressional notification requirement does not carry a penalty for the agency. The EPA could, however, face administrative penalties under the Antideficiency Act. The law allows for criminal prosecution if an agency staffer knowingly violated the statute, but that seems highly unlikely. The Department of Justice has not brought charges against under the Antideficiency Act in modern history.

otherData.headline: Senators Unveil Bipartisan War Authorization Bill

articleContent: WASHINGTON â€• A bipartisan group of senators is taking another crack at making Congress do its job and vote to authorize wars.

Sens. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) and Tim Kaine (D-Va.) on Monday unveiled a new authorization for use of military force, or AUMF, that redefines the limits on President Donald Trumpâ€™s ability to attack non-state terrorist groups around the world. This is not related to Trumpâ€™s recent strikes in Syria.
Their proposal does four things.

Most notably, it expands Trumpâ€™s authority to take military action against al Qaeda, ISIS or the Taliban, wherever they may be geographically. It also authorizes military action against â€œassociated forcesâ€ of those groups.
It repeals a 2002 AUMF that authorized military action in Iraq and a sweeping 2001 AUMF that allowed military action against al Qaeda.

It requires the president to report to Congress any time he sends new forces into a new country. The president has 48 hours to notify Congress, and lawmakers have 60 days to pass legislation to remove that authority if they donâ€™t agree. If lawmakers donâ€™t take any action, the existing authorities stay in place.

Finally, every four years, it requires the president to submit to Congress a plan to repeal, modify or keep the authorizations. If Congress does nothing within 60 days, the existing AUMF stays in place.

â€œFor too long, Congress has given Presidents a blank check to wage war,â€ Kaine said in a statement. â€œWeâ€™ve let the 9/11 and Iraq War authorizations get stretched to justify wars against multiple terrorist groups in over a dozen countries, from Niger to the Philippines. Our proposal finally repeals those authorizations and makes Congress do its job by weighing in on where, when, and with who we are at war.â€
Hereâ€™s a copy of the bill.
Co-sponsors of the bill include Sens. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.), Chris Coons (D-Del.), Todd Young (R-Ind.) and Bill Nelson (D-Fla.).
Corker, who chairs the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has scheduled a hearing to debate, amend and vote on his legislation next week.

â€œThere have been a number of efforts over the years to update these authorities,â€ he said in a statement. â€œI am pleased that we have reached an agreement on a product for the committee to consider and that I hope will ultimately strike an appropriate balance of ensuring the administration has the flexibility necessary to win this fight while strengthening the rightful and necessary role of Congress.â€
The senators get points for pushing an issue that Congress keeps putting off. But theyâ€™ve got serious obstacles ahead.

Republicans, who typically want to give the president as much power as possible to take military action, have reasons to get on board. But this isnâ€™t going to go over well with Democrats who have been pushing for tighter restrictions on the presidentâ€™s ability to start wars, whether itâ€™s by imposing geographic limits or on the number of U.S. troops being deployed. They also wonâ€™t like that this AUMF doesnâ€™t expire.

Then thereâ€™s the issue of Hill leaders letting the bill get a floor vote at all. Congress is constitutionally required to authorize any sustained military action, but House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) have denied war authorization votes for years, for no real reason other than shielding their party members from a politically tough vote.

Congressâ€™ inaction has infuriated a relatively small but bipartisan group of lawmakers who argue they are shirking their role in war-making decisions and letting presidents abuse the never-expired 2001 AUMF.

President Barack Obama stretched the legal limits of the 2001 authorization to unilaterally bomb ISIS, arguing it is an offshoot of al Qaeda. And just last week, Speaker Ryan said Trump could use the 17-year-old war authorization to bomb the Syrian government, which has nothing to do with al Qaeda.
Kaine, who has been loudly calling for a new AUMF for years, said holding a war authorization vote really comes down to lawmakers having a spine or not.

â€œThis is personal to me as the father of a Marine and someone who represents a state so closely connected to the military,â€ he said. â€œCongress has painstakingly avoided this debate for years because war votes arenâ€™t easy. But if weâ€™re going to ask our troops to risk their lives in support of a mission, then we need to at least have the courage to show we are behind them.â€

articleContent: By Roberta Rampton

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A new national security aide to U.S. Vice President Mike Pence stepped down on Sunday, only two days after being officially named to the job, after a behind-the-scenes White House argument hit the headlines, a White House official said.

The appointment of Jon Lerner to Penceâ€™s team was one of the more short-lived personnel moves in a White House known for turbulent staff turnover and infighting, and the first to envelope the vice president, who works hard to stay out of the drama.

Penceâ€™s office had announced on Friday that Jon Lerner, a senior aide to United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley, would become Penceâ€™s top adviser on foreign policy issues. By Sunday night, the vice presidentâ€™s office had issued a second statement that Lerner had withdrawn.
The issue boiled over on Friday, when Pence and his senior staff were on an eight-hour flight to Peru to attend the Summit of the Americas.
President Donald Trump had been become upset, the White House official said, when he was told in error that Lerner was a so-called â€œNever Trumperâ€ - a term that describes anti-Trump Republicans.
Lerner had backed Republican Senator Marco Rubio during the primary race to pick the partyâ€™s candidate ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

Pence phoned Trump and cleared up the tension, the official said. But the short-lived drama became public on Sunday in a report by Axios which said that Trump had initially told his chief of staff John Kelly to ax the appointment and questioned why Pence would have made the pick.
Lerner then offered to withdraw on Sunday night â€œto minimize the amount of conflict and internal drama,â€ the White House official said, and Pence decided it was the best option.
Lerner will continue working for Haley, the official said.
(Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Editing by Michael Perry)

articleContent: â€œHi, itâ€™s Helen,â€ I heard when I picked up the phone Friday afternoon, her pleasant voice a welcome replacement for a publicistâ€™s typical humdrum introduction. I immediately understood this conversation would be between myself and Ms. Helen Hunt, who could navigate my questions herself, thank you very much.

For over four decades, Hunt has affected audiences with her warm smile and natural charisma, appearing in everything from the late 1970s sci-fi series â€œThe Bionic Womanâ€ to Louis C.K.â€™s controversial and critically panned â€œI Love You, Daddyâ€ last year. She won multiple Emmys for her role as Jamie Buchman in the long-running â€™90s TV series â€œMad About Youâ€ and took home an Oscar for â€œAs Good As It Getsâ€ in â€™97. She starred in the films â€œWhat Women Want,â€ â€œPay It Forward,â€ â€œCast Awayâ€ and â€œBobby,â€ to name just a few, before taking a step off screen to focus on writing and directing. Her two projects, â€œThen She Found Meâ€ and â€œRide,â€ solidified Hunt as a blossoming filmmaker, giving her the opportunity to direct episodes of television seriesâ€™ like â€œRevenge,â€ â€œHouse of Lies,â€ â€œFeud,â€ â€œThis Is Usâ€ and â€œSplitting Up Together.â€

But, at 54, Hunt seems eager to get back on our screens and uncover the kinds of roles sheâ€™s long been craving. As an actress whoâ€™s witnessed decades of Hollywood ups and downs, she has strong opinions about her industry and the parts she wants to inhabit in it.

Currently, she can be seen in â€œThe Miracle Season,â€ based on the true story of Iowa Cityâ€™s West High School 2011-12 volleyball team. The squad, after the tragic death of its star player, attempts to conjure up the strength to make it to the state championship alongside tough-love coach Kathy Bresnahan (Hunt). On the phone, sans publicist, we spoke about the movie, the changes sheâ€™s experienced in her ever-changing workplace and, of course, those â€œMad About Youâ€ revival contracts.
Youâ€™re a busy woman these days.
I suddenly got busy after not being busy!
I canâ€™t start this conversation off without mentioning the supposed deals you and Paul Reiser closed for a â€œMad About Youâ€ reboot. Is it a go?

We closed this thing with Sony, who is our studio, which means thatâ€™s great, but thereâ€™s nowhere to do it yet. I read somewhere, â€œTheyâ€™re being coy.â€ Thereâ€™s no being coy, nobodyâ€™s bought it yet, you know what Iâ€™m saying? I mean, at all. [Thereâ€™s] nothing Iâ€™m even hiding. So our enthusiasm is clear, but we donâ€™t have any home for it yet. And we donâ€™t know if we will or if weâ€™ll have one that everybody likes. Seems like it is marching steadily toward â€œI hope it happens.â€

The show is now going to be run by a spectacular writer, Peter Tolan from â€œRescue Meâ€ and â€œMurphy Brown,â€ with me and Paul by his side. Danny Jacobson (the showâ€™s co-creator) will come back and consult, and thatâ€™s great. But weâ€™re really excited that we have Paul and me as the guardians of what it was, and Peter Tolan with new, fresh, smart enthusiasm, whoâ€™s going to be doing a lot of the writing. The cocktail of what it was and something brand new is what has made me excited about it. I canâ€™t think of anyone better than Peter Tolan to be that kind of new breath-of-life into it. Heâ€™s a big element. His sensibility combined with our comfy-with-each-other thing is exciting to me.
To come back with a different spin on it, a different showrunner and possibly a new network must be thrilling.

Yes. I honestly canâ€™t high-five yet because no one may want to buy it or, more possibly, how ever those deals get made might not ever get made. But the prospect of doing it went from seeming absurd to seeming really exciting. Iâ€™ve always been interested with this show: What is it like to love someone over time? Thatâ€™s been the thing that hooked me into doing it in the first place. Itâ€™s one thing to love somebody after a year and itâ€™s another thing to love somebody after seven years. To check in on whatâ€™s the grace and the grit of loving someone after 20 years? Thatâ€™s a pretty terrific prospect, and with a great new writer and my dear friend who I love acting with. If it happens, Iâ€™d be super excited, but I donâ€™t know if itâ€™s going to happen.
I really hope it does, especially with the many platforms out there now aside from the networks who could be interested.
Right, right. Thatâ€™s in the hands of who knows what, but Iâ€™m open to any place thatâ€™s interested in the things weâ€™re interested in.

You and Paul were, in a way, trailblazers for successful TV stars â€• even earning yourself huge pay raises in the final season of â€œMad About You.â€ (They each got a $750k raise, to $1 million an episode.)
Those days are gone [laughs].
But we see these stars now, like Ellen Pompeo, for instance, making a ton of money to remain on hit shows while fighting for what they deserve. Do you see yourself as a pioneer in that world?

It would be hard for me to use that word, but I was very aware that I had, thanks to Paul, been invited into an incredibly generous job in every way. Luckily, I knew enough, even in Season 2 and 3, to say to myself once a day, â€œThis isnâ€™t going to last forever, remember that.â€ Getting to work on 11-page scenes with a scene partner you love working with about something you care about [is amazing]. We didnâ€™t have jerks on the show. There was nobody that made it a drag. It was a particularly lovely group, and Paul and I have remained really great friends, so coming back to all of that would be like, â€œYouâ€™re kidding?â€

Even though we see a lot of solid roles for women and female-led shows and films, theyâ€™re still hard to come by. Are you excited to have the chance to maybe reprise Jamie Buchman and then take on even more roles?

Yes. Iâ€™m about to go work on something that just so happens would be great. Iâ€™m very fired up about my acting at the moment and excited about possibilities that are in front of me and behind me with this movie thatâ€™s out, which Iâ€™m really proud of.
Yes, letâ€™s talk â€œThe Miracle Season.â€ After taking a few years to focus on directing, what about this character, coach Kathy Bresnahan, resonated with you?

I had worked with the director Sean McNamara before on â€œSoul Surfer,â€ so I knew he was a lovely guy and a terrific filmmaker. Thatâ€™s step one. And I knew that there was a wonderful part in there and I just went ahead and started working on it, and I had the help of the real woman I played. It wasnâ€™t until I was standing on the volleyball court dressed like her, surrounded by these 20-something-year-old women that I thought, â€œOh my God. Iâ€™m standing exactly where I should be.â€ In a circle of women, reminding them and myself what their value is. That they can remind themselves of what that value is rather than looking to somebody else, a man in particular, to give it to them. That I could be encouraging and loving with them and still be a fierce leader.

It wasnâ€™t until I was playing the part that I realized that. And then, when the movie came out, I went, not only am I standing in a circle of women, which is where I like to be, but Iâ€™m standing in a circle of women at a time when thatâ€™s, I think, the hope of how to work through this. I have never had an experience of partnering with women around my work or in my friendships when there has been anything other than fierce solidarity. Whatever that myth is about women being competitive with each other, I have never experienced it.
Weâ€™re now in these Me Too and Timeâ€™s Up movements. Do you find that this film fits nicely within this particular moment?

I do. I mean, thereâ€™s a lot of other stories to tell: Thereâ€™s anger to write about and healing â€• or the impossibility of healing to write about. A lot is going to come out of this forever. I heard [the writer and activist] Alice Walker speak once and she said the most important thing [sheâ€™d] done in [her] life was be in a circle with other women and talk. So when I look at the clips from this movie or watch this movie, there they are; standing in a circle, reminding each other and fortifying each other. Thereâ€™s no movie Iâ€™d rather be in today.
Itâ€™s a true story about this slightly unlikeable, tough coach who happens to be a woman. Thatâ€™s a role we usually see played by men, so what was the experience portraying Kathy like for you?

I love sports movies. I mean, I wanted to be Kurt Russell in â€œMiracleâ€ then, so this was my chance. It was a dream come true. I made a sports movie called â€œRideâ€ and I did â€œSoul Surfer,â€ so this is a genre that I adore and this one had this giant piece of heartbreak and soul in the middle of it. It made it the perfect movie for me.
Having a young daughter and being in a movie like â€œMiracle Season,â€ are you excited for her to see it. Well, has she seen any of your iconic roles? â€œTwister,â€ I hope!

She has not seen â€œTwister.â€ I suggested it actually and it hasnâ€™t been on the top of her list. Sheâ€™s not only seen â€œMiracle Season,â€ sheâ€™s in â€œMiracle Season.â€ She has two scenes at the beginning that I had nothing to do with â€• she auditioned and she got the part. Sheâ€™s the younger sister of Erin Moriartyâ€™s love interest. Being on the set surrounded by these wonderful actors-turned-volleyball-players and volleyball-players-turned-actors, they all just treated her like they were her aunties and it was a pretty amazing summer we spent.
Could you see her getting into the business? You started young, soâ€¦
Yeah! It will be utterly and totally up to her.
Over this press cycle, youâ€™ve talked about your fear of â€œsuckingâ€ as an actor.

[Laughs] Itâ€™s just more a motivator. I didnâ€™t see how healing the movie might be to be in or what it might mean to people at the time it came out, I was just busy doing my work. Thereâ€™s a famous line from a play where an actress says, â€œYou have no idea what it feels like to be acting when you know itâ€™s bad.â€ And I quote that to young actors a lot and say, â€œThatâ€™s what makes you do a lot of homework before you start a film.â€ Do I know who this person is? Do I know what my part in the story is? Am I serving what the writer wrote? Just to avoid feeling like youâ€™re not doing a good job.
Looking at past roles that maybe couldâ€™ve happened for you, I stumbled across a rumor that you were considered for â€œBasic Instinctâ€ [before Sharon Stone was cast].
I donâ€™t ever remember being talked about for â€œBasic Instinctâ€ for one second.
Were there any roles you turned down because you felt you couldnâ€™t serve a character or honor the storytellerâ€™s work?

There are. I never want to mention parts Iâ€™ve turned down. The roles Iâ€™ve succeeded in, many of them were turned down by other people, so I donâ€™t want to put my sticky fingers on someone elseâ€™s work. But I certainly turned movies down and regretted it; I turned movies down and said, â€œThank God! Why did I agonize for three weeks?â€ You just make the best decisions you can, you know?

You went on to win Emmys for â€œMad About Youâ€ and an Oscar for â€œAs Good As It Gets.â€ Then you appeared in movies like â€œWhat Women Want.â€ When you look back on that movie, for example, do you still feel like it would have the same success today?

I donâ€™t know, theyâ€™re remaking it, I think? Thatâ€™s what I heard. But the movies I look back on that are the most meaningful to me are probably the two that I wrote and directed, just because they came from the very deepest parts of me â€• one is called â€œThen She Found Meâ€ and the other was called â€œRide.â€ And then I was in this movie â€œThe Sessionsâ€ a handful of years ago and I feel really proud of that movie. I would like it if younger people saw that movie because in this time of being flooded with sexualized violence and porn, you canâ€™t go anywhere now without seeing it or hearing about it. This was a movie about healthy sex, healthy sexuality and I think it was kind of singular and shocking in a quiet way. Iâ€™m very proud to leave that behind â€• not that Iâ€™m going anywhere soon, but Iâ€™m proud that thatâ€™s something I was in and helped to make.
A beautiful movie which got an enormous response at Sundance in 2012.
It did, that was wild.
Were you expecting that kind of reception for the movie and your role in it, which earned you an Oscar nomination?

No, no, no. I had no idea, but I did sit down and there were, whatever there are, 2,000 people in that auditorium or something, and I had never been to Sundance and right before it started I was like, â€œIâ€™m about to be vulnerable in every way in front of all of these people.â€ It was a very quiet screening but there was laughing, which was good, and when it was over, they stood up and they didnâ€™t stop. And I said, â€œWhoa, this has made some sort of impact on people.â€ That was really exciting. I can tell when I read something â€• especially when I watch something, even one episode of a show I otherwise like â€• it will have that sick, frankly, feel to it that deals with sex. So to have a movie that was this intimate, and only feel its honest approach and desire to show what sex can be, I thought was quite remarkable in front of 2,000 people.

It was ahead of the curve weâ€™re seeing now with filmmakers taking bigger risks with their female leads. Women not just playing stereotypes. How does it feel now versus a decade or so ago in terms of the treatment of women in Hollywood and the roles youâ€™re being presented with?

Itâ€™s never been one thing. I canâ€™t say nowâ€™s the time when itâ€™s great. Certainly, thereâ€™s great parts on television for women for sure, but I donâ€™t know how to say this time is different from before in terms of parts. Itâ€™s just all about writers. You just have to nurture and pay [laughs] writers because everybody, men included, are searching for a story and a good writer, and when it comes along, hope theyâ€™re smart enough to grab it.
Is that why you decided to write, direct and produce your own movies? To make the content you wanted to see?

Yeah. Also, writing is step one and discovering the courage to do that was something I wanted to try. When you direct something you wrote, itâ€™s more like getting another chance to rewrite it. Youâ€™re rewriting it with the production design, the music and how youâ€™re photographing it. I guess I wanted to experience getting as close to the bone as possible with creating a story.
And starring in it. Do you always have yourself in mind for these characters?

No, I think itâ€™s, in general, a really bad idea [laughs], in terms of people taking the movie seriously and in terms of enjoying the job of writing and directing it. In these cases [â€œThen She Found Me,â€ â€œRideâ€], both practically and creatively, it ended up being the right move. But I donâ€™t recommend it necessarily.
I imagine itâ€™s difficult to direct yourself.

It is definitely difficult. Itâ€™s also terrific, because on a small movie where time is an issue, you have one person who sees the movie the way you do and is willing to work long hours and change in the van and do whatever it takes to get the movie made. It sets a tone for weâ€™re all going to dig in and get this movie made, even with the amount of time and money that we have. But itâ€™s a very different experience; very immersive, to say the least.
Women directors, in general, have to push even harder to helm projects and fight for budgets. Are you seeing more female directors get a chance to make movies in the menâ€™s club?

Itâ€™s all about money. People have to hire women, #JustHire. Hire women, people of color, women of color â€• that is how this is changing and it will stop changing if people stop doing that. The pressure that people are feeling to hire not only white men has to remain in order for things to change.
Youâ€™ve been directing a lot in the television world with â€œFeud,â€ â€œThis Is Usâ€ and â€œSplitting Up Together,â€ among other shows. Have you seen a shift there in terms of female directors?

Weâ€™ll see at the end of the year when the directors guild tells us how many [there are]. It was a year or two ago we thought it was getting better and it got like 1 percent worse, so letâ€™s hope. Thatâ€™s my takeaway too; it seems like thereâ€™s more diversity in terms of directors on TV. One thing we all can do â€• almost every time I direct I have a mentee with me, a woman, usually. Ryan Murphy really has been doing it for a few years now. He has a mentee program where every time you direct you have a woman or a person of color following you around. He really is in it for the long haul in helping to make sure theyâ€™re actually hired to direct. He deserves a ton of credit, I think.
He definitely pushed this before anyone else.
And the way heâ€™s pushing it is, again, with money. Heâ€™s hiring people.
At the Oscars this year, Frances McDormand brought up the inclusion rider, which requires a certain level of diversity among a filmâ€™s cast and crew.
I think itâ€™s fantastic. It comes back to the same thing: hire people.
Are you going to focus on directing as you have been doing or are we going to see you more on screen this year?

At the moment I have some acting and some directing on my plate, so Iâ€™m really excited about that. And some writing! Iâ€™m working hard and enjoying never having to choose between those things. Iâ€™ve never been comfortable saying, â€œIâ€™m more of a comedic actress than a dramatic actress! I prefer this screen over that screen!â€ I just want to be a part of telling good stories, and today Iâ€™m getting to do that. Thatâ€™s great news.
â€œThe Miracle Seasonâ€ is in theaters now.

otherData.headline: Facebook's Tracking Of Non-Users Sparks Broader Privacy Concerns
otherData.short_description: CEO Mark Zuckerberg said that, for security reasons, the company collects â€œdata of people who have not signed up for Facebook.â€

articleContent: By David Ingram

SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Concern about Facebook Incâ€™s respect for data privacy is widening to include the information it collects about non-users, after Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg said the worldâ€™s largest social network tracks people whether they have accounts or not.

Privacy concerns have swamped Facebook since it acknowledged last month that information about millions of users wrongly ended up in the hands of political consultancy Cambridge Analytica, a firm that has counted U.S. President Donald Trumpâ€™s 2016 electoral campaign among its clients.
Zuckerberg said on Wednesday under questioning by U.S. Representative Ben LujÃ¡n that, for security reasons, Facebook also collects â€œdata of people who have not signed up for Facebook.â€
Lawmakers and privacy advocates immediately protested the practice, with many saying Facebook needed to develop a way for non-users to find out what the company knows about them.

â€œWeâ€™ve got to fix that,â€ Representative LujÃ¡n, a Democrat, told Zuckerberg, calling for such disclosure, a move that would have unclear effects on the companyâ€™s ability to target ads. Zuckerberg did not respond. On Friday Facebook said it had no plans to build such a tool.

Critics said that Zuckerberg has not said enough about the extent and use of the data. â€œItâ€™s not clear what Facebook is doing with that information,â€ said Chris Calabrese, vice president for policy at the Center for Democracy & Technology, a Washington advocacy group.
COOKIES EVERYWHERE

Facebook gets some data on non-users from people on its network, such as when a user uploads email addresses of friends. Other information comes from â€œcookies,â€ small files stored via a browser and used by Facebook and others to track people on the internet, sometimes to target them with ads.
â€œThis kind of data collection is fundamental to how the internet works,â€ Facebook said in a statement to Reuters.

Asked if people could opt out, Facebook added, â€œThere are basic things you can do to limit the use of this information for advertising, like using browser or device settings to delete cookies. This would apply to other services beyond Facebook because, as mentioned, it is standard to how the internet works.â€

Facebook often installs cookies on non-usersâ€™ browsers if they visit sites with Facebookâ€likeâ€ and â€œshareâ€ buttons, whether or not a person pushes a button. Facebook said it uses browsing data to create analytics reports, including about traffic to a site.
The company said it does not use the data to target ads, except those inviting people to join Facebook.
TARGETING FACEBOOK

Advocates and lawmakers say they are singling out Facebook because of its size, rivaled outside China only by Alphabet Incâ€™s Google, and because they allege Zuckerberg was not forthcoming about the extent and reasons for the tracking.

â€œHeâ€™s either deliberately misunderstanding some of the questions, or heâ€™s not clear about whatâ€™s actually happening inside Facebookâ€™s operation,â€ said Daniel Kahn Gillmor, a senior staff technologist at the American Civil Liberties Union.

Zuckerberg, for instance, said the collection was done for security purposes, without explaining further or saying whether it was also used for measurement or analytics, Gillmor said, adding that Facebook had a business incentive to use the non-user data to target ads.
Facebook declined to comment on why Zuckerberg referred to security only.
Gillmor said Facebook could build databases on non-users by combining web browsing history with uploaded contacts. Facebook said on Friday that it does not do so.
The ACLU is pushing U.S. lawmakers to enact broad privacy legislation including a requirement for consent prior to data collection.

The first regulatory challenge to Facebookâ€™s practices for non-users may come next month when a new European Union law, known as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), takes effect and requires notice and consent prior to data collection.

At a minimum, â€œFacebook is going to have to think about ways to structure their technology to give that proper notice,â€ said Woodrow Hartzog, a Northeastern University professor of law and computer science.
Facebook said in its statement on Friday, â€œOur products and services comply with applicable law and will comply with GDPR.â€
The social network would be wise to recognize at least a right to know, said Michael Froomkin, a University of Miami law professor.
â€œIf Iâ€™m not a Facebook user, I ought to have a right to know what data Facebook has about me,â€ Froomkin said.
(Reporting by David Ingram; Editing by Peter Henderson and Richard Chang)

otherData.headline: A Peek Inside 'Divas Live,' Pop Music's Greatest Worship Service
otherData.short_description: On the 20th anniversary, here's how all-star women came together for a concert extravaganza filled with as much drama as there was glory.

articleContent: The New York air was crisp and calm on the night of April 14, 1998. But inside the Beacon Theater on Manhattanâ€™s Upper West Side, a fire blazed. The faithful had gathered. A religious ceremony was to take place. Six deities waited in the wings, but they neednâ€™t proselytize upon taking the stage. Every sane soul had already kneeled at their altar, and would do so again for several years to come.

The event, of course, was VH1â€²s â€œDivas Live.â€ The gods were pop prima donnas: Aretha Franklin, Mariah Carey, CÃ©line Dion, Gloria Estefan, Shania Twain and Carole King who, separately and together, performed numbers from their respective catalogs. The worship service was a ratings smash, so the following year, VH1 increased the cause for hosannas. Whitney Houston, Tina Turner, Cher and Brandy headlined â€œDivas Live â€™99,â€ joined by Mary J. Blige, Chaka Khan, LeAnn Rimes, Faith Hill and â€œvery special guestâ€ Elton John. It became the highest-rated program in the networkâ€™s history, a grail for both VH1 and the world at large.

As almost any large-scale production can attest, putting at least half a dozen superstars on the same bill doesnâ€™t happen without a few hitches â€• and altercations â€• along the way. So, ahead of the eventâ€™s 20th anniversary, I called up five producers who put together the first three â€œDivasâ€ shows (2000â€²s was a Diana Ross tribute featuring Carey, Hill, Donna Summer, Destinyâ€™s Child and RuPaul) to see just how much gossip I could marshal about these glittery exaltations.
Grab some popcorn. Or a little holy water.
1. The Origins, Or: On The First Day, God Created CÃ©line

Heading into 1998, a VH1 executive by the name of Wayne Isaak, whoâ€™d spent more than a decade as a publicity guru at A&M Records, was courting CÃ©line Dion for a â€œbig concert eventâ€ that would appeal to the networkâ€™s core audience: adults 24 to 35, particularly women, whoâ€™d made insidery fodder like â€œBehind the Music,â€ â€œStorytellersâ€ and â€œCrossroadsâ€ appointment viewing.

Around the same time, Isaak and the rest of VH1â€²s original-programming team was in need of a tentpole to replace the networkâ€™s eponymous Honors special, a lackluster ceremony that, between 1994 and 1997, saluted musiciansâ€™ philanthropic work. Conveniently, the network had just launched the Save the Music Foundation, a nonprofit that donated instruments to public schools. Top brass seized the opportunity to raise funds for the organization and stage an all-star revue.

Isaak knew he could get Dion, but Lauren Zalaznick, a former marketing whiz who would go on to run Bravo, pushed for a franchise that would serve as a brand unto itself. So Isaak pitched an idea called â€œThree Divas,â€ a twist on the popular opera group known as the Three Tenors. The team thought to capitalize on the banner moment that women in music were enjoying. Sarah McLachlan had recently inaugurated Lilith Fair. Missy Elliott and Lilâ€™ Kim were eating up the hip-hop scene. At the female singer-songwriter apex sat figures like Alanis Morissette and Tori Amos. Madonna and Lauryn Hill were on the cusp of releasing career-defining records. The 1999 Grammys would boast a rare all-female Album of the Year roster.

Isaak pitched Dion on the idea of joining Aretha Franklin and Mariah Carey for â€œThree Divas,â€ to which she apparently gave her resounding approval. With that, the concept quickly snowballed. What if we add Gloria Estefan, Isaak asked. â€œOf course,â€ everyone responded. And how about Shania Twain? Well, that was a bit iffier.

Twain had a couple of modest pop hits to her name, but she was still predominately a country draw. With her third album, â€œCome On Over,â€ released to widespread acclaim in November 1997, her record label was working to turn her into a mainstream crossover virtuoso â€• a prospect aided by VH1, which put Twainâ€™s videos in frequent rotation. But she wasnâ€™t quite there yet when Isaak tried to convince his colleagues to place her in the same lineup as Franklin, Carey, Dion and Estefan.

â€œI didnâ€™t want Shania Twain,â€ Zalaznick recalled. â€œI didnâ€™t think she fit the bill as a diva. But he really convinced me that she was going to be the biggest artist of the year that year, and I think he was right.â€

By the time â€œDivas Liveâ€ aired in April, Isaakâ€™s premonition had come true. â€œYouâ€™re Still the Oneâ€ was a mega-smash, turning Twain into a household name and giving her the third most popular song of 1998, per Billboardâ€™s year-end chart. In fact, Twainâ€™s segment was the highest-rated quarter-hour of the entire â€œDivasâ€ broadcast, according to Isaak.
